issue_title: Distance mis-reported
body:
I'm running the following code:

```
var
  turf = require('turf'),
  distance = turf.distance,
  point = turf.point,
  unit = 'miles';


console.log(distance(point(42.954553, -81.347474),point(46.471034, -80.980912),unit));
```

The result I'm getting is:
```
45.105636619364745
```

Now, those two coordinates are London, Ontario and Sudbury, Ontario which are over 240 miles apart, checked against [this](http://tjpeiffer.com/crowflies.html). Other coordinates seem to be reporting rational distances. Am I doing something wrong or is this a bug?

issue_title: Distance mis-reported
Cleanup posts template.
body:
No issue.

* Fix indentation (it was surprisingly hard for me to grok what was happening without indentation).
* Utilize `alternateActive` from `core/client/utils/link-view.js` to maintain the `active` state. Observing `childViews` is deprecated (and may not work properly in future versions of Ember).
* Remove now unused `item-view`.
repo_description: Just a blogging platform

issue_title: Do not use static and {{bind-attr}} for the same attribute.
body:
No issue.

This would work in pre-HTMLBars land for the initial render (but any rerenders would lose the static attribute name). Added https://github.com/emberjs/ember.js/pull/10096 to throw an assertion when this occurs.

issue_title: Support for Windows
body:
@michaeldrotar I think you may be experiencing a different problem to @blowsie as you're not seeing the `'true' is not recognized as an internal or external command...` error. It might be that the `which` executable is not found/available on your system.

The `which brew >/dev/null 2>&1 && eval $(brew --env) && echo $PKG_CONFIG_LIBDIR` part of PKG_CONFIG_PATH is applicable for Macs only. We need to work out a portable way of making Windows ignore any error it generates, like the `|| true` command does for Linux.

I now have in my possession a new Windows 8.1 laptop so hope to make a bit more progress with this. Please do keep adding comments to this issue about your own attempts of getting it working as these all help narrow down the problems.

(On a multi-platform note, I managed to get libvips and sharp working on an ARMv6 Raspberry Pi over Christmas. WebP support was the trickiest bit to get working.)
issue_labels.name: [enhancement, help-required]

issue_title: Remove ObjectController proxying behavior.
body:
No issue.

Ember.ObjectController (and Ember.ArrayController) will be deprecated in Ember 1.11 (and removed from core in Ember 2.0). The reasoning is detailed in the Ember 2.0 RFC.

This PR does the following:

* Updates templates/controllers/views to explicitly reference model properties (instead of relying on proxying behavior).
* Clearly delineate where certain properties are being set or retrieved from (for example it was not clear exactly where `scratch` and `titleScratch` were stored).
* Remove usage of `Ember.ObjectController`.
* Add JSCS rule to prevent future PR's from adding regressions.

References:

* https://github.com/emberjs/ember.js/pull/10062 - Deprecate Ember.ObjectController
* https://github.com/emberjs/rfcs/pull/15 - The Road to Ember 2.0
repo_description: Just a blogging platform

issue_title: Remove ObjectController proxying behavior.
body: To test the deprecation in https://github.com/emberjs/ember.js/pull/10062 I also confirmed that with these changes (and the last couple of PR's I submitted) the Ghost test suite passes properly on Ember canary (which will ultimately be 1.11) and Ember 1.10.0-beta.3.

issue_title: Problem putting image into footer
body:
Header is printed to pdf in a synchronous way. This mean any async request like getting image will not finish in time. This is current limitation of phantom.js

Solution 1:
Add the same image to template content and hide it with style display:none. Then you can add it to the header and it will show up because it is already cached and no async request is needed.

Solution 2:
Use base64 encoding and Data URI scheme to embed image directly.

issue_title: Make swagger-ui configurable with a separate js/json file
body:
Swagger-ui is mostly great already by default but would be great if there was an easy way to modify some of it's parameters without needing to copy-paste the whole index.html (with lots of dependencies, custom copies get easily out of sync with the master).

**Suggestion**: separate `swagger-ui-config.js` file read in the index.html, which has good/current defaults, easily overridable in the client project. Parameters like:

- `base-href` (known by the server)
- `authorization` (oauth2 confs etc)
- `do-not-put-link-to-the-sample-petstore`

... or some other way to externalize the swagger configuration into a separate minimalistic javascript-file.

issue_title: How to wait until page freezes in protractor?
body:
It depends on how you added the scroll; if your scroll action/library contains `setTimeout`, it will not work, otherwise it should work out of the box if `ignoreSynchronization` isn't set.

That being said, using a click/coordinates to identify an element is never a good idea, as it requires you to change the coordinate every time you make a small change to your app.

issue_title: feat: Fail on launcher-, reporter-, or preprocessor-load errors.
body:
Karma should fail if any plugin can't be instantiated. That is: launcher, preprocessor, reporter.

Btw, I like the idea of collecting all errors and then failing, so that user sees all the errors and not only the first one.

Here are all the places where Karma instantiate plugins and thus a fatal error can happen (in order in which it happens):
1. Loading plugins (loading the DI modules):
https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/blob/6d5330981b13a1df75f1037ded532429cabd77cb/lib/server.js#L310
2. Instantiate reporters
https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/blob/51f1b8832b86c4f556b58381fa183776212cfaa7/lib/reporter.js#L85
3. Instantiating frameworks (inside `start` function):
https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/blob/6d5330981b13a1df75f1037ded532429cabd77cb/lib/server.js#L30
4. Start browsers (after the webserver is ready listening):
https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/blob/6d5330981b13a1df75f1037ded532429cabd77cb/lib/server.js#L69
5. Instantiate preprocessors (this happens lazily, once the preprocessor is needed; we need to change that and instantiate all needed preprocessors ahead, inside `createPreprocessor` factory)
https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/blob/6d5330981b13a1df75f1037ded532429cabd77cb/lib/preprocessor.js#L88

Thus, I would add the check into the [webserver listener](https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/blob/6d5330981b13a1df75f1037ded532429cabd77cb/lib/server.js#L72), after launching browsers (), and fail Karma if any error occurred. At that point, all of the plugins were instantiated, except preprocessors. We need to change preprocessors to instantiate all needed preprocessors ahead (in the `createPreprocessor` factory), instead of lazily.


I'm sorry this is confusing. I think it would be good to refactor Karma to instantiate everything first. Right now, "instantiating things" is kind of tangled together with bootstrapping (this is probably more efficient, but harder to understand). I wish I did it differently;-)

@srawlins Let me know if I can help you more. This is very valuable work you are doing!
issue_labels.name: [needs: review]

issue_title: Unicode Url ends in loop
body:
Ok I have looked a bit into the code and found the following test:

https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/blob/8df98b4f7dbb635c44834ad516db7ae3e5a97a32/core/test/functional/routes/admin_test.js#L114

Next looked up the documentation for this config parameter.
http://support.ghost.org/config/

Ok...

First I looked if setting forceAdminSSL to { redirect: false } has any effect.
Yes it has, but now I can't access the blog and get forbidden, so I tried setting urlSSL manual in some variants. With punycode, without punycode, with \u for unicode chars. Nothing made it to work.

Finally I discovered if set the url to http:// instead there is no redirecting and nginx will do the redirect instead.

issue_title: Remove ObjectController proxying behavior.
body:
No issue.

Ember.ObjectController (and Ember.ArrayController) will be deprecated in Ember 1.11 (and removed from core in Ember 2.0). The reasoning is detailed in the Ember 2.0 RFC.

This PR does the following:

* Updates templates/controllers/views to explicitly reference model properties (instead of relying on proxying behavior).
* Clearly delineate where certain properties are being set or retrieved from (for example it was not clear exactly where `scratch` and `titleScratch` were stored).
* Remove usage of `Ember.ObjectController`.
* Add JSCS rule to prevent future PR's from adding regressions.

References:

* https://github.com/emberjs/ember.js/pull/10062 - Deprecate Ember.ObjectController
* https://github.com/emberjs/rfcs/pull/15 - The Road to Ember 2.0

issue_title: Allow source maps for non-preprocessed files
body:
I put together a [`source-map-support` plugin](https://www.npmjs.com/package/karma-source-map-support) that improves stack traces in Chrome with inline source maps (like those produced from Browserify with the `debug` option).

Here's a comparison of a stack without/with this plugin.

```diff
--- stack-without	2015-01-02 15:02:55.000000000 -0700
+++ stack-with	2015-01-02 15:03:12.000000000 -0700
@@ -1,11 +1,11 @@
 AssertionError: case 2: expected [ 0, 0.6666666666666666 ] to deeply equal [ 0, 0.5 ]
-    at Function.assert.deepEqual (http://localhost:9876/absolute/var/folders/6m/3grlt52x7w3047wy0n6j7dr00000gn/T/2d4c510ad9122153a42db199d1cc8e9553208184.browserify:1848:32)
-    at Context.<anonymous> (http://localhost:9876/absolute/var/folders/6m/3grlt52x7w3047wy0n6j7dr00000gn/T/2d4c510ad9122153a42db199d1cc8e9553208184.browserify:6061:14)
+    at Function.assert.deepEqual (node_modules/chai/lib/chai/interface/assert.js:205:1)
+    at Context.<anonymous> (src/scenes/util/geom.test.js:27:1)
     at callFn (http://localhost:9876/base/node_modules/mocha/mocha.js:4496:21)
     at Test.Runnable.run (http://localhost:9876/base/node_modules/mocha/mocha.js:4489:7)
     at Runner.runTest (http://localhost:9876/base/node_modules/mocha/mocha.js:4892:10)
     at http://localhost:9876/base/node_modules/mocha/mocha.js:4970:12
     at next (http://localhost:9876/base/node_modules/mocha/mocha.js:4817:14)
     at http://localhost:9876/base/node_modules/mocha/mocha.js:4827:7
     at next (http://localhost:9876/base/node_modules/mocha/mocha.js:4766:23)
     at http://localhost:9876/base/node_modules/mocha/mocha.js:4794:5
```

The plugin simply delegates to the [`source-map-support` package](https://www.npmjs.com/package/source-map-support).

Things are still less than ideal.  The debugger doesn't generate clickable links for compiled sources.  I'll see if there's a way to address this.

Not sure if this will work for other cases, but it is working well for me when using [`karma-browserify`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/karma-browserify) to generate bundles before tests run.
issue_labels.name: [PR please, type: feature]

issue_title: fix(server): launch browsers when file_list is ready
body:
Short story: I agree we need to fix this issue, but I don't think this PR is the right solution. I'm not sure what is the cause of the issue is.

Long story: Here is how Karma works:
It starts the webserver, once the webserver is listening on given port, start browsers.
A browser opens `/` url, the webserver serves `static/client.html` for that url, which establishes socket.io connection - the browser is captured. Responding to this request does not wait for resolving the files.

When a test run starts, all browsers refresh an iframe with actual tests. This iframe points to `/context.html`. Webserver does delay serving of `/context.html`, until the `file_list` promise is resolved (it needs updated list of files in order to generate the `/context.html` response).

**Thus, capturing of the browser is not delayed until the files are resolved.**

I'm not sure what the actual cause of your problem is. Sounds like the Karma process is too busy resolving all the files (and possibly preprocessing them) and the webserver does not get scheduled to handle the requests from browser. Can you try it with some GUI browser, eg. Chrome and check out the timeline - how long does it take to serve the initial `/` request, including its resources (such as `static/karma.js`, socket.io, etc)? Then the browser sends a message (through socket.io), "register", how long does that message take? Also, how many files do you have (I would like to reproduce the issue? 
 
Let's figure out what the cause is and then we can fix it properly.

Can you open the timeline in the browser
This PR will make capturing browsers much slower (waiting for all files to be resolved and then starting browsers; it takes significant time for the browser to actually open the url). So I don't think this PR is a good solution.
issue_labels.name: [needs: investigation]

issue_title: Expected conditions in protractor
body:
This is a follow-up to [Expected conditions in protractor](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27737333/expected-conditions-in-protractor) stackoverflow topic.

Long story short, as far as I understand the closest analogy to explicit waits for expected conditions is using `browser.wait()`. 

In [python-selenium](http://selenium-python.readthedocs.org/en/latest/waits.html#explicit-waits) or [java-selenium](https://selenium.googlecode.com/git/docs/api/java/org/openqa/selenium/support/ui/ExpectedConditions.html), there are multiple built-in commonly used expected conditions shortcuts, like:

 * [text_to_be_present_in_element_value](http://selenium-python.readthedocs.org/en/latest/api.html#selenium.webdriver.support.expected_conditions.text_to_be_present_in_element_value)
 * [invisibility_of_element_located](http://selenium-python.readthedocs.org/en/latest/api.html#selenium.webdriver.support.expected_conditions.invisibility_of_element_located)
 * [title_is](http://selenium-python.readthedocs.org/en/latest/api.html#selenium.webdriver.support.expected_conditions.title_is)

Is it possible to have these shortcuts built-in to protractor? Or, if not, what would be the appropriate way to implement it and use with protractor?

If the request doesn't make any sense, please close the issue. Thank you!

issue_title: Expected conditions in protractor
body:
This is a follow-up to [Expected conditions in protractor](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27737333/expected-conditions-in-protractor) stackoverflow topic.

Long story short, as far as I understand the closest analogy to explicit waits for expected conditions is using `browser.wait()`. 

In [python-selenium](http://selenium-python.readthedocs.org/en/latest/waits.html#explicit-waits) or [java-selenium](https://selenium.googlecode.com/git/docs/api/java/org/openqa/selenium/support/ui/ExpectedConditions.html), there are multiple built-in commonly used expected conditions shortcuts, like:

 * [text_to_be_present_in_element_value](http://selenium-python.readthedocs.org/en/latest/api.html#selenium.webdriver.support.expected_conditions.text_to_be_present_in_element_value)
 * [invisibility_of_element_located](http://selenium-python.readthedocs.org/en/latest/api.html#selenium.webdriver.support.expected_conditions.invisibility_of_element_located)
 * [title_is](http://selenium-python.readthedocs.org/en/latest/api.html#selenium.webdriver.support.expected_conditions.title_is)

Is it possible to have these shortcuts built-in to protractor? Or, if not, what would be the appropriate way to implement it and use with protractor?

If the request doesn't make any sense, please close the issue. Thank you!

issue_title: Feature: Paste image from clipboard in editor
body:
While writing a blog post with Ghost i sometimes use the Windows/Ubuntu Snippet tool to copy images or make screenshots. 

**Current steps to add an image**

1. Open snippet tool
2. Select area to copy
3. Save image to folder
4. Open editor and press Ctrl + Shift + I to add image tag
5. Click on the image preview
6. Open popup, navigate to folder and choose image
7. Image added

**With paste support from clipboard these steps are reduced to**

1. Open snippet tool
2. Select area to copy
3. Open editor and press Ctrl + V
4. Image added

I've written a [plugin](https://github.com/Rovak/InlineAttachment) which allows users to paste content from the clipboard in a textarea or editors like CodeMirror. This plugin can be used, or only use the code which is relevant for the textarea editor.

Right now most browsers lack the support for listening to `paste` events, only Chrome supports it natively, Firefox works with some ugly hacks. I'm also not sure how pasting images would work on mobile.

If this feature is accepted then i can implement it and base it on #4373.

As an extra adding drag-drop support is fairly simple with these changes, it only requires hooking into a few native drag events. Both the `drag` and `paste` event have a `FileList` available from which to read the files.

By default, our drafts should not have preview links. We should set them up under the url menu in Post Settings with the following options:

After that if the post have been published, it would reset the link automatically to `null` and it is not accessible anymore

issue_title: Labs page checkboxes
body:
There are a couple issues with this right now that are going to have to be worked out.

We can't use anything that requires authentication from an initializer, because if the app is (re)loaded and there isn't an existing session, anything that needs an auth token will fail (i.e., the `store.find()` in `Feature`).

`Feature` can't be used anywhere that only gets one chance to "get" its computed properties.  So whereas it's okay to use in a template where its final value will be observed, somewhere like a Route's model hooks won't work, because they only get one chance to check the value.  The example I'm thinking of is checking whether the feature is enabled to allow access to a page: https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/blob/master/core/client/routes/settings/tags.js#L25. If you direct link to or reload the Tags page, you get booted out because `Feature` isn't ready yet.

I think the promise is going to need to be exposed from `Feature`, either manually or by using `PromiseProxyMixin`.

issue_title: Configurable umask for unix socket
body:
Hello,

would it be possible to add a configurable umask/chmod when using unix socket ?

Something along those lines would be awesome :

````js
server: {
    socket: '/path/to/ghost.socket',
    mask: 000
}
````
Otherwise, on *most* system with the default umask being at 002, the server must either be in the same group or the same user, which may not be desirable.

issue_title: "sh: 1: mocha: Permission denied" - Running mocha test via "npm test" fails
body:
I am attempting to use Mocha for testing in a project. I've followed the steps in this tutorial: https://www.joyent.com/blog/risingstack-writing-testable-apis-the-basics

My package.json looks like this:

```
{
  "name": "cyoab",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "private": true,
  "scripts": {
    "test": "mocha test"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "express": "~4.2.0",
    "static-favicon": "~1.0.0",
    "morgan": "~1.0.0",
    "mongoose": "*",
    "cookie-parser": "~1.0.1",
    "body-parser": "~1.0.0",
    "debug": "~0.7.4"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "mocha": "~2.1.0",
    "chai": "~1.10.0",
    "sinon": "~1.12.2"
  }
}
```

When I run "npm test" or "sudo npm test" I get the following output:

```
matt@matt-Inspiron-N5040:/media/matt/Storage1/Dev/cyoab$ sudo npm test

> cyoab@0.0.1 test /media/matt/Storage1/Dev/cyoab
> mocha test

sh: 1: mocha: Permission denied
npm ERR! weird error 126
npm WARN This failure might be due to the use of legacy binary "node"
npm WARN For further explanations, please read
/usr/share/doc/nodejs/README.Debian
 
npm ERR! not ok code 0
```

I have tried making mocha executable via chmod, but that didn't work.

I am using node v0.10.25 on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS.

Any ideas? Or am I posting this in the wrong place? I have a feeling it isn't necessarily a Mocha issue, but I'm not sure.

Thank you,

Matt

issue_title: [Feature] Improved post excerpts / previews
body:
The discussion of how best to round, whether to strip html or not etc in some way misses the point, as it seems to not consider the control of where an excerpt begins. This is what brought me to this thread after making my first post - if the first line of my post is a sub-heading, then it appears as plain text and therefore out of context. I want to limit my excerpt to the first paragraph following that heading.

The problem is also outlined here in the same way (wishing to exclude a leading blockquote): 
https://ghost.org/forum/using-ghost/17745-exclude-content-for-excerpt/
...and partially addressed (through a hack) here:
https://ghost.org/forum/using-ghost/15991-customize-post-preview/.

In both situations, the desired behaviour is to specify both start and end points for an excerpt via tags in the HTML. This obviates the need for ghost controlled rounding up/down by paragraph at all...

Thanks!
issue_labels.name: [themes]

issue_title: [Feature] Tag Management
body:
Howdy, unsure if this is the place to report it, knowing it is still being worked on.. but I've not been able to find it reported elsewhere..

I use ghost with the "fileStorage: false" option in my config due to the use of ephemeral storage and I noticed when using the tag management panel the section where an image is added has some odd behavior.

Initially there are multiple submit boxes and buttons for what presumably should simply be one box for the URL and a submit button.. But, even more interesting is if one clicks away out of this tag-info section and moves to another tag, and then another tag after that.. the URL boxes and submit buttons keep building up.

If one clicks away to another section, such as 'General' or 'Users' and returns to the 'tags' section to again click on a tag to edit its tag-info section, it returns to the initial errant amount of URL boxes and submit buttons.

this is happening on 0.5.7 with a postgres database and filestorage disabled.
 
here are some images showing first the initial state, and second what happens after navigating to a few other tags:

issue_title: Ghost Labs - Checkboxes to override config flags
body:
We're starting to develop certain features behind config flags, like tags, and perhaps soon OAuth / public API, custom permalinks, code injection, apps and maybe even search or i18n.

As we roll these out people are going to want to play with them, and we ***want*** people playing with these new features in advance, finding bugs, discovering usability issues etc.

So how about, as well as having a config flag, we make a 'Ghost Labs' page that provides the ability to turn on these options. The Ghost Labs page would be a hidden page a lot like our Ugly Debug Tools, that would simply live at `/settings/labs/` with no internal link.

We can add a 'labs' setting to the settings DB that stores a JSON object with a boolean value for each feature we add to the page and whether it's on or off - which overrides the config value.

This might be a teeny bit fiddly to implement, but I think it could be a lot of fun, and a great way to get more feedback on features whilst they are in development. It would give us a space to try things out that we aren't sure about, or provide different potential solutions and experiment a little bit with what works best in practice.
issue_labels.name: [settings]

issue_title: Bug: Tag Settings Menu Shows Multiple URL and Submit Items for Tag Image Field When Using fileStorage: false
body:
### Issue Summary
The Tag Settings Menu that is activated upon navigating to the Tags section of Settings shows multiple URL input boxes and multiple submit buttons if the "fileStorage: false" config option is set. 

When navigating to other tags in the Tags section of Settings the total amount of URL input boxes and submit buttons increases on each tag that one navigates to. 

When navigating away from the Tags section of Settings (example: going to Users) and returning to the Tags section and navigating to the TSM for a tag the initial number of errant URL input boxes returns.
 
### Steps to Reproduce

Set the "fileStorage: false" setting in config.js. Enable "tagsUI: true" in config.js. 

Go to Ghost Admin page and navigate to Settings -> Tags. Select a tag to activate the Tag Settings Menu slide-out. See the Tag Image Field being displayed improperly as in the first attached image.

Select a different tag from the one initially selected from within the Tags section of Settings to enable the Tag Settings Menu slide-out once again. See that the number of URL fields and Submit buttons has increased as in the second attached image.

The correct behavior should be one that matches the rest of Ghost while the "fileStorage: false" setting is being utilized: One URL field and One Submit button.

### Technical details

* Ghost Version: Release 0.5.7
* Client OS: Windows Vista SP2 with all recent updates
* Server OS: Heroku platform, Cedar-14 stack
* Node Version: 0.10.35
* Browser: Chrome 39.0.2171.95 m
* Database: PostgreSQL

![tags1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7681885/5607610/efc90e02-942f-11e4-9ad4-443329538cb3.png)


![tags3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7681885/5607611/f41ef20a-942f-11e4-81d2-aca5ef5bf641.png)

issue_title: Breaking changes.
body:
I'm really sorry for the inconvenience here. I really didn't intend to do anything shitty.

I don't really know of a good way other than the usual semver major version change to let people know about breaking changes. Is there some specific reason you can't continue to use v1?

issue_title: Breaking changes.
body:
Yea, we released with >1.0.0 in our packages.json, something we often do because we trust upstream authors not to implementing breaking changes without notifying us of deprecated methods.

Excuse me for being blunt but we're getting annoyed users...

What really needs to happen here is a new version is released by yourself.   This new version rolls back the API and notifies users for X months that methods are deprecated (This can be each time they are used)..   Your V2 should support methods from V1, but under a deprecated flag, that's pretty much all...  Is that doable?

issue_title: Breaking changes.
body:
I totally understand the problem with annoyed users, and I've experienced the same problem with a dependency breaking out from under me. (Although in that case, it was major breaking changes at the patch level, which is not at all something you should expect.) In any case, I'm really sorry.

I implemented this as a major version change because semver explicitly permits breaking changes between major versions. You're right that ideally I would have let people know somehow, and some sort of deprecation notice would have been a lot better experience.

Before I pushed any of this I made sure that all the v1 tests pass with the exception of filters. Is that the feature that you're depending on in your project?

issue_title: Can't dynamically create tests
body:
You can generate tests in this way, but `before()` only runs after all tests have been defined.

If you populate `TEST_NAMES` in the `describe()` directly instead of the `before()` your example will work as you expect.

issue_title: Breaking changes.
body: All right, I've pushed a fix for this in v2.0.6. EtherpadLite's bootstrap code is directly accessing the internals of the EJS lib, using an undocumented internal variable directly. This is clearly not a great idea. (Blind updates between major versions of a supporting lib aren't nearly as heinous, but they're also a recipe for breakage. See http://semver.org/ for what types of changes to expect at different version levels.) I'll be removing this bandaid eventually. Let me know if you need some help figuring out how to clean up that bootstrap code.

issue_title: Why can't I use / in a permalink?
body: Because `/` has special meaning. In WP it seems you did `/date/title` for your permalinks. You can include dates in the permalinks via Ghost settings & then title the post as "post". I don't know why you would call the post "post", but then it would have the structure of `http://domain.com/04-01-2014/post`.

issue_title: Seedrandom is slow
body:
Seedrandom is careful, but slow.  It is about 9x slower than native Math.random(), which is acceptable if you don't need too much randomness.  But if you need a lot of randomness, you want a seedable prng about the same speed as Math.random().

A possible solutions is to offer alternate algorithms such as:
https://github.com/davidbau/seedrandom/tree/xorshift/xor

>>> NOTE: If you change the location of the content/ directory Ghost expects to find the same directory structure that exists in the module. To get started copy the default content directory structure as the basis for your custom content/ location.

issue_title: Use special symbols in grep
body:
Let's say we have three describe() blocks:

```js
describe('booking/summary', function(){...})
describe('coolTest/nonsense', function(){...})
describe('component/booking/summary', function(){...})
```

And then we want to run only first block ```booking/summary``` with ?grep=booking/summary it will launch both ```'booking/summary'``` and ```'component/booking/summary'```

Proposal is to allow special symbols, at least ```^``` to mark the beginning of the line. Ideally, both ```^``` and ```$``` should be allowed to be sure that you'll run specific test without any chance finding suite name somewhere inside another suite.
issue_labels.name: [Feature, PR PLEASE]

issue_title: Swagger UI gives `no zlib library` and `no iconv library` warnings
body:
To repro:

1. git clone git@github.com:apigee-127/swagger-tools.git
2. cd swagger-tools/examples/2.0
3. npm install
4. node index.js
5. Surf to `http://localhost:3000/docs/`

You should get something along

```
 base is http://localhost:3000/docs/
shred.bundle.js:1726 no zlib library
shred.bundle.js:1734 no iconv library
swagger-ui.js:71 Loaded SwaggerUI
```

Tested in Chrome and Firefox.

The UI runs but it might be nice to have the warnings fixed as they might hide some issues.

Original report at https://github.com/apigee-127/swagger-tools/issues/114 .

issue_title: When running focused specs output shows other specs as passed
body:
This is an issue with Jasmine 1.3. Protractor simply reports the results from Jasmine and there is nothing Protractor can/should do to fix this.
That being said, it is fixed in Jasmine 2.0; follow this for protractor's status for supporting jasmine 2.0: https://github.com/angular/protractor/issues/362

issue_title: manage database state during test runs
body:
We want to do E2E testing between our Angular app and our API using Protractor. We can't figure out how to setup the database before and between tests.

We want the ability to add a specific record or records before a given test runs and then reset the database after that test runs.

We've investigated using this mostly Ruby stack: RSpec, Database Cleaner, FactoryGirl, Capybara, and Poltergeist. This works OK but is infested with `sleep` calls. We'd therefore prefer to use Protractor. 

Unfortunately, it doesn't seem that Protractor has any capabilities to manage database state. Does anyone have any advice on how to handle this?
issue_labels.name: [type: question]

issue_title: [Feature Request] Should be possible to init Ghost with a config object
body:
Hi @coen-hyde, welcome to Ghost's GitHub. 

I see you've got both an issue and a PR, and you've closed the issue in favour of the PR but I'm commenting here because the issue is really the best place to discuss the merits of the feature request, and also we usually use GitHub's features to close an issue with a PR if it is decided it's something we want to add. 

We've got some [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) that might be worth a bit of a read - both in relation to feature requests and the format of your PR, but in short, my main concern here is that neither the issue you've raised not the PR really explain your use case or why it would be worthwhile to add this extra level of complexity to Ghost.

There's already a couple of different ways to specify the path to a config file, including passing in a path or setting an environment variable, and there is no discussion of why these are not suitable. Adding yet-another-way to specify config adds quite significant complexity especially when you consider how rare the use case is  - it's something that's easy to end up getting broken in future. Therefore I'd like to be convinced that there is a definite use case for this.

issue_title: [TASK] Update jshintrc
body:
I agree with @clark800 that removing both `boss` and `W004` would make the jshintrc file a bit better. The goal is to have the hinting as a tool that makes it easier to catch bad practices or coding styles we don't prefer.

The (case)[https://github.com/ripple/ripple-lib/blob/develop/src/js/ripple/transaction.js#L503] @wltsmrz pointed out doesn't look like great coding practice to me. I'm sure you can use it responsibly but it's hard to read and easy to misunderstand. Allowing assignments where a boolean evaluation is expected should not be a best practice.

For `W004`, I'm not sure if it's more readable to keep `var`. Effectively redefining a var or assigning a previously assigned var doesn't change anything logically, but you might accidentally override a var in your scope you didn't intend to. I expect that to be the reason for jshint to have this option.

Right now we do manual inspection of a pull request to enforce stylistic changes and avoid gotchas. I would like to make the jshint checking part of the test process so it will actually fail the test. That's essentially the same thing as blocking a pull request by a comment for a stylistic change, but now it's automated. It does not replace code review, it's part of the automated tests and makes code reviews a little easier. A certain set of stylistic preferences and gotchas shouldn't come up in code reviews anymore since the hinting will have already caught that.

> The goal is to have the hinting as a tool that makes it easier to catch bad practices or coding styles we don't prefer.

Agreed

> The (case)[https://github.com/ripple/ripple-lib/blob/develop/src/js/ripple/transaction.js#L503] @wltsmrz pointed out doesn't look like great coding practice to me. I'm sure you can use it responsibly but it's hard to read and easy to misunderstand. Allowing assignments where a boolean evaluation is expected should not be a best practice.

It's easy to read and hard to misunderstand, to me. It's unlikely that anyone is going to use this without knowing what they're doing. Making jshint more strict in this regard won't catch any bugs

> I would like to make the jshint checking part of the test process so it will actually fail the test. That's essentially the same thing as blocking a pull request by a comment for a stylistic change, but now it's automated.

Bad idea, IMO. You'll still have to review code for style, because jshint is quite lacking. I definitely don't agree with failing tests for jshint.

issue_title: Oauth2 password flow
body:
Hi. I'm trying to use the oauth2 feature with password flow from swagger 2.0 spec. I dont' know if I'm doing thing wrong or if there some missing stuff, but let me explain. This is my spec:

```
swagger: '2.0'

info:
  title: BakPak API
  description: BakPak server API
  version: '1.0.0'

host: localhost:5000
basePath: /api/v1

schemes:
  - http
  - https

consumes:
  - application/json

produces:
  - application/json

securityDefinitions:
  basicPassword:
    type: oauth2
    flow: password
    tokenUrl: http://localhost:5000/api/v1/token
    scopes:
      s1: Scope 1
      s2: Scope 2
    
paths:
  /token:
    get:
      tags:
        - auth
      summary: Get an authentication token
      description: Get an authentication token
      operationId: GetToken
      responses:
        '200':
          description: ""
        default:
          description: Operation failed.
  /test:
    get:
      summary: Test endpoint
      description: Test endpoint
      responses:
        '200':
          description: ""
        default:
          description: Operation failed.
      security:
        - basicPassword:
          - s1
          - s2  
  /user:
    post:
      tags:
        - user
      summary: Add a user
      description: Add a user
      operationId: AddUser
      parameters:
        - name: body
          in: body
          description: Type can be `bp`, `facebook` or `google`.
          schema:
            $ref: '#/definitions/Credentials'
      responses:
        '200':
          description: ""
        default:
          description: Operation failed.
          
definitions:
  Credentials:
    properties:
      type:
        type: string
      username:
        type: string
      password:
        type: string
      token:
        type: string
```

I have a `/test` endpoint just to test oauth2. I remove the comment in `index.html` to enable oauth2 flow:
```
            initOAuth({
              clientId: "your-client-id",
              realm: "your-realms",
              appName: "your-app-name"
            });
```

When I click on the **"on/off"** button to authorize, a new windows browser is opened with the following url `http://localhost:5000/swagger-ui/null&redirect_uri=http://localhost:5000/swagger-ui/o2c.html&realm=your-realms&client_id=your-client-id&scope=s1,s2`.

Note the `null` in the url. It is normal? I'm not super familiar with every aspect of oauth, but I was expecting a popup for username/password and somehow receiving at some endpoint a `POST` with a 
`application/x-www-form-urlencoded` in the request body like this:
`grant_type=password&username=johndoe&password=A3ddj3w`

reference: http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.3.2

issue_title: Change Request: Bring "themePath" into config.
body:
I found the need to separate the `themes` directory (or `themePath` in the code) from the `content` directory. In my case, I am installing Ghost via NPM, and my project directory looks like this:

```
/themes
   /casper
config.js
index.js
package.json
```

I don't want to keep `content` in my repository, because that is dynamically updated on the server, but I do want to keep `themes` in my repository, because that is where I edit the ui of my site.

I found that this change was pretty easy to implement, and I already have it working in a fork. You can see a comparison of the branches here <https://github.com/rchrd2/Ghost/compare/TryGhost:master...master>. I only modified three lines.

While, I found it useful to customize `themePath`, it might be even better to allow all paths to be configured (ie `apps`, `data`, `images`). I can't think of a specific use case, but why not solve this in a general way?

Either way, I can submit a pull request for my `themePath` if that seems okay. I think others might want to make this same change. What do others think?

### Example Config.js
```
...
      url: 'http://example.com',
      mail: {},
      database: {
          client: 'sqlite3',
          connection: {
              filename: path.join(__dirname, '/shared/content/data/ghost.db')
          },
          debug: false
      },

      server: {
          host: '0.0.0.0',
          port: '5000'
      },
      paths: {
          contentPath: path.join(__dirname, '/shared/content/'),
          themePath: path.join(__dirname, '/themes')
      }
  },
...
```

issue_title: Forgive me for this but ghost editor need spelling checker please
body:
I know this is a closed issue but I would like to ask this question here for reference, please let me know if you want me to discuss somewhere else. 

There have been quite a few talks of using hacks and plugins to enable this temporarily, the browser plugin doesn't seem to be working any more and I've tried adding ```spellcheck="true"``` as per @eduncan911 's suggestion with no success. 

I understand that there is a work in progress to fix this (which is awesome :+1: ) but is there anything that we can do in the mean time? Even if it is horribly hacky? 

Just a bit of context: I'm Dyslexic and this issue seriously affects me. I have had a reasonably embarrassing experience (which i'm used to) publishing a blog with mistakes in it, but the problem is I was unaware that the spell checker wasn't working. Anything that we can do to warn users would be helpful at this stage before a bigger release. 

When is the https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/pull/4373 due to land? i.e. what release number are we aiming for?

issue_title: server timeout between  message is too short and shall be configurable
body:
There is a timeout mechanism in place to let the server drops a connection if the time between a the client connection and the first HEL message.
The default value is currently 1000ms. This timeout parameter shall be made configurable  to cope with slow client devices.

issue_title: Forgive me for this but ghost editor need spelling checker please
body:
Using the chrome emulator to pretend your browser is a touch screen might work - but spellcheck=true won't work because the thing you're typing into on a non-touchscreen is CodeMirror, not a textarea, and the browsers don't recognise it as an editor (hence no spellcheck).

We don't work to any sort of planned releases - we're open source and it simply doesn't work. Right now, I have in mind that there'll be a release very soon with tag management, and the next one should hopefully feature the new editor providing there are no major issues when we merge it in and start testing it properly. 

The best thing anyone can do to help is go to #4373 and follow the instructions to test out the demo of the new editor - @mansona why not compose your posts in the demo editor that has spell check and copy them over afterwards? That sort of real-world testing is critical to shipping such a big change ;)
issue_labels.name: [bug, editor]

I am using Protractor and PhantomJS in a continuous integration process. We build the project on a remote web server and launch E2E tests using Grunt, Protractor and PhantomJS. I am using Jenkins for that. I also use protractor-html-screenshot-reporter to have reports and screenshots when tests failed.

The problem is that even all tests passed (I know it because the reports show me that), sometimes (about 50%) the execution failed because PhantomJS may have died at the end of the tests. It is annoying because, in Jenkins, I am using the return code of the execution to know if the tests passed.

var HtmlReporter = require('protractor-html-screenshot-reporter');

issue_title: Refactor Middleware + Express Apps
body:
I'm interested to hear if this went any further? There've been a lot of different attempts and angles on solving the middleware, and ghost-as-middleware problems, and I've spent significant time myself recently trying to figure out what steps to take to try to improve the core of Ghost core to make everything a bit nicer and specifically - more testable.

Going to cc @gleneivey, @JoshWillik, @hswolff and @jaswilli here - all people who have dived into the murky depths and tried to make Ghost better.

A couple of issues worth referencing as well:

* Good old #827 - we'd love to make Ghost usable as express middleware
* This issue - finishing up the partial refactor of the different express apps inside of Ghost
* The unloved #2182 - optimising Ghost boot (and potentially lazy-loading modules when they are needed rather than intialising everything at the beginning)
* And just for fun mentioning the idea that we'd like more dynamic routing: #4519 - so that routes like /author/ or /tag/ can be customised (and translated).

This is a massive bundle of stuff that I'd like to fix. At the heart of it all, we need to make the internal Ghost modules behave more like modules, and reduce the amount of glue we need to hold everything together. I've been thinking about how to unpick it into stages and I think, wait, know that task is way beyond one person. It would be great to work together to figure out how to rejig the Ghost internals into something simpler.

issue_title: Refactor Middleware + Express Apps
body:
I made some good progress, but came up against everything you just wrote, which put me exactly where I was a year ago: there needs to be a decent cleanup done here. And I have some ideas.

I wrote a bit reply here which I just deleted as I don't want to overwhelm :) but basically: yes. I walked right into a wall and couldn't go further without pulling up weeds and moving *everything* around which I know you don't want. `/core` needs to be gutted - it's put together in a very "script-y" way which means that modules are being treated as includes and everything is bound together.

Moving forward... I think a freeze should go in and a month taken to clean things up. Some ideas I had are:

 - Move modules to a `/lib` directory to keep with Node standards. Move isolated bits (authentication, caching, middleware stuff) into their own repos and reference them in package.json using a Github URL
 - Use an app.js file in the root to do what it's supposed to do: create the express app and configure it by calling into various Ghost modules
 - Simplify `/admin` by sticking the views in the views directory. There's no need to be tricky here, just pop it in there and let it go. No need for a second app either (the problem you encountered RE views missing was actually rather silly and easily fixed by passing an absolute reference to the admin view, not switching the views directory on the fly).

I'll stop here, I *sincerely* do not want to rehash our conversation from a year ago :). I'm happy to help as needed but for this to work we need to freeze things and restructure - and I'm all yours if you choose to.
issue_labels.name: [server]

issue_title: Refactor Middleware + Express Apps
body:
## Comments on #827 

I haven't been closely following the state of the ghost core for a little while, but I'm surprised #827 is still open.
Between the midddleware PR #3849 and the HTTPS bugfix from PR #4435, Ghost has been working as (mounted)middleware on [my site](https://www.joshwillik.com/blog) without issue for quite some time now. Both PRs still pass tests.

This is obviously going to be biased, but I've always felt that my approach to Ghost-as-middleware was the cleanest proposed solution. The **whole** implementation is [26 lines of code](https://github.com/JoshWillik/Ghost/blob/middleware/core/middleware.js). 

The only other real solution I've seen -- #4101 -- separates the boot process into totally different paths: ghost-standalone and ghost-as-middleware. I think this introduces unnecessary code complexity; there is more code surface area and the two paths functionally achieve the same result.

*Sidenote: #4101 bundles a lot of good changes, like being able to pass a config object directly instead of a config file path. I think a lot of the work going into that PR is fantastic. I just don't think it's the right way to go for ghost-as-middleware.*

I don't really have any thoughts on the second two, other than they're both great ideas.
Unfortunately I don't have the time to tackle either right now (unless you're looking for a new employee ;P)

Just my 2 cents.
*If I misunderstood the issue's purpose, my apologies, feel free to delete this comment.*
issue_labels.name: [server]

issue_title: Refactor Middleware + Express Apps
body: Also - I forgot to add this - the entire `api` module is a disaster. It's a data access interface as well as an HTTP endpoint - really hard to test (as I'm sure you've found out) and makes things difficult to use.

issue_title: Refactor Middleware + Express Apps
body:
@ErisDS I have an idea: what would be the best way to "arm-wave" a structure that might make sense that we could steer towards? In other words - a dart-board/target where we could look at files and functional bits and then split out exact tasks?

I think, for instance, that a great first step would be to identify the isolated bits that go into Ghost (off the top of my head): authentication, authorization (role-based stuff), CMS workflow, an HTTP API, a data-access surface, mutable config, the Ember app, caching, update-checker, etc.

Once these are laid out, the next step is moving them to their own modules with their own tests, Gruntfile, package.json, etc.

Once that's complete, then we mesh them all together into Ghost 0.7 :).

I'm happy to take a stab at this along with you and whomever - let's just decide what venue/format. Google docs maybe? I'm open to anything.
issue_labels.name: [server]

issue_title: Parameter of type "file" causing exception
body: I think the problem is, as soon as you set the Content-Type header manually, the boundary is missing. According to http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5392344/sending-multipart-formdata-with-jquery-ajax/5976031#5976031 the contentType option must be set to false to force jQuery to build the Content-Type header on it's own, including the correct boundary.

issue_title: Refactor Middleware + Express Apps
body:
I think I could have phrased my question a little better - I was thinking more along the lines of looking for specific examples of patterns inside of projects that we could use to nurture the Ghost internals a little. For example, during the boot process we do a lot of require('thing') and then thing.init() calls (this is what #2182 is sort of about).

Perhaps a good example to start on, would be the mailer - surely we can refactor it so it lazy-loads when we need to send mail, rather than initialising it on boot. 

It's small and serves a single purpose, so perhaps we can throw together some examples of an ideal structure for it, and use it as a template?
issue_labels.name: [server]

issue_title: Refactor Middleware + Express Apps
body:
re: splitting out modules into their own repo...at this point in time it's not necessary imo. I'd be more in favor of following what React has done and allow for usage of sub-modules within Ghost the way you can with React. [For an example look how this Three.js + React project uses modules within React.](https://github.com/Izzimach/react-three/blob/master/src/ReactTHREE.js#L24-33)

This would allow us to get our footing towards isolating individual functionality and still allow it to be exposed such that it could be used by 3rd-party libraries.

IMO the first tangible step towards making Ghost more modular is by shifting all the modules within Ghost to be run on demand, not upon being required and included in another file. I did some work on this, I'm not sure where it was left off however.

But what you said @robconery about Ghost being very "script-ey" is very true, and I think just moving away from that as strongly as possible will be a good first step.

Also I do think we need some idea of one top-level coordinator for a Ghost application instance. That being the thing that coordinates all the modules so that together it equates to a running Ghost application.
issue_labels.name: [server]

issue_title: Refactor Middleware + Express Apps
body:
Another thought would be to shift the code structure towards isolated modules, [similar to what Ember does](https://github.com/emberjs/ember.js/tree/master/packages).  This is where the `src` and the `tests` exist alongside each other and are treated as if they existed in isolation.

The Ghost app itself would be another module that just consumed the other ones.
issue_labels.name: [server]

issue_title: [TASK] Update jshintrc
Informing users when the autosave goes wrong
body:
This is effectively the follow on from #4543. We've now got autosave working much more reliably, and more importantly if things go wrong it will recover.

Further still, in 0.5.7 we got better session handling on the editor, such that if you get logged out (which is a common problem which interferes with autosave) you get the option to log in again via a modal on the editor, meaning less chance for losses.

However, there's still no warning to the user if autosave isn't working for some reason. A couple of different options were proposed in #4543 and #4558, which centered around the idea that a warning should be displayed if we get more than X failures in a row.

To take directly from @jaswilli's [comment on #4543](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/issues/4543#issuecomment-65112840)

> Instead of a flag indicating that an error has been shown, we could have a counter that gets incremented when auto-save is invoked and is set back to zero after a successful save. That way we could do something like:

```
if ((this.get('saveAttempts') % 5 === 0) && options.silent) {
  // show an error after 5 missed auto-saves
}
```

The main problem with these ideas is that we don't really know what's going on, so it's probably worth thinking about introducing better logging of events in Ghost, and using Ghost(Pro) to build a picture of what's needed. Still I wanted to record this before closing #4543 as something we probably need to do.
issue_labels.name: [design, ghost-ui]

issue_title: Critical Bug: Save is not reliable
body: We've not had further reports of save problems since releasing these fixes. That's no guarantee that everything is OK, but it's a pretty good sign. I've raised #4761 as a place to discuss the potential need for error notifications from the autosave and am closing this :)
issue_labels.name: [bug]

issue_title: Critical Bug: Save is not reliable
body:
We're getting reports of content going missing, even after manual saves and on posts that were seemingly published.

At this time, there is no clear reproduction case, all we know is the following is happening:

1. User opens editor and starts writing content
2. Something goes wrong
3. Posts appear to save but do not

What we know is that:
1. there are code paths where save errors are not handled in terms of showing an error (autosave is known to not show errors which needs revisiting, and there may be other code paths)
2. save errors are likely not being handled correctly in relation to the beforeunload alert/modal which warns users not to leave if their content isn't saved
3. we could recover more gracefully from failures (try again?)
4. it seems that there are code paths in which a save can appear to work but not have (i.e a manual save, with a green save notification)
issue_labels.name: [bug]

issue_title: Wrap account_tx binary parsing in async.setImmediate
body: Would be better to replace with `async.nextTick`. Internally `async.setImmediate` is assigned to `async.nextTick`, but the API docs only show `nextTick` as an available method (https://github.com/caolan/async#nextTick)

issue_title: Wrap account_tx binary parsing in async.setImmediate
body: Ah. I didn't read the docs, I read [the code](https://github.com/caolan/async/blob/master/lib/async.js#L86-L113). Internally async seems to [prefer](https://github.com/caolan/async/blob/master/lib/async.js#L553) setImmediate. I also prefer to use setImmediate. I have dozens of test cases.
The problem I note is that they look to be completely nondeterministic: sometimes test have success, some other time they fail.

The tests that fail do not include pages with a lot of jquery plugin. It is pure angular sometimes, with REST calls. But still they fail.

When does waitForAngular is applied and when does not?

The documentation says I shoudn't care of synchronization, but it does not look to be so true.

Is protractor following semver?

If it is, then please release a 1.5.1 patch with protractor.getInstance re-added, and bump current version to 2.0.0.  I can do a PR with the change if it's desired.

issue_title: Feature: Paste image from clipboard in editor
body:
After reading issue #1246 my understanding is that there were given 2 suggestions:

1. Use the current [Upload Plugin](https://github.com/blueimp/jQuery-File-Upload/) plugin and configure [pasteZone](https://github.com/blueimp/jQuery-File-Upload/wiki/Options#pastezone) to allow for pasting with the default paste shortcut in the editor. I guess this does not work out-of-the-box with the current codemirror editor.
2. Add the option to click the image placeholder (dropzone) and paste, this requires an extra button on the image placeholder.

The issue was closed because it required more consideration, which i agree if you choose for option 2. It is not intuitive.

My issue is based on the first suggestion, and the new textarea editor. No extra UI buttons, just an extra shortcut which automagically uploads the image from the clipboard and adds the image tag with the url in the current cursor position inside the editor. Users who use shortcuts expect paste to work in most applications.

issue_title: 1.5.0 breaks backwards compatibility
body: It's alright, thank you.

issue_title: [TASK] Update jshintrc
body:
Yeah, I can see why jshint behaves that way, but it would be nice if it did generate a warning for that case. I submitted an issue, so hopefully they will change that: https://github.com/jshint/jshint/issues/2081. But it would be nice to remove those extra parens in the meantime.

As for esnext, we should leave that in because we are planning on moving to Facebook Flow, which does es6 to es5 compilation, which means that we will be able to start using es6 language features, like the "let" keyword for lexical scoping. That will solve the remaining few cases where we are redeclaring variable names in an elegant way.

issue_title: [TASK] Update jshintrc
body:
> I submitted an issue, so hopefully they will change that: jshint/jshint#2081. 

This is not an accidental oversight. It's intentional, and it's the reason I used parentheses in the first place http://jshint.com/docs/options/#boss. Maybe the jshint people will have a change of heart

> As for esnext, we should leave that in because we are planning on moving to Facebook Flow, which does es6 to es5 compilation

I haven't been party to any such plans, but you can remove `esnext` until we make a decision on Facebook Flow. It was added to our javascript style guide repo to accommodate use of `const` in ripple-rest, but we don't use it [const] in ripple-lib

issue_title: Bug: Tag Settings Menu Shows Multiple URL and Submit Items for Tag Image Field When Using fileStorage: false
body:
### Issue Summary
The Tag Settings Menu that is activated upon navigating to the Tags section of Settings shows multiple URL input boxes and multiple submit buttons if the "fileStorage: false" config option is set. 

When navigating to other tags in the Tags section of Settings the total amount of URL input boxes and submit buttons increases on each tag that one navigates to. 

When navigating away from the Tags section of Settings (example: going to Users) and returning to the Tags section and navigating to the TSM for a tag the initial number of errant URL input boxes returns.
 
### Steps to Reproduce

Set the "fileStorage: false" setting in config.js. Enable "tagsUI: true" in config.js. 

Go to Ghost Admin page and navigate to Settings -> Tags. Select a tag to activate the Tag Settings Menu slide-out. See the Tag Image Field being displayed improperly as in the first attached image.

Select a different tag from the one initially selected from within the Tags section of Settings to enable the Tag Settings Menu slide-out once again. See that the number of URL fields and Submit buttons has increased as in the second attached image.

The correct behavior should be one that matches the rest of Ghost while the "fileStorage: false" setting is being utilized: One URL field and One Submit button.

### Technical details

* Ghost Version: Release 0.5.7
* Client OS: Windows Vista SP2 with all recent updates
* Server OS: Heroku platform, Cedar-14 stack
* Node Version: 0.10.35
* Browser: Chrome 39.0.2171.95 m
* Database: PostgreSQL

![tags1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7681885/5607610/efc90e02-942f-11e4-9ad4-443329538cb3.png)


![tags3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7681885/5607611/f41ef20a-942f-11e4-81d2-aca5ef5bf641.png)
issue_labels.name: [bug]

issue_title: browser.debugger() fails to pause test
body:
No problem. Using this code:

```
element(by.css('.navbar-organization a')).getText().then(function(text){console.log(text);})
browser.debugger();
expect(element(by.css('.navbar-organization')).element(by.css('.dropdown-menu li')).length).to.equal(2);
```

It does not pause on the `browser.debugger();` line. Coming from Ruby on Rails, the equivalent of this would be `binding.pry`. `binding.pry` *would* pause here. It does not care if you have an exception happening after it.

This code does pause as expected:

```
element(by.css('.navbar-organization a')).getText().then(function(text){console.log(text);})
browser.debugger();
/*expect(element(by.css('.navbar-organization')).element(by.css('.dropdown-menu li')).length).to.equal(2);*/
```

It's an async vs sync thing, I think.
issue_labels.name: [needs: investigation, needs: more info]

OK, I think what you are saying is just that `browser.debugger() != debugger`.

This is commented in http://angular.github.io/protractor/#/debugging, but I'll also update the function description to try to make it super clear that `browser.debugger()` isn't just an alias for `debugger`.

issue_title: Crash on missing file
AfterAll hook doesn't run when 'bail' is set
body:
This appears intentional, but has some unfortunate unintentional consequences, the most obvious of which I'm currently encountering.

I need to run some tests against an instantiated application; when the tests are done, I want to shut down the application gracefully. Before and After hooks make sense for this, right? Wrong! The application will never get cleaned up if there is an error because the after hook doesn't run!

I'm not sure why hooks are treated the same as test suites; the intent of the 'bail' option is just to stop running tests, but cleanup should still happen; that is, 'after' hooks that apply to tests that did run should be executed.

issue_title: browser.debugger() fails to pause test
body:
It was clear to me before I opened this issue that `browser.debugger != debugger`. I didn't understand what those differences were, however. Does the documentation mention the case described above?

The documentation says ```We use browser.debugger(); instead of node's debugger; statement so that the test pauses after the get command has been executed. Using debugger; pauses the test after the get command is scheduled but has not yet been sent to the browser.```, but I don't know what the `get` command is in this context or what the implications might be.

Anyway, I'm clear on why `browser.debugger()` was not pausing now. Thanks for the help.

issue_title: Protractor unable to load urls in ios-driver with wrapDriver
body:
Protractor current release seems unable to open urls in ios-driver with protractor.wrapDriver().get() however regular webdriver..Builder().get() works as expected

### Open chrome browser via regular selenium-standalone-server and loads URL as expected

```javascript
var driver = new webdriver.Builder().
    usingServer('http://localhost:4443/wd/hub').
    withCapabilities(webdriver.Capabilities.chrome()).build();
driver.manage().timeouts().setScriptTimeout(20000);
var ptor = protractor.wrapDriver(driver);
ptor.get('http://www.angularjs.org');
```

### Open Safari browser on iPhone emulator via ios-driver server and loads URL as expected

```javascript
capabilities = webdriver.Capabilities.iphone()
capabilities['language'] = 'en';
capabilities['simulator'] = true;
var driver = new webdriver.Builder().
    usingServer('http://localhost:4444/wd/hub').
    withCapabilities(capabilities).build();
driver.get('http://www.angularjs.org');
```

### Should open Safari browser on iPhone emulator via ios-driver server and load URL 

```javascript
capabilities = webdriver.Capabilities.iphone()
capabilities['language'] = 'en';
capabilities['simulator'] = true;
var driver = new webdriver.Builder().
    usingServer('http://localhost:4444/wd/hub').
    withCapabilities(capabilities).build();
driver.manage().timeouts().setScriptTimeout(20000);
var ptor = protractor.wrapDriver(driver);
ptor.get('http://www.angularjs.org');

    GET /wd/hub/session/6a295263-1c7f-4940-b998-c1d08c9cd6d7 200 1ms - 915b

issue_title: [Jasmine] "grep" option to selectively select it/describe cases to run from spec files
body:
I know that Protractor uses `minijasminenode` (was unsure to post here or there about it), and was wondering if there was a way to selectively run it/describe blocks based on a grep of the descriptor for the blocks. 

Using `iit` or `ddescribe` would not be feasible as we would have to manually go in to around a large amount of test files to exclusively include (or exclude via `xit` or `xdescribe`).

The functionality would be like how `mocha` has a `-g` option.

```
  -g, --grep <pattern>            only run tests matching <pattern>
  -i, --invert                    inverts --grep matches
```

body:
Allow users to filter the specs that they want to run using simple string match.
To use this feature, either:
1) specify jasmineNodeOpts.grep in your conf.js file

2) via commandline like "protractor conf.js --jasmineNodeOpts.grep='string to match'"

issue_title: AfterAll hook doesn't run when 'bail' is set
body:
This appears intentional, but has some unfortunate unintentional consequences, the most obvious of which I'm currently encountering.

I need to run some tests against an instantiated application; when the tests are done, I want to shut down the application gracefully. Before and After hooks make sense for this, right? Wrong! The application will never get cleaned up if there is an error because the after hook doesn't run!

I'm not sure why hooks are treated the same as test suites; the intent of the 'bail' option is just to stop running tests, but cleanup should still happen; that is, 'after' hooks that apply to tests that did run should be executed.
issue_labels.name: [Unconfirmed]

issue_title: Expose currently running suite name, e.g. `protractor.currentSuite`
body:
I was thinking that `protractor.currentSuite` should have only 1 value at a current time, depending of which test is running, if that test/spec file belongs to a suite then set `protractor.currentSuite` to the suite name else `undefined`.
When `--suite` parameter is set to 1 value `protractor.currentSuite` is easy, simple assigns to argv.suite.
When `--suite` is set to multiple values or omitted then it gets trickier because the current value of `protractor.currentSuite` depends on pattern matching the current test file name with the suites listed in the configuration.

Perhaps I'm wishing suites to be a first class citizen, meaning we attach more info to it, for example to do other things like providing a summary of test results at suite level:

```sh
  Summary of run suites:
    ch_camp_enUS - ✔
    ch_packages_enUS - ✔
    ch_paste_enUS - ✔
    ch_smoke_enUS - ✔
    ch_loginvalid_enUS - ✔
    ie10_camp_enUS - skipped
    ie10_packages_enUS - ✔
    ie10_paste_enUS - skipped
    ie10_smoke_enUS - FAILED!
```
issue_labels.name: [type: feature request]

issue_title: Parameter of type "file" causing exception
body:
Parameters of type `file` are causing an exception in the current swagger-ui (6b448c1fae) at line 537 in swagger-client.js. If parameter type is `file` then `getType()` function returns `undefined` and `innerType.toString()` will throw an exception. I had to add to the `if` statement in `getType()` this code `else if (type == "file") { return type; }` in order to get my API doc displayed.

Here is the API definition JSON:
http://pastebin.com/AC8cB8C1
Please note the `swagger` field is an integer because of an other issue with swagger-js (https://github.com/wordnik/swagger-js/issues/142).

issue_title: API: Next and Previous post
body:
Progress update. I've hit 2 issues so far. One in bookshelf and one in knex.
Current API call will generate something along these lines:
`select * from posts where slug = ? and status = 'published'`

to get the next post I wanted to extend the query like this:
`select * from posts where 
(slug = ? and status = 'published') 
or id = (select min(id) from posts where published_at > (select published_at from posts where slug = ?))`

First problem: knex doesn't support subqueries with any operator other than 'in'. There is no way that I'm aware of to generate this in knex: `select min(id) from posts where published_at > (select published_at from posts where slug = ?)`. To workaround this I've used knex.raw queries which are not very optimal. Opened an issue here https://github.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/614

Second problem: bookshelf doesn't allow me to relax constraints on generated query.
`where (slug = ? and status = 'published')` is coming from properties set on the model by `Posts.forge(data)`. Tapping into query builder will only allow me to append constraints (i.e. `(slug = ? and status = 'published') AND ...`), no way to OR them.

There's clearly an easier path to the solution that I don't see yet. But I'm new to all three: knex, bookshelf & ghost, so oh well, the battle goes on.
issue_labels.name: [api, help wanted]

issue_title: Allow --async-only to be satisfied by returning a promise
body:
The --async-only flag is intended to catch programmer error where omitting the done callback from the test function arguments causes it to become a synchronous test instead, that does nothing. However, it complains if the test returns a promise, which is unhelpful/unusable when using promises or a mix of async (callback) functions and promises.

This PR proposes changing the behavior of --async-only so that it only fails if the function does not accept a done callback or return a promise. This makes the flag even more useful since forgetting to return a promise will now report an error when using --async-only.

This results in a slight change to the behavior of --async-only: instead of failing immediately for synchronous functions, check to see if the test function returned a promise (or otherwise failed due to an assert, etc) before complaining about not having a done callback.
repo_description: mocha - simple, flexible, fun javascript test framework for node.js & the browser. (BDD, TDD, QUnit styles via interfaces)

issue_title: Expose currently running suite name, e.g. `protractor.currentSuite`
body:
Can you elaborate on your use case? Do you just need to know from the runner, or do your tests need to know this information?

If you're trying to map each file name and `config.suite` against `config.suites`, there is some complexity in that jasmine runner does not run each file separately, but globbed together. This means protractor cannot determine which file is currently being run. (Of course, we can manually invoke jasmine multiple times to get the files to run separately, but before doing that, if you can explain your use case, it'd be great).
issue_labels.name: [type: feature request]

> main thing to keep in mind is that the changes in #4373
> <https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/pull/4373> are a stopgap and we do
> need to significantly overhaul the underlying editor - so adding new
> features to the current editor needs to be done in a way that doesn't make
> moving the editor forward even harder to do.
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/issues/4669#issuecomment-69025994>.
>

issue_title: Request url generated with incorrect format for query parameters of type 'array'
body:
It seems the url generated by the swagger-ui interface is incorrect for query parameters with type array.

For example, if we have this get request defined :
```
get:
      parameters:
        - name: fields
          in: query
          required: false
          type: array
          items:
            type: string
          enum: [uid, date, title, description]
```

When swagger-ui generates the url to perform this get request, the 'fields' parameter is encoded as a comma separated values string : ?fields=date%2Ctitle%2Cdescription

![screen shot 2015-01-07 at 15 47 25](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5336692/5647245/8c8b3ee4-9684-11e4-9b15-3164d238acf4.png)



This encoding is incorrect, well at least it isn't supported by swagger. 
When the request is sent to the server, swagger sends back a 400 response :

![screen shot 2015-01-07 at 15 41 41](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5336692/5647172/c5fb490e-9683-11e4-97dc-5f23e59c5553.png)


Swagger accepts different formats for array parameters : 
```
fields=date&fields=title&fields=description
```
or
```
fields[]=date%2Ctitle%2Cdescription
```

body:
If you try to signup an invited user on master, you get a bunch of validation errors as if you didn't fill out the form:

![](http://puu.sh/ec3X1.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Log in to Ghost and invite a new user
2. Log out of Ghost
3. Click the link in the new user invite email
4. Fill out the form and hit Create Account

### Technical details: 

* Ghost Version: master , introduced since 0.5.7
issue_labels.name: [blocker, bug]

issue_title: Request url generated with incorrect format for query parameters of type 'array'
body:
It actually works as designed. The only real problem is that it display the request URL as a URL encoded one, but if you look at the call itself (using your browser's console, for example), it does send it as comma-separated request as expected.

This is the *default* behavior of arrays. If you want to change it, you need to add a property called `collectionFormat`. For `fields=date&fields=title&fields=description` you need to use `multi` as the value of that field.

For second example of `fields[]=date%2Ctitle%2Cdescription` is indeed comma-separated, only the name of the parameter is `fields[]` and not `fields`.

I'm not entirely sure what you mean by statements like 'supported by swagger' and 'Swagger accepts different formats...'. Swagger is a specification, not a tool. If you're referring to a specific tool, please let us know which one you're referring to.

issue_title: [feature request] Attach protractor to existing webdriver session
body:
It would be useful to be able to have protractor use an existing selenium browser session rather than always create a new one.

Note that I'm *not* asking to be able to attach to an already running local browser, for example that the console user has started up themselves (e.g. [Issue 18](https://code.google.com/p/selenium/issues/detail?id=18) ).

Rather, what I mean is, if I have started up a selenium browser session using, for example, a different testing framework or language bindings (e.g. python selenium ), run some tests in there, and exported the session ID into the environment or in some other way made it available, it would be nice to be able to configure protractor in the normal way (e.g. using an option in the protractor configuration file) to access this session.  Something like the below pseudo-code snippet.  It seems like this should be possible and relatively straightforward using the capabilities described here [attachToSession](http://angular.github.io/protractor/#/api?view=webdriver.WebDriver.attachToSession).

In my particular use case, I'm doing some testing in Python involving creating a new user, resetting the password, logging in, &c; which in my application do not involve Angular JS.  At the end of these tests, I have a browser session on the app with a newly created, logged-in user with a randomized credentials. I'd like to proceed to test the Angular app with Protractor using the existing browser session, I can get the sessionId from the Python binding, and I can quit the python testing process without closing the browser.

I know that I could re-write all these tests to use protractor but that would be a huge pain, because I'm making use of a bunch of convenient python libraries to check email accounts for password reset emails.

I also know that i could just go ahead and close the browser, and then re-open a new session with protractor, but I pay by the minute for my remote browser service and would rather not burn the two minutes to wind-down and wind-up a new session.

```javascript
exports.config = {
    ...
    'capabilities': {
        ...
        'sessionId':'uuid-of-an-existing-selenium-session',
        // or even better . . . 
        'sessionId':process.env.SELENIUM_SESSION_ID,
        ...
    },
    ...
}
```

I searched the issues and the google groups and couldn't find this.

issue_title: Request url generated with incorrect format for query parameters of type 'array'
body:
you're right, maybe the problem isn't with the specification itself but with the implementation.
I'm using nodejs/hapi/swaggerize-hapi and it doesn't accept the generic comma separated values format. I have a 400 response saying that the 'fields' parameter must be an array.

it only accepts fields[]=date%2Ctitle%2Cdescription and fields=date&fields=title&fields=description

issue_title: Parameter of type "file" causing exception
body:
Parameters of type `file` are causing an exception in the current swagger-ui (6b448c1fae) at line 537 in swagger-client.js. If parameter type is `file` then `getType()` function returns `undefined` and `innerType.toString()` will throw an exception. I had to add to the `if` statement in `getType()` this code `else if (type == "file") { return type; }` in order to get my API doc displayed.

Here is the API definition JSON:
http://pastebin.com/AC8cB8C1
Please note the `swagger` field is an integer because of an other issue with swagger-js (https://github.com/wordnik/swagger-js/issues/142).

issue_title: Fixed contact and terms of service references in main.handlebars
body:
My model is passing a contact object and terms of service object conforming to the [2.0 spec](https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-spec/blob/master/versions/2.0.md#infoObject) and looks similar to:

```xml
<info>
  <contact>
    <email>info@mydomain.com</email>
    <name>Product Development Team</name>
    <url>http://www.mydomain.com</url>
  </contact>
  <termsOfService>http://mydomain.com/terms.html</termsOfService>
</info>
```

However, in the swagger-ui, the 'Contact the Developer' link is "mailto:Product Development Team" and the terms of service link is not displayed. I found that the reference in main.handlebars was referencing the incorrect field names.

I based the pull request branch off of develop. If you would rather it be based off of master, please let me know. Also, I did not rebuild dist as part of this pull request. Again, please let me know if you want me to include that as well.
