issue_title: Is underscored: true option supported?
body:
I'm trying to generate model User with it's migration. My config looks like this:

    {
        "development": {
            "host"     : "...",
            "database" : "...",
            "define"   : {
                "underscored": true
            },
            "dialect"  : "postgres",
            "port"     : "5432",
            ...
        },
        ...
    }

From project root I launch:

`node_modules/sequelize-cli/bin/sequelize model:generate --name User --attributes email:string,name:string,hash:string,salt:string`

After this I get `coffee/models/user.coffee`:

    "use strict"
    module.exports = (sequelize, DataTypes) ->
      User = sequelize.define("User",
        email: DataTypes.STRING
        name: DataTypes.STRING
        hash: DataTypes.STRING
        salt: DataTypes.STRING
      ,
        classMethods:
          associate: (models) ->
      )
  
      # associations can be defined here
      User
      
And `coffee/migrations/20150107142601-create-user.coffee`:

    "use strict"
    module.exports =
      up: (migration, DataTypes, done) ->
        migration.createTable("Users",
          id:
            allowNull: false
            autoIncrement: true
            primaryKey: true
            type: DataTypes.INTEGER

          email:
            type: DataTypes.STRING

          name:
            type: DataTypes.STRING

          hash:
            type: DataTypes.STRING

          salt:
            type: DataTypes.STRING

          createdAt:
            allowNull: false
            type: DataTypes.DATE

          updatedAt:
            allowNull: false
            type: DataTypes.DATE
        ).done done
        return

      down: (migration, DataTypes, done) ->
        migration.dropTable("users").done done
        return
        
Is it supposed migration file to create fields `createdAt` and `updatedAt` despite `underscored` option set to `true`? It seems migration file should contain smth like:

    created_at:
      allowNull: false
      type: DataTypes.DATE

    updated_at:
      allowNull: false
      type: DataTypes.DATE
      
and model one:

    ...
    hash: DataTypes.STRING
    salt: DataTypes.STRING
    createdAt:
      field: "created_at"
    updatedAt:
      field: "updated_at"
  
Is `underscored` option not yet supported in cli or I'm just doing something wrong?

Thank you.

issue_title: [TASK] Update jshintrc
body:
@wltsmrz Thanks for polishing up the jshintrc file. There are just two edits that I'd like to add: removing the `boss` and `W004` relaxing options. I also moved `laxbreak` to the end, that is one relaxing option that may have some readability benefits. And I removed `camelcase` since it has no effect.

I can't think of any cases where `boss` (assignments where comparisons are expected) or `W004` (redefining parameters) should be allowed, but if there is a rare case where someone really wants to use it, they can disable the jshint warning with the `// jshint ignore:line` comment directive. But I'd imagine that 99% of the time when these warnings fire it will be catching bugs for us.

issue_title: Feature to execute failed tests only
body:
Can you clarify which of the following use cases is the one you want?

1) Automatically rerun failed tests as part of the initial protractor run to deflake. i.e.
> protractor config.js
running...A,B,D passed, C,E failed
running C,E again...C passed, E failed
running E again...E passed

2) Manually rerun failed tests after edits. i.e.
> protractor config.js
running...A,B,D passed, C,E failed
> vim test.js // try to fix C and E
> protractor config.js --run-last-failed
running only C,E...C passed, E failed
> vim test.js // try to fix E
> protractor config.js --run-last-failed
running only E...E passed
issue_labels.name: [type: feature request]

issue_title: Added DeepZoom support
body:
Hi Victor, thanks for adding this useful new feature.

`npm test` is currently failing at the jshint check. Please can you fix this and add tests to test/unit/io.js to cover your new options and code.

Please can you rename the slightly generic sounding `overlap` method to be the more-specific `tileOverlap`, which would also then match `tileSize`.

The pre-compiled libvips-dev packages for the latest stable Debian/Ubuntu releases don't include the libgsf-1-dev dependency so it's probably best to wrap the use of the `vips_dzsave` method in resize.cc with `#ifdef HAVE_GSF` (if that's available) or similar.

Are you able to update the preinstall.sh script with the new dependencies on libgsf-1-dev for Debian-based and libgsf-devel for RHEL-based Linux?

Once you're happy with the above, please can you change the destination of your PR to the `intake` branch (a limitation of Github means you may have to close and open a new PR to do this) as that's where the new features for the next major release v0.9.0 are assembling themselves. Sorry for not making the branching tactics clear - I need to improve making contribution as easy as possible.

Finally, and most importantly, please can you add yourself to the list of contributors in package,json as you deserve it.

Cheers,
Lovell

issue_title: Is underscored: true option supported?
body:
I'm trying to generate model User with it's migration. My config looks like this:

    {
        "development": {
            "host"     : "...",
            "database" : "...",
            "define"   : {
                "underscored": true
            },
            "dialect"  : "postgres",
            "port"     : "5432",
            ...
        },
        ...
    }

From project root I launch:

`node_modules/sequelize-cli/bin/sequelize model:generate --name User --attributes email:string,name:string,hash:string,salt:string`

After this I get `coffee/models/user.coffee`:

    "use strict"
    module.exports = (sequelize, DataTypes) ->
      User = sequelize.define("User",
        email: DataTypes.STRING
        name: DataTypes.STRING
        hash: DataTypes.STRING
        salt: DataTypes.STRING
      ,
        classMethods:
          associate: (models) ->
      )
  
      # associations can be defined here
      User
      
And `coffee/migrations/20150107142601-create-user.coffee`:

    "use strict"
    module.exports =
      up: (migration, DataTypes, done) ->
        migration.createTable("Users",
          id:
            allowNull: false
            autoIncrement: true
            primaryKey: true
            type: DataTypes.INTEGER

          email:
            type: DataTypes.STRING

          name:
            type: DataTypes.STRING

          hash:
            type: DataTypes.STRING

          salt:
            type: DataTypes.STRING

          createdAt:
            allowNull: false
            type: DataTypes.DATE

          updatedAt:
            allowNull: false
            type: DataTypes.DATE
        ).done done
        return

      down: (migration, DataTypes, done) ->
        migration.dropTable("users").done done
        return
        
Is it supposed migration file to create fields `createdAt` and `updatedAt` despite `underscored` option set to `true`? It seems migration file should contain smth like:

    created_at:
      allowNull: false
      type: DataTypes.DATE

    updated_at:
      allowNull: false
      type: DataTypes.DATE
      
and model one:

    ...
    hash: DataTypes.STRING
    salt: DataTypes.STRING
    createdAt:
      field: "created_at"
    updatedAt:
      field: "updated_at"
  
Is `underscored` option not yet supported in cli or I'm just doing something wrong?

Thank you.

issue_title: PATCH requests being issued as patch (lowercase), invalid against HTTP/1.1
body:
Okay, I think the problem is that I tested with 1.2, and it may be specific for 2.0.

Upon making changes to the 2.0 petstore and add the patch call that exists in 1.2, I get an error on the OPTIONS call, and it looks like there's indeed a problem.

The relevant request header sent by the OPTIONS request is:

``
Access-Control-Request-Method:patch
``

and it should definitely be PATCH.

The server replies with:

``
Access-Control-Allow-Methods:GET, POST, DELETE, PUT, PATCH, OPTIONS
``

issue_title: Cannot use Arrow keys to select option in a drop down
body:
Hi @philipbeadle 

You can use one of the two ways to select an option:

```javascript
    var options = element(by.id('frequencySalary'));
    options.sendKeys('Monthly')
```

or

```javascript
    var optionsElements = element(by.id('frequencySalary')).all(by.tagName('option'));
    optionsElements.count().then(function(count) {console.log('I have ' + count + ' options')});
    optionsElements.get(1).click(); // click on 2nd option
```

>I am trying to automate the page with just keys to prove the page is accessible and also to test that it works for power users who prefer keyboard to mouse so click etc will not suffice.
It's a bad idea to test the chore browser's behavior as it's not your logic, i.e. you should not need to test that arrow keys work with options since that's something your browser implements.

issue_title: WebDriver control flow can sometimes get locked
body:
Here is my best explanation of why the above code requires the `webdriver.promise.delayed()` to lock.

When the then/success callback of the promise is executed in the control flow, it is run with the `opt_active` parameter `false`, which means that the current active frame will not be switched to the child. It ends up with a pending task for execute1 and a child task for execute2 - thus the lock.

On the other hand, if the code is just:

```js
var webdriver = require('selenium-webdriver');
var util = require('util');
var flow = webdriver.promise.controlFlow();

flow.execute(function() {
  console.log('A');
  return flow.execute(function() {
    console.log('C'); // called successfully
  }, 'execute2');
}, 'execute1');
```
then the execute2 task is scheduled in a child frame and the active frame gets switched to that frame - it finishes, the parent frame finishes, everything is happy.

Here are the annotated logs showing this difference (I used custom logging added to the webdriver node module):

Situation A: lock
```
{ history: [],
  activeFrame: '[execute1]',
  activeRoot: '[execute1]' }
--- loop turn ---
{ history: [],
  activeFrame: '[execute1]',
  activeRoot: '[execute1]' }
--- run in new frame from run event loop ---
execute1
--- start run in new frame ---
{ history: [],
  activeFrame: '[(pending - execute1)]',
  activeRoot: '[(pending - execute1)]' }
A
--- run in new frame from notify ---
--- start run in new frame ---
{ history: [],
  activeFrame: '[(pending - execute1)]',
  activeRoot: '[(pending - execute1)]' }
B
--- after run in new frame ---
{ history: [],
  activeFrame: '[(pending - execute1)[execute2]]',
  activeRoot: '[(pending - execute1)[execute2]]' }
and then that repeats forever
```

Situation B: no lock
```
{ history: [],
  activeFrame: '[execute1]',
  activeRoot: '[execute1]' }
--- loop turn ---
{ history: [],
  activeFrame: '[execute1]',
  activeRoot: '[execute1]' }
--- run in new frame from run event loop ---
execute1
--- start run in new frame ---
{ history: [],
  activeFrame: '[(pending - execute1)]',
  activeRoot: '[(pending - execute1)]' }
A
--- after run in new frame ---
{ history: [],
  activeFrame: '[execute2]',
  activeRoot: '[(pending - execute1)[execute2]]' }
--- loop turn ---
{ history: [],
  activeFrame: '[execute2]',
  activeRoot: '[(pending - execute1)[execute2]]' }
--- run in new frame from run event loop ---
execute2
--- start run in new frame ---
{ history: [],
  activeFrame: '[(pending - execute2)]',
  activeRoot: '[(pending - execute1)[(pending - execute2)]]' }
C
--- Marking task execute2 complete
--- loop turn ---
{ history: [ 'execute2' ],
  activeFrame: '[]',
  activeRoot: '[(pending - execute1)[]]' }
--- run in new frame from notify ---
--- start run in new frame ---
{ history: [],
  activeFrame: '[(pending - execute1)]',
  activeRoot: '[(pending - execute1)]' }
--- Marking task execute1 complete
--- loop turn ---
{ history: [ 'execute1' ], activeFrame: '[]', activeRoot: '[]' }
```
issue_labels.name: [needs: investigation]

issue_title: HTML reporter retains old 'grep=' querystrings when changing suites
body:
Currently, if you use the `http://localhost/tests.html?grep=MySuite` format for limiting Mocha tests in the browser, all the suite/test links in the report get additional `grep=` params. Clicking on them retains older (ignored) values in the URL:

`http://localhost/tests.html?grep=MySuite&grep=MySuite%20%23someMethod`

Switching back to the higher suite will tack on yet another param:

`http://localhost/tests.html?grep=MySuite&grep=MySuite%20%23someMethod&grep=MySuite`

Ideally, switching to a new `grep` setting should clear the existing one in the URL. I'll submit a PR which implements this desired behavior.

issue_title: Versioning while mulitple people edit simultaneously
body:
I've looked through the road map to try and find something on this, but not seeing it. I'm wondering if there are any plans to improve simultaneous editing in Ghost. We have a blog setup with 6 users, but any time more than one are in a post, each save overwrites the other's work. It would be great (knowing getting to the point of Google docs is a huge undertaking) to at least know when someone else is viewing the draft, and or if they have made changes. Are there plans for something here that I'm just not seeing? 

Thanks!

issue_title: Running a test with multiple browsers causes "Error: Server has not been started."
body:
When running my tests, I have noticed that I am getting peculiar "Server has not been started" errors when testing with multiple browsers. I am using Windows 7 64bit with Node version `v0.10.26`.

I've narrowed this down to a  minimal test case. The config file is:
```javascript
exports.config = {

    seleniumPort: null,
    seleniumArgs: [],

    specs: [
        '../spec-e2e/**/*.spec.js'
    ],

    chromeOnly: false,

    multiCapabilities: [
        {
            'browserName': 'chrome'
        },
        {
            'browserName': 'firefox'
        },
        {
            'browserName': 'internet explorer'
        }
    ],

    suites: {
        testsuite: '../spec-e2e/roles.spec.js'
    },

    baseUrl: 'http://google.ca',
    allScriptsTimeout: 10000,

    jasmineNodeOpts: {
        onComplete: null,
        isVerbose: false,
        showColors: true,
        includeStackTrace: true
    }
};
```
The only spec (the roles spec specified above) is simply:
```javascript
describe('Settings-Administration-Roles', function() {
    it('is dependent on the Users page for user/membership addition', function() {
        expect(1).toBeGreaterThan(0);
    });
});
```
Now, this _doesn't_ happen every time that Protractor is run: only about every 3-10 times or so. Thus, I built a script for reproducing this:
```batch
@echo off
set /a index=0
setlocal ENABLEDELAYEDEXPANSION
:start
	set /a index=index+1
	call node_modules\.bin\protractor config\spec-e2e.js --suite testsuite >> StrangeErrorTest%index%.txt
goto start
```

I've looked through the road map to try and find something on this, but not seeing it. I'm wondering if there are any plans to improve simultaneous editing in Ghost. We have a blog setup with 6 users, but any time more than one are in a post, each save overwrites the other's work. It would be great (knowing getting to the point of Google docs is a huge undertaking) to at least know when someone else is viewing the draft, and or if they have made changes. Are there plans for something here that I'm just not seeing? 

Thanks!

issue_title: Gravatar profile images breaks when Gravatar image rating is greater than "G"
body:
I recently changed my Gravatar to a picture of me holding a beer, and rated it as "PG". After doing so, my profile picture in my Ghost blog began to appear as a broken image. 

![screen shot 2015-01-07 at 11 07 22 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3655670/5657748/fd824c40-96c1-11e4-9e94-f18b4d24400a.png)

**Issue**
If a user is using their Gravatar for a profile image and they switch the image to one with a rating greater than "G", their profile image in Ghost will now be a broken image.

**Steps to reproduce**
* Create a new user account using an email address that has a Gravatar associated with it (rating of "G")
* Visit http://www.gravatar.com and change your Gravatar rating to "PG"
* Visit your Ghost blog and look anywhere the profile picture should appear (login as the user, etc)

**Separate note**
If you attempt to create a user account and your Gravatar is already rated above "G", no profile picture is set (because the current implementation returns a 404 for anything above "G").

**Suggestions on a fix?**
I've found where the issue occurs, but need some guidance as to how to proceed with a fix.

I could make a simple change to increase the acceptable rating for Gravatars (to which level would be up for discussion), or just fix the broken images when a user happens to switch to a Gravatar that is not rated "G".

issue_title: [Feature Request] Should be possible to init Ghost with a config object
body:
I would have to second this PR. The very first thing I tried to do was require ghost and pass it configuration options collected from the rest of my app. 

It wouldn't be much of an mess to take options at start up. The problem looks to stem from [here](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/blob/master/core/server/config/index.js#L404). The config handler exports a singleton and it will only read from a hard coded path for testing. 

This could be made pretty flexible with out a lot of code with something like [nconf](https://www.npmjs.com/package/nconf) or [confit](https://www.npmjs.com/package/confit). 

This would make multi-tier config pretty straight forward and make ghost as a module really simple to set up and run.

This is how we [use nconf in our production apps](https://gist.github.com/esatterwhite/14e4361d0d49865ce3d2) 

minus all of the documentation in there, this is less than 100 lines of code.

This conf module checks for:
1. System level overrides
2. Command line arguments
3. Environment variables
4. A configuration file(s)
5. System specified defaults

This could easily be extended to key off of NODE_ENV and read config.<ENV>.json, etc if that is your cup of tea. And this would really be a matter of changing `config.foo` to `+config.get('foo')`

Doing something like this would free developers to set up, deploy and configure ghost how ever they wanted. It would also mean that I don't have to keep massive config files with sensitive authentication information in source control.

issue_title: Mocha.run throws a TypeError if callback is not provided
body:
To reproduce the issue, install Mocha 2.1.0 and run this script on Node console.
```javascript
var Mocha = require("mocha");
var mocha = new Mocha();
mocha.addFile("./test.js");
mocha.run();
```

Here is `test.js`
```javascript
it("nothing", function() {});
```

Then, I get:
```
Donghwan@DONGHWAN ~/Documents/GitHub/vibe-javascript-client (master)
$ node test-runner


  √ nothing

  1 passing (7ms)


c:\Users\Donghwan\Documents\GitHub\vibe-javascript-client\node_modules\mocha\lib\mocha.js:414
          fn(failures);
          ^
TypeError: undefined is not a function
    at done (c:\Users\Donghwan\Documents\GitHub\vibe-javascript-client\node_modules\mocha\lib\mocha.js:414:11)
    at Runner.<anonymous> (c:\Users\Donghwan\Documents\GitHub\vibe-javascript-client\node_modules\mocha\lib\runner.js:590:5)
    at Runner.emit (events.js:117:20)
    at c:\Users\Donghwan\Documents\GitHub\vibe-javascript-client\node_modules\mocha\lib\runner.js:597:10
    at c:\Users\Donghwan\Documents\GitHub\vibe-javascript-client\node_modules\mocha\lib\runner.js:518:7
    at next (c:\Users\Donghwan\Documents\GitHub\vibe-javascript-client\node_modules\mocha\lib\runner.js:248:23)
    at Object._onImmediate (c:\Users\Donghwan\Documents\GitHub\vibe-javascript-client\node_modules\mocha\lib\runner.js:276:5)
    at processImmediate [as _immediateCallback] (timers.js:345:15)
```

2.0.1 works fine. As the [wiki page](https://github.com/mochajs/mocha/wiki/Using-mocha-programmatically) shows use of `mocha.run()`, I think it's a regression in 2.1.0. A workaround is [to pass an empty callback](https://github.com/vibe-project/vibe-javascript-client/commit/058f9d5020306cf2800e9f2862b4a773637483c5).

It looks like that https://github.com/mochajs/mocha/commit/30582e646d579ce67ef4229922651da498e79a80 is the cause. Before executing `fn(failures);`, it should check if `fn` is available.

That's no good though. I want to use the arrow keys to prove the page is accessible. 

Sent from my iPhone

> On 8 Jan 2015, at 9:13 am, Hank Duan <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> Hi @philipbeadle
> 
> You can use one of the two ways to select an option:
> 
>     var options = element(by.id('frequencySalary'));
>     options.sendKeys('Monthly')
> or
> 
>     var optionsElements = element(by.id('frequencySalary')).all(by.tagName('option'));
>     optionsElements.count().then(function(count) {console.log('I have ' + count + ' options')});
>     optionsElements.get(1).click(); // click on 2nd option
> I am trying to automate the page with just keys to prove the page is accessible and also to test that it works for power users who prefer keyboard to mouse so click etc will not suffice.
> It's a bad idea to test the chore browser's behavior as it's not your logic, i.e. you should not need to test that arrow keys work with options since that's something your browser implements.
>

issue_title: Gravatar profile image breaks when Gravatar image rating is greater than "G"
body:
Hi @Trendy thanks for the incredibly detailed report! This issue is a work of art :+1: 

Firstly, I think that Ghost showing a broken image is a bug that ought to be fixed - I am sure there are other reasons why we might get into this state other than the rating (internet problems, gravatar service problems etc) but whilst we have a pretty straightforward reproduction case, it would be great to fix it so that it always falls back to the default if at all possible.

Secondly, I don't think Ghost needs to have any opinion what-so-ever on someone's profile picture. Therefore I think we can also increase the acceptable rating so that it doesn't matter what rating the picture is. If you do signup not realising Ghost will pull your gravatar and want to remove it, that's easy to do.

issue_title: Operation parameter is $ref
body:
I'm not sure why this is tagged as a feature and not as a bug. The spec says for a [Operation Object](https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-spec/blob/master/versions/2.0.md#operationObject)

parameters : 
[Parameter Object | **Reference Object**]

**The list can use the Reference Object to link to parameters that are defined at the Swagger Object's parameters.**

See also the related closed issues, swagger-api/swagger-editor#182
and apigee-127/swagger-tools#79 which claimed to fix $ref for parameters long ago.

issue_title: Gravatar profile image breaks when Gravatar image rating is greater than "G"
body:
@ErisDS Haha, thanks, I like to file good bug reports when I come across something!

I'll tackle this in two parts. Tonight I can get all ratings of Gravatar's working/committed and then I'll investigate a way to fallback to the default when a 404 error occurs.

issue_title: Gravatar profile image breaks when Gravatar image rating is greater than "G"
body:
Hi @Trendy,

The way I understand it, dealing with the broken/404 image result is really easy to handle.  There's a `d` (for default) query parameter that takes a few options.  Right now we have it set to return `404` if the Gravatar isn't available.  If it's set to `mm` it will return the "silhouette" image--that's probably what we should be going with.

http://en.gravatar.com/site/implement/images/

issue_title: Simplify installation of swagger-ui in java webapps
body:
there are also existing jvm-packages: one is found in webjars (https://github.com/webjars/swagger-ui) & ring-swagger-ui (https://github.com/metosin/ring-swagger-ui). the later one is packaged by us and can be used from Java-based apps just by depending on it: swagger-ui files can be found from classpath resources under `/swagger-ui`. One can override single files just by placing your own under the same name, works at least so with Leiningen, should work the same way with Maven etc.

Would love to see a [configurable](https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-ui/issues/804) jvm-packaged version from the main project.

The problem is that the original issue was also not very clearly described, as "not working" can mean any number of things, and there is no logging output or link to a demo of the issue. I had already seen your blog post and code snippet, but the best way to troubleshoot and get your questions answered is to provide a link to a page that actually runs the code that demonstrates the issue in action, e.g. jsFiddle, jsbin, etc. Feel free to paste your code snippet into one of those sites and check that is still exhibits the same broken behavior in Firefox. (Please also use the `logging: true` option.) Thanks again!

issue_title: Classes + .d.ts
body:
new thing: we have [rpl-www](https://github.com/tmcw/rpl-www) installed for self-running and live-codable documentation. trick is to

* don't use require() - this isn't node, so it won't be available
* `turf` is available as a library by default
* use `//=` comments to expose things

so for example:

```js
var points = turf.featurecollection([
  turf.point(10.1953125, 43.75522505306928),
  turf.point(10.404052734375, 43.84245116699039),
  turf.point(10.579833984375, 43.6599240747891),
  turf.point(10.360107421875, 43.51668853502909),
  turf.point(10.140380859375, 43.58834891179792),
  turf.point(10.1953125, 43.75522505306928)]);

var result = turf.featurecollection(
  points.features.concat([turf.convex(points)]));
//=result
```

The line `//=result` is like saying 'make a map with what's in the variable `result` right now'.

* I've been using `turf.featurecollection` a bunch to show before & after on the same map, but you can also do multiple maps by using `//=` comments twice or more
* esprima seems to prefer semicolons. I'll look for the upstream cause but for now, non-asi style javascript is safest

issue_title: Why does a buffered point result in a oval?
body:
thanks @rowanwins! Buffers are circles... but geojson only really represents polygons as lists of edges. This means that a "perfect" circle is not actually possible. This is a problem related to the [coastline paradox](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coastline_paradox). In a nutshell, a circle has an infinite number of vertices if defined as a polygon, so you have to decide on a resolution for your vertices. This is currently fixed in turf-buffer, and it is unaffected by the size of the buffer. 

Also note that Leaflet does some automatic simplification of its own, so the display may be more jagged when zoomed out, even if the data you are using for calculations is more precise.

There is a branch of turf-buffer I will be pushing out in a couple days that will give you perfectly circular point buffers, as well as an optional curve resolution. This means you can specify whatever detail you would like (memory and performance *will* be affected, but you can tinker with it).

I set up [a little example](https://github.com/bebraw/swagger-todo) that shows how to build a minimal Todo backend using Express, jwt and co. The problem is that `swagger-ui` relies on api key. I noticed it's possible to customize this a little bit (ie. push api key to header) but that doesn't solve the problem entirely.

I would need some way to log in to the system first. I will be able to get the token required by authentication through that.

An extra challenge is how to make this all work nicely with [swagger-tools](https://github.com/apigee-127/swagger-tools) but that's a separate problem. If there was a nice extension point for something like this, it would probably be easier to handle that side. I would just need something that can be plugged into an Express middleware and served as a static site through it.

issue_title: html2canvas is not working in firfox
body:
There's plenty of test cases that work fine with Firefox without a timeout:
 - https://github.com/niklasvh/html2canvas/tree/master/tests/mocha
 - https://github.com/niklasvh/html2canvas/tree/master/tests/cases

So unless you can actually show a case where it wouldn't work without a timeout, there isn't much we can or will do about it. If you run html2canvas on a container before it is present or has content, or the styles for it have been assigned, then obviously it won't work either, but the solution for that would be to wrap it in a window load, content load or domready event.

issue_title: Markdown Tables
body:
The compiler doesn't support generating tables with markdown syntax, but HTML. And HTML makes our articles hard to maintain.

It needs a bigger update, as all themes should have their own table syntax (eg. bootstrap classes) or must fit some CSS to our syntax, but it worth it. It's a commonly used feature.

# Example

    | Name            | Phone       |
    |-----------------|-------------|
    | Peter Russo     | +0123456789 |
    | Frank Underwood | +0123987654 |

| Name            | Phone       |
|-----------------|-------------|
| Peter Russo     | +0123456789 |
| Frank Underwood | +0123987654 |

# Related Links

- [Tables in GitHub Flavored Markdown](https://help.github.com/articles/github-flavored-markdown/#tables)
- [Generate Markdown Tables](http://www.tablesgenerator.com/markdown_tables)

issue_title: Bug: Imports from a Ghost installation: Imported 'Owner' account login not functioning, gives incorrect error message.
body:
### Issue Summary
When importing data from a Ghost installation (Blog Old) to a different install of Ghost (Blog New) and then logging out of the Blog New admin account on Blog New a user attempting to log back in to Blog New with the (different) account details for the imported "Owner" account from Blog Old is given an error message saying that the account is "Locked due to too many login attempts.", urging them to use the Forgotten Password link, even though this account has never attempted a log in before on this new installation of Ghost.

### Steps to Reproduce

Export Ghost settings and data from one Ghost install, import into a different installation.

Log out of Ghost on the installation which the data was imported into.

Attempt log in with account credentials contained in imported data and settings, see incorrect error message.

### Expected behavior 

User is given correct error message explaining why they are unable to log in. Or, user is able to log in to imported accounts without any issues when importing from another Ghost installation. 

### Technical details

* Ghost Version: Release 0.5.7
* Node Version: 0.10.25

issue_title: Bug: Imports from a Ghost installation: Imported 'Owner' account login not permitted, gives incorrect error message.
body:
@lemur3 Thanks for the bug report. When an import is performed, any imported user account is locked. Although the message isn't quite accurate with regard to there being 'too many login attempts', it is correct in so much as the user needs to use the reset password flow to gain access.

However, it sounds like the main bug here is something slightly different. Can you please clarify the following details:
- Are you logging out of, and then logging back into the same account?
- Was there only one account on Blog New when you performed the import?
- Does Blog Old contain a user with the same email address as the owner on Blog New? If so, is the user on Blog Old also the Owner?

issue_title: Facebook callback goes to wrong server in a multi-server AWS stack
body:
We have an AWS EC2 stack of several webservers running node.js/passport.  These servers are behind a NAT, and there's an Elastic Load Balancer which directs traffic in round-robin fashion to distribute load among the servers.

When there's a Facebook authentication, the callback response may go to the same server that issued the request, but sometimes it goes to the wrong server (because browsing traffic can be directed to any webserver in the stack).  So if we reduce the number of webservers to 1, everything works great.  If we increase the number of webservers and increase traffic, the client hangs waiting for the callback.

I'm looking for a best-practice way of addressing this use case.

issue_title: Gravatar profile image breaks when Gravatar image rating is greater than "G"
body:
I recently changed my Gravatar to a picture of me holding a beer, and rated it as "PG". After doing so, my profile picture in my Ghost blog began to appear as a broken image. 

![screen shot 2015-01-07 at 11 07 22 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3655670/5657748/fd824c40-96c1-11e4-9e94-f18b4d24400a.png)

**Issue**
If a user is using their Gravatar for a profile image and they switch the image to one with a rating greater than "G", their profile image in Ghost will now be a broken image.

**Steps to reproduce**
* Create a new user account using an email address that has a Gravatar associated with it (rating of "G")
* Visit http://www.gravatar.com and change your Gravatar rating to "PG"
* Visit your Ghost blog and look anywhere the profile picture should appear (login as the user, etc)

**Separate note**
If you attempt to create a user account and your Gravatar is already rated above "G", no profile picture is set (because the current implementation returns a 404 for anything above "G").

**Suggestions on a fix?**
I've found where the issue occurs, but need some guidance as to how to proceed with a fix.

I could make a simple change to increase the acceptable rating for Gravatars (to which level would be up for discussion), or just fix the broken images when a user happens to switch to a Gravatar that is not rated "G".

- Allows highest rating for Gravatars (x), since Ghost should have no opinion on image ratings.

This is a much broader discussion (and one probably too late to have), but have we thought about standardizing latitude/longitude order, at least with respect to how Turf plays with Mapbox.js? I have this in my code (both pairs point to the same geographic point, but are reverse of each other), and always keep second-guessing myself whether I have the order right.

![screen shot 2015-01-09 at 10 32 47 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4551508/5685020/54bf61c6-97eb-11e4-9147-1e910564b3a8.png)

issue_title: Latlng vs LngLat
body:
turf uses GeoJSON and GeoJSON does lon, lat, so turf does too. Shapefiles, GPX, KML, GeoJSON, Shapely, all also do lon, lat.

We can add a note about this to turf docs (basically "this is geojson").

issue_title: Latlng vs LngLat
body:
Leaflet's, since it wraps Leaflet. Leaflet followed the precedent of Google Maps.

The split is more or less "GIS, data formats, developer tools = lon, lat" and "end-user-ish-things = lat, lon". Turf falls into the former bin.

issue_title: Support importing markdown files
body:
This is part of the epic #4605

----

We now have zip support in the uploader, meaning that it is possible to import from a set of files, rather than a single file. This issue describes the basic markdown file support that should be built into the importer in order to handle Roon imports. There are likely more features that could/should be added (like handling frontmatter), and it is also likely that the importer will get restructured to be an app or series of apps in future.

When importing markdown files the following rules apply:

- If a single markdown file is imported, this should become a post
- If multiple markdown files are imported via a zip, each one should become a zip.

The content of the markdown file is handled as follows:

- If it has a level one heading marked up with `# My Heading`, this should be treated as the post's title (i.e. `post.title`) and removed from the content
- If it has an image with no alt before a level one heading, this should be treated as a featured image (i.e. `post.image`) and removed from the content
- The remaining content of the markdown file should become the content for the post (i.e. `post.markdown`)

The filename is handled as follows:

- If it contains a status (published or draft) then this status should be used for the post and the status should be removed from the filename \*
- If it contains a date or date and time, then this should be used as the created_at date for drafts, or the published_at date for published posts and removed from the filename
- The remaining filename should be used as the slug
- If there is no title in the markdown, the slug should be used as the title as-is 

\* Note: Roon exports include deleted images, these should be explicitly ignored.
issue_labels.name: [importer]

issue_title: Add markdown file handler to importer
body:
This is a WIP because it is done on top of #4690 and also because it assumes a slightly modified Roon export format that has not yet been shipped. 

closes #4691

- adds a file handler for markdown file (.md and .markdown)
- handles titles and featured images
- gets status, date, and slug from the filename
- has a test suite

issue_title: parsing background images on windows fails
body:
function parseBackgrounds(backgroundImage) fails to parse the block and definition if the file url contains ( or ). 

Given the following url string
url('file:///c:/Program Files(x86)/myApplication/images/ico_graph_off.png')

parseBackgrounds yeilds

block = url('file:///c:/Program Files(x86)/myApplication/images/ico_graph_off.png')
definition ='file:///c:/Program Files(x86)/myApplication/images/ico_graph_off.png'

This fails to load the image because the single quotes have not been removed.

Given the following url string
url(file:///c:/Temp(x86/myApplication/images/ico_graph_off.png)

parseBackgrounds yeilds

block = url(file:///c:/Temp(x86/myApplication/images/ico_graph_off.png)
definition = file:///c:/Temp(x86/myApplication/images/ico_graph_off.png) 

This fails to load the image because of the closing parenthese isn't removed.

issue_title: `{{has}}` helper doesn't check for exact tag matches
body:
The has helper `tags=""` lookup is using a regex and only doing a partial match of the tag.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a post with the tag 'Produce' (or any other tag which can be a substring of another tag) and publish it 
2. Create a post with the tag 'Reproduce' (or any other tag which is a superstring of the first tag) and publish it 
3. Update your theme to check for the superstring tag, something like `{{#has tag="reproduce"}}Hello World{{/has}}`
4. Check your blog and see that both posts output 'Hello World' not just the post with 'reproduce' as a tag.

Tag matches should be exact.

### Technical details: 

* Ghost Version: master
issue_labels.name: [blocker, bug, themes]

body: fixes #4780

issue_title: Generated post URL from title should replace @ with dash
body:
Post URLs are generated from the post title, which is awesome!

Special characters in post URLs such as `.` are replaced with a dash. This is also nice because the period often separates words and the dash keeps the URL readable.

__Problem:__

I've noticed that the `@` is removed instead of replaced with a dash. If this was intentional, then you can go ahead and close this issue:)

However, for myself, this often results in URLs that jumble words. For example:

-  `phonegap-cli@4.1.2` --> `/phonegap-cli4-1-2`
- `PhoneGap Meetup@Vancouver` --> `/phonegap-meetupvancouver`

It would be nice to replace the `@` with a `-` so the URLs are generated as:

-  `phonegap-cli@4.1.2` --> `/phonegap-cli-4-1-2`
- `PhoneGap Meetup@Vancouver` --> `/phonegap-meetup-vancouver`

Cheers,
Michael

body:
Good to know that this is the expected way for it to work. I hadn't noticed it in any documentation so I wasn't sure.

Though, perhaps not a bug, and more of a general change request, notifying users (in some way) that imported accounts may be locked by default on import would be good. Informing them that their account is locked only when they try to log in is not as graceful as I imagine Ghost should be.

issue_title: Pass the current runner config into the onPrepare hook
body:
Currently the `onPrepare()` hook has no arguments passed into it. This means that, even though it is called once per capability, it has no idea which capability is being executed so it can't make context-sensitive decisions. This PR passes that configuration block into `onPrepare()` so it can do that, like including requirements that only certain tests need (for performance reasons, or where only certain environments require/support them).

Since `runFilenameOrFn_()` already supports the concept of passing arguments to the callback, this only requires a 1-line code change. However, in the process of editing this file I noticed a few lines that had extra whitespace at the end of them. Since trimming line-ending whitespace is a rule generally followed by other AngularJS code bases, I included those trimmings here.
repo_description: E2E test framework for Angular apps

issue_title: Remove v2 branch?
body:
All my projects follow a "release branch" strategy, rather than a "release from master" strategy. Development happens in master, and only bug fixes get committed to the release branch (currently v2). These are then constantly merged back to master. This is how I'm used to doing things, but I'm not religiously tied to it. If people prefer doing things a different way, it's fine as long as it's clear where development happens, and we have a stable branch that always represents whatever should be used in production.

It's also worth noting we have two built files for browsers that should usually go in a release. v1 had these committed into revision control, which is not optimal for things which are created as part of a build. Currently I'm manually creating a GH Release when something significant changes, and manually building (`jake build`) and uploading those files. I was hoping to add some hooks into the current `jake publish` flow which would automate that process as well.

issue_title: Remove v2 branch?
body:
@mde said:

> All my projects follow a "release branch" strategy, rather than a "release from master" strategy. Development happens in master, and only bug fixes get committed to the release branch (currently v2).

This is completely fine for me, but I was just confused about the branching scheme as master and v2 are basically the same thing, and we do not intend to break backwards compat in master in the near future.

What we are doing in Jade is basically everything happens in master, and once design flaws and old bugs (whose fixes would break backward compat) pile up, we branch out to a new branch, and concurrent development happens with v2 routinely merged from master. When v2 is mature enough (and when we have too many fixes piled up) we merge from it.

Considering the fact that we are not like the Linux kernel or huge projects with multiple supported release branches, I feel that the Jade system works pretty well; but if you prefer to *always* have a production branch, go ahead, I don't hold a strong opinion.

issue_title: Remove v2 branch?

body:
The url parsing around lib/tasks/db.js:33 rejects urls has a couple of problems:
1. it rejects some valid urls, for example urls without username/password
2. it fails with a strange message when a URL is rejected:
```
[10:03:30] Starting 'db:migrate'...
[10:03:30] 'db:migrate' errored after 483 μs Cannot read property '6' of null
```

It seems like it might be better to use the [node built-in url module] (http://nodejs.org/docs/latest/api/url.html#url_url_parse_urlstr_parsequerystring_slashesdenotehost) instead of a regular expression for parsing.

issue_title: Operation params are exposed via url for easier sharing
body:
Our API has quite a few parameters, so when pointing developers to our docs, I wanted to help them fill out some of the more interesting fields. While default values can accomplish the same goal to some extent, it's convenient to be able to share many different parameters for the same operation.

So for the pet store example, I might want to point a developer to a particularly interesting pet, or help them create a default pet in their account to start them off (though this feature only really makes sense on a more complex API).

Example: this will open the `pet/getPetById` operation and pre-fill the `petId` field with the value `4`
`http://localhost:3000/#!/pet/getPetById?petId=4`

Example: this will open the `pet/addPet` operation and pre-fill the `body` field with the value `{"id":4, "name":"Spike"}` so the developer only has to click the "Try it out!" button to create their first pet.
`http://localhost:3000/#!/pet/addPet?body=%7B%22id%22%3A4%2C+%22name%22%3A%22Spike%22%7D&parameterContentType=application%2Fjson`

Clicking "Try it out!" updates location.hash with the current params, which you can then copy & paste.

Caveat: it's just a concept, not tested exhaustively, and I'm by no means a Swagger expert.
repo_description: Swagger UI is a dependency-free collection of HTML, Javascript, and CSS assets that dynamically generate beautiful documentation from a Swagger-compliant API.

issue_title: Generated post URL from title should replace @ with dash
body:
@claydiffrient it would also be fabulous to add some test coverage to capture these changes.

The characters are: 
- punctuation: `'`, `"`  `:`  `,` `;` `?` and `!` `'`, `"`
- and-like things: `&` `+` and `|`
- at `@`
- slashes: `/` and `\`
- brackets `[` `]` `(` `)` `<` and `>`
- other symbols `$` `£` `#` `%`  `*`  `=`  `^`  and `~`  

The issue is, as I see it, where symbols are used to separate words without spaces. Usually, there would be spaces as well as the symbol, and the spaces would end up being collapsed down into a single dash. 

So the question becomes what symbols, like the `@` sign, are likely to be used without spaces as word separators, as opposed to being used as prefixes and suffixes that don't require the concept of a space.

I think the answer to this is anything and-like for sure and probably a lot of the punctuation (colons and commas).

However, from another perspective, we do already collapse down multiple dashes, so if there is more than one dash that's ok. The main thing that I don't think we do currently, is trim away a leading or trailing dash.

If we de-duplicate and trim away leading/trailing dashes, then we can probably replace most characters with a dash, rather than removing it and the question becomes which characters can't we do that for - to which the answer is  'any character which could appear in the middle of a word' - i.e basically just `'`

Or did I just massively over-simplify this?

Tests and real-world use cases would be helpful I think :)

issue_title: Informing users when the autosave goes wrong
body:
Using Facebook, Gmail and various other services, I got used to simple "offline" hints. [Offline](https://github.com/hubspot/offline) is one of the solutions that I like a lot - in principle, not saying that we should use the library). In particular, I like the idea of catching a failed AJAX call and retrying it when connection has been reestablished.  Basically, I think that a good solution would work with all of Ember data's ajax requests, not just the post autosave.

An error message on failed autosave with regards to save not working might be useful too, but since we can't give useful fixing information for the save issue anyway, we might as well go and report troubles for all AJAX troubles we might run into.
issue_labels.name: [design, ghost-ui]

issue_title: Bug: New posts are added to the bottom of the post list
body:
### Issue Summary
When you create a new post, the latest post appears at the bottom of the post list until refreshing, or leaving then revisiting the admin interface.

![new_post_issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3655670/5693745/4eeff4b2-98fa-11e4-98e6-a08a4fea4f21.gif)


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Login to Ghost, note the order of the posts.
2. Create a new post, and publish it.
3. Return to the "Content" menu and note the new post appears at the bottom of the list.

This is a bug because the default ordering of the post list is reverse chronological order, thus the latest post should appear at the top of the list.

### Technical details

* Ghost Version: 0.5.7
* Client OS: Mac OS X 10.10.1
* Server OS: Mac OS X 10.10.1 & Ubuntu Linux 14.04
* Node Version: 0.10.30
* Browser: Chrome 39.0.2171.95 (64-bit)
* Database: SQLite

issue_title: Memos Broken

People using ripple-lib to recalculate transaction tree hashes have been out of luck.

Seems like the memo json parser is [broken](https://github.com/ripple/ripple-lib/commit/1704ac4ae144c0ce54afad86f644c75a632080b1), and is misinterpreting rippled's hex as if it were utf8.  i.e. `FF` as two bytes, rather than one.

issue_title: Bug: New posts are added to the bottom of the post list
body:
So that *sort of* makes sense to me:

That change changes the way items in the content list are rendered from being what I assume is the proxied items  in the `ArrayController` that is the PostController:

`{{#each itemController="posts/post" itemView="post-item-view" itemTagName="li"}}`

To explicitly grabbing posts from the model: 

`{{#each post in model itemController="posts/post" itemView="post-item-view" itemTagName="li"}}`

But the documentation for Ember SortableMixin, which provides the ability to sort items in an ArrayController, says this:

> Ember.SortableMixin provides a standard interface for array proxies to specify a sort order and maintain this sorting when objects are added, removed, or updated without changing the implicit order of their underlying model array

So as I understand it, the model itself is not sorted. Ember adds the new post at the end, and it works when you refresh because then the items are provided from the server in the right order.

*(I'm typing this out because I'm trying to improve my understanding of the Ember internals and perhaps someone can point out mistakes in my understanding or terminology that will help me in future)*

I've done a bit of reading and it seems SortableMixin is supposed to be being deprecated, and I also believe Ember is moving away from using ObjectController and ArrayController where the model gets proxied, in order to reduce a little bit of the 'magic' and our dependence on the magic in Ghost is also what is causing #4766. 

I've read a couple of references to Ember.computed.sort, but I'm not sure how to apply it in this case. I *think* the right answer is to have a more explicit sorted version of the posts? Something like:

`{{#each sortedPosts}}` ?
issue_labels.name: [blocker, bug]

issue_title: Bug: New posts are added to the bottom of the post list

issue_title: Bug: New posts are added to the bottom of the post list
body:
@Trendy You're spot on that this would be good to consider, although I've classified this as a blocker, meaning it needs to be fixed before we do another release - I cannot believe this hasn't been noticed before now it's awful :(

I am playing with `Ember.computed.sort` and I think it might be the right way to go in order to make resolving #2640 easier as well (although it would be good to get @LevelbossMike to confirm as he has the most experience with the filtering concept).

The original reason for requiring this [massive amount of ugly extra sorting code](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/blob/master/core/client/controllers/posts.js#L40) was that the 'sortProperties' for SortableMixin all had to be in the same direction, and our post list is sorted with status:asc, and all the other properties as desc. This prevents us having to do a big union query to get drafts and published posts in the right order, but one day we'll need to do that anyway.

It seems that `Ember.computed.sort` takes a list of properties and directions, which at first look seems to mean we can remove the orderBy function completely and replace it with:

```
 sortProperties: ['status:asc', 'published_at:desc', 'updated_at:desc', 'id:desc'],
 sortedPosts: Ember.computed.sort('model', 'sortProperties'),
```

And change the template to `{{#each post in sortedPosts}}`

If it doesn't work we can replace sortProperties with our custom orderBy function again. Further when thinking about #2640, we can dynamically update sortProperties, or again use a custom function and it should be a logical extension to this change.

 I'm currently taking it for a spin to see if the order stays correct without needing all that code.
issue_labels.name: [blocker, bug]

issue_title: Test sharding / parallelization
body:
A note about dynamic creation of groups (@vojtajina) - We should be aware of how this affects tests that happen to have side effects. Imagine tests B, C, and D, and a naive alphabetical devision of tests into two groups - {B,C} and {D}. Lets say C has a devastating side affect and I'm adding test A, hence changing the grouping to {A,B} and {C,D}. Now D will fail, just because the grouping changed.

Of course, tests shouldn't have side effects, but this case is bound to happen, and might be very confusing to users.

body:
The opt in is because how will Express know how to call your function? This opt in is not something visible to end users, only to communicate the calling signature to Express's code.

Express will soon make the user specify locals not mixed with options. Without a way for your module to tell Express not to mix them together, then you'll never see the benefit.

Express would always pass two objects so it wouldn't even be ambiguous.

issue_title: Bug: New posts are added to the bottom of the post list
body:
### Issue Summary
When you create a new post, the latest post appears at the bottom of the post list until refreshing, or leaving then revisiting the admin interface.

![new_post_issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3655670/5693745/4eeff4b2-98fa-11e4-98e6-a08a4fea4f21.gif)


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Login to Ghost, note the order of the posts.
2. Create a new post, and publish it.
3. Return to the "Content" menu and note the new post appears at the bottom of the list.

This is a bug because the default ordering of the post list is reverse chronological order, thus the latest post should appear at the top of the list.

### Technical details

* Ghost Version: 0.5.7
* Client OS: Mac OS X 10.10.1
* Server OS: Mac OS X 10.10.1 & Ubuntu Linux 14.04
* Node Version: 0.10.30
* Browser: Chrome 39.0.2171.95 (64-bit)
* Database: SQLite

## Additional Information

I'm really new to Ember, so please feel free to call me on my ignorance, but I thought this was relevant. It seems that when the new post is added to the store (loosely assuming it has something to do with Ember Data), it is just stored as the last item until we do a completely new request to the server (refresh).

![screen shot 2015-01-10 at 8 08 49 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3655670/5693939/cc5f4cea-9904-11e4-9c1e-36fff21050b8.png)
issue_labels.name: [blocker, bug]

issue_title: Cannot include files from root directory
body:
I have an ejs file that i'm rendering through express say hello.ejs. The views folder structure is views/site/test/hello.ejs

I have the following snippet inside the hello.ejs file

```
<%- include('/partials/site/templates/navbar.html'); %>
```

Currently this doesn't work. I can't include files from the views directory.

The current work around i see is going to the parent directory and giving the path

```
<%- include('../../../partials/course/templates/navbar.html'); %>
```

It'd be useful to allow include from root dir.

issue_title: `{{has}}` helper doesn't check for exact tag matches
body:
The has helper `tags=""` lookup is using a regex and only doing a partial match of the tag.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a post with the tag 'Produce' (or any other tag which can be a substring of another tag) and publish it 
2. Create a post with the tag 'Reproduce' (or any other tag which is a superstring of the first tag) and publish it 
3. Update your theme to check for the superstring tag, something like `{{#has tag="reproduce"}}Hello World{{/has}}`
4. Check your blog and see that both posts output 'Hello World' not just the post with 'reproduce' as a tag.

Tag matches should be exact.

### Technical details: 

* Ghost Version: master
issue_labels.name: [bug, themes]

issue_title: Double slash in the URL when basePath ends with '/' and resource API path starts with '/'
body:
> copy in swagger-js 2.0.48 and test it out.

I tried it out, the problem is not fixed in 2.0.48.

If I understand the implementation in swagger-js correctly, the code handling double-slash in the URL is inside the method `this.getAbsoluteBasePath`, which is unfortunately not invoked when the basePath is already a full URL. See [swagger.js#L451](https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-js/blob/1f8984acebe76d055d5304420a5dfe38f9af4556/lib/swagger.js#L451):

```js
this.basePath = response.basePath.indexOf('http') === -1 ? 
  this.getAbsoluteBasePath(response.basePath) : 
  response.basePath;
```

Later, when the user clicks on the "Try it out!" button, the method `urlify` performs a simple concatenation to build the URL and thus a double-slash is produced. see [swagger.js#988](https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-js/blob/1f8984acebe76d055d5304420a5dfe38f9af4556/lib/swagger.js#L988):

```js
var url = this.resource.basePath + this.pathJson();
// url = "http://localhost:3000/" + "/products" 
```

issue_title: RTL Languages
body:
Hi Rezaa, welcome to Ghost's GitHub. We use GitHub as an issue tracker for features and issue with the software itself. We have a [forum](https://ghost.org/forum) for general questions.

Ghost doesn't have any support for being translated into any language yet. You can find details on our [roadmap](https://trello.com/c/YomMBGO2/47-localisation-multi-lang-i18n).

issue_title: [Hold] Add the needed table columns for client Oauth.
body:
One major blocker is that OAuth itself is a fairly tricky subject (let alone the programming around it) and our resident expert @sebgie has been working on other projects. We're also a bit stuck without a way to [migrate permissions](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/issues/3910). If you follow along with [meetings / or write-ups](http://dev.ghost.org/tag/meetings/) you'll see we're planning to shift the team's focus from user-facing features as things are at the moment, towards the developer-facing features like this once we've shipped a few more of the features we're working on. 

In short, you can help us out in a number of ways, contributing in any way to the project (testing pull requests, fixing bugs and smaller issues) helps us move faster and get to this stuff sooner ;)

This will need resource management similar to what [karma-browserstack-launcher](https://github.com/karma-runner/karma-browserstack-launcher) has (using [the npm browserstack module](https://www.npmjs.com/package/browserstack)). ```
UnknownError: N sessions are currently being used. Please upgrade to add more parallel sessions.
```

issue_title: Infinite scroll in Posts list dead on large monitors
body:
Posts list infinite scroll dead on large monitors. Discovered on a 30" monitor running 2560x1600 resolution.

### Issue Summary

Unable to load next batch of posts in the posts list inside admin, when browser is larger than the initial 15 items.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Make sure there's more than 15 posts in the list. I tested with 20. It doesn't matter if they're all draft.
2. Resize your browser to a window height greater than 1500px
3. Go to [http://localhost:2368/ghost](http://localhost:2368/ghost) to see the posts list 
3. Try to scroll the posts list

When trying to scroll the posts list, nothing happens.
I would expect the list to load the next batch of posts into the list.

![posts-list-dead-scroll](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/67565/5637891/a1251d40-9600-11e4-9661-348608c6cd46.gif)

A workaround is to resize the browser windows for vertical scroll to appear, and then scroll the list again to load up the next batch of posts.

![workaround-posts-list-dead-scroll](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/67565/5637898/b0799b18-9600-11e4-82af-eeee216ec78d.gif)

### Technical details:

* Ghost Version: master (latest commit: 04180bc83b5e99947d1c3820e3032c62e82a08c2)
* Client OS: Mac OS X 10.10.2
* Server OS: Mac OS X 10.10.2
* Node Version: 0.10.35
* Browser: 39.0.2171.96 & Chrome 41.0.2251.0 dev
* Database: SQLite
issue_labels.name: [bug]

issue_title: swagger-ui doesn't use resourcePath to in "Try it out!" call
swagger-ui doesn't use resourcePath in "Try it out!" call
body:
Hi, resource path is really used just for the organization of docs:

```
# base path
http://my.server.com/api

# resource listing, serves up list of all available apis
http://my.server.com/api/api-docs

# api declaration, serves up a single api definition under the path `users`, which is the `resourcePath`
http://my.server.com/api/api-docs/users

# base path, where the `users` api is called, from `basePath` + `path` (in api declaration):
http://my.server.com/api/users
```

issue_title: Image upload via iOS / Android displayed sideways
body:
It's nothing to do with Ghost, it's a browser issue. If you search Google, you'll find many, many complaints about it all over the web for all sorts of different sites.

Fuji cameras record orientation data within EXIF just like Apple devices do, and the browser decides how to display them.

issue_title: swagger-ui doesn't use resourcePath in "Try it out!" call
body:
Hi,
 I ran in to a possible bug.
In the raw output of my endpoint the `resourcePath` is correctly displayed
When I click "Try it out!" `basePath + path` are used in the call : `http://localhost:8080/rest/hello`

I thought `basePath + resourcePath + path` would be used : `http://localhost:8080/rest/string/static/hello`.

I made an [example app to illustrate the issue]( /mbde/swagger-example) it uses : 
 * jersey 1.18.2 
 * spring 3.2.9 
 * swagger-jersey-jaxrs_2.10 1.3.12
 * swagger-ui 2.0.24 from org.webjars

Output of raw : 
````json
{
  "apiVersion": "0.1",
  "swaggerVersion": "1.2",
  "basePath": "http://localhost:8080/rest",
  "resourcePath": "/string/static",
  "apis": [
    {
      "path": "/{string}",
      "operations": [
        {
          "method": "GET",
          "summary": "identity function",
          "notes": "",
          "type": "string",
          "nickname": "getStatic",
          "parameters": [
            {
              "name": "string",
              "required": true,
              "type": "string",
              "paramType": "path",
              "allowMultiple": false
            }
          ]
        }
      ]
    },
    {
      "path": "/hello",
      "operations": [
        {
          "method": "GET",
          "summary": "hello world",
          "notes": "",
          "type": "string",
          "nickname": "getStaticHelloWorld",
          "parameters": []
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}
 ````
Thanks for the good work :)

issue_title: [TASK] Add flow tasks to Gulpfile
body:
The full flow workflow isn't integrated yet, but the transitional workflow is:
1. Add /* @flow */ to the top of a file you are working on
2. Run "gulp typecheck" and fix all the warnings/errors for that file
Once we do this for all the files, we can disable "weak mode" and do a second round of error fixing. Once that is done, we can start adding type annotations and start using the "gulp strip" task.

issue_title: Pass the current runner config into the onPrepare hook
body:
In general, we try to avoid feature creep in the configuration file. `multiCapabilities` was added because it was highly requested, addresses a common use case, and provides a lot of benefits. On the other hand, it has significant costs, as does anything that complicates the config. The idea of multiCapabilities is that you want to run the _same setup_ on a couple different browsers. We don't want, and cannot support, one config file being able to support all cases. If what you're requesting is easy to do with multiple config files, that's a great solution!

For this specific request - you can get at the current capabilities using `browser.getCapabilities` (returns a promise). Could you let us know if this doesn't cover your use case? If so, what other context are you looking for?

If we do introduce a way to get the config (which is not out of the question), I'd like it to be more general than being passed as a parameter to onPrepare functions.
issue_labels.name: [cla: yes]

body:
I cannot reproduce the problem of it linking to `protractor.js` instead of `element.js`.  I assume that this is just because the docs hadn't been re-generated in a while.

I'm not sure how I feel about the fix Julie is proposing though.  What if someone generates a new set of website docs, then does a `git commit --amend`, changing the hash?  When they push everything to github, the docs they've generated will **all** link to a 404.  The current approach has its problems to be sure, but it's never fails so dramatically.  What I would rather see is some sort of fully-automated process for updating the docs so that they just never get out of sync with the code

issue_title: CanvasRenderer.variables & save/restore state
body:
I'm noticing that the CanvasRenderer.variables are not being tracked properly with save/restore states. How would you prefer to fix this: a) make this.variables into an array for tracking states, and pop/push when save/restore is run. b) tap into native tracking of variables—e.g.: "if (this.ctx[property] !== value) {" instead of "if (this.variables[property] !== value) {" I think option (b) would be easier, and you don't have to worry about things as much. I did a jsperf on the performance gains of using this.variables, and it's negligible on 1,000,000 checks. This will fix issues with shadow not rendering properly in certain cases, such as this:
Giant blue lobsters!!!

issue_title: ejs with v0.11.14   Error: Identifier 'rethrow' has already been declared
body:
All things being equal, it's generally better to make fewer changes than more. :)

And I have generally come to prefer expressions because they just have normal hoisted variables. With declarations, the declared variable and the assignment are both hoisted, which adds another potentially confusing wrinkle. ... Or maybe it's just that declarations remind me of the bad old days of late 90s JS programming. :)

issue_title: Pass the current runner config into the onPrepare hook
body:
Well... this is certainly disheartening. :(

First, it's not one-browser-many-cases. It's one-case-many-browsers. But browser.getCapabilities() doesn't address it because it returns Selenium's block, not Protractor's. Suppose you wanted to use a configuration similar to the one discussed in this issue:

https://github.com/angular/protractor/issues/1354

Suppose you wanted your screenshot tool at the end of each test to drop the file in a directory whose name contained the resolution being captured. There's no way to do this currently - browser.getCapabilities will give you the browser name and version back, but not the other options. But with a single additional option in the capabilities block you could pass a parameter to each test that was specific to that block. This makes it a single line of code to marry these up.

Over the past year it seems like this kind of thing has been repeatedly requested:

https://github.com/angular/protractor/issues/1594
("I would definitely benefit from this...")

https://github.com/angular/protractor/issues/1195
``var capsPromise = browser.getCapabilities(); //does not contain useful stuff```

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/22305297/run-protractor-tests-with-different-window-sizes

etc. Various requests to be able to pass in dynamic elements to a test like user/pass, test data, browser resolutions, etc. are all over StackOverflow and here.

config.params is messy because it's hard-coded. onPrepare is given as the specific answer for how to do things like set resolution in a number of places as well, e.g. here:

http://ramonvictor.github.io/protractor/slides/#/34

I'm not saying Ramon is the de-facto source for this information... but there certainly isn't anything to contradict it elsewhere...

Multiple configs is a bad answer because 95% of my protractor config is identical between each test - it's only the elements in each capabilities block that changes. (It's the same app... just across a range of browsers and resolutions...) Having to duplicate 200 lines of configuration data just to change ONE line of "put THESE screen shots in THIS folder" is a huge maintenance hassle.

Finally, it's disheartening because this was the first in a collection of contributions I had planned to make. I thought it was perfectly in line with a testing framework designed specifically for a JS framework that values declarative definitions, dependency injection, DRYness, etc. Discovering that the TESTING framework prefers basically the opposite - inferential connections between items, significant repetition, and call-for rather than injecting dependencies makes me wonder if the rest of what I had planned to suggest was misguided.

Is there a document somewhere that outlines the design principles behind this project? I have what I believe are some valuable ideas, but I don't want to be a nuisance... and I certainly don't want to repeatedly trigger 8-hour discussion about 8-byte code changes! :) I'm happy to comply with whatever those principles are... but where can I find them outlined?
issue_labels.name: [cla: yes]

issue_title: HTML reporter retains old 'grep=' querystrings when changing suites
body:
Currently, if you use the `http://localhost/tests.html?grep=MySuite` format for limiting Mocha tests in the browser, all the suite/test links in the report get additional `grep=` params. Clicking on them retains older (ignored) values in the URL:

`http://localhost/tests.html?grep=MySuite&grep=MySuite%20%23someMethod`

Switching back to the higher suite will tack on yet another param:

`http://localhost/tests.html?grep=MySuite&grep=MySuite%20%23someMethod&grep=MySuite`

Ideally, switching to a new `grep` setting should clear the existing one in the URL. I'll submit a PR which implements this desired behavior.

issue_title: HTML reporter: Allow the error to contain a formatted HTML error message
body:
We're still eagerly awaiting feedback on this. At this point this issue should be thought of as a place to discuss how to add colored messages and diffs in the browser. The fact that it includes a PR is just meant to demonstrate our position on how to accomplish it.

By the way -- I'm not sure how to add a test for this behavior in html reporter as it currently doesn't have any.

In the mean time we've published a mocha fork with these patches it in (mocha-papandreou), and Unexpected 5 with support for `htmlMessage` went out out of beta, so if anyone's interested in getting really nice object diffs that are also colored in the browser, try installing mocha-papandreou@2.1.0-patch2 or above and unexpected 5.2.0 or above.

issue_title: Patch cucumber framework JSON output to be fully compliant to cucumber-j...
body: The purpose of the 'resultJsonOutputFile' reporter isn't for it to match a cucumber log. The purpose is for jasmine/mocha/cucumber to be able to share a common output. If you just want to report specific items for cucumber, you can pass your reporter into cucumber as a custom reporter.

issue_title: New Navigation Menu Interface
body:
This is part of the Navigation epic: #4535

--- 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/120485/5228785/917b5448-7717-11e4-9b1d-1e24a48e5729.png)

The navigation menu lives on its own settings screen under `/settings/navigation/`. It uses the compass icon added in #4536. To start with, this UI should be built behind a config flag, the same as permalinks, tag management etc.

The navigation UI should start out with one default entry - "Home" - pointing at `{{@blog.url}}`, and with one empty entry below it with placeholder text (this will be loaded from the default setting).

### Notes on the interface:

* Ignore the application frame in the screenshot - that's just old mockup - focus on settings pane content
* Cursor state for drag handles should be "move" - there should be no other hover state for drag handles.
* There should be no special highlight or state when a nav-item is being dragged
* Hover state for the trash icon should be `$red`
* Add icon is the exact same one from the content screen
* Grab handles and trash icons should have padding around them for increased hit area
* There will be no concept (for this first version) of nesting / hierarchy
issue_labels.name: [ember, settings]

issue_title: [develop 2.0] add support for multiple file uploads
body:
I think there's some confusion here. @mhdl64 is using Swagger 1.2 and not 2.0.

Another problem is that I can't think of a way to describe multiple file uploads, unless we modify the 2.0 spec.

You can describe a single file parameter, no problem. But you cannot specify an array of files, since `file` is not an applicable value for `item`'s `type` - https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-spec/blob/master/versions/2.0.md#itemsType.

We could change that, though it'll carry complications to both the documentation and the schema (not a reason not to add support for it).

Even if we do add support for it, we may need to impose a `collectionFormat` value of `multi`. It makes sense for `multipart/form-data` but possibly a bit less for `application/x-www-form-urlencoded` (though we can infer the meaning). We can say that the `collectionFormat` is inferred and with that combination it is assumed to be `multi` (and cannot be overridden - validation error), but we have a similar case in the spec where we currently force people to include a property with a known default value which cannot be changed.

Last thing, there's a ticket for a future version of the spec to allow specifying the mime type(s) of the uploaded files, and it should integrate well into this solution.

issue_title: CanvasRenderer.variables & save/restore state
body:
Sorry it wasn't a "jsperf", I was just running a "js perfomance" loop 1,000,000 times. 

Running in jsperf.com, here's there results:  http://jsperf.com/context-vs-variables

Ctx runs 32 million checks per second on my machine, and Variables runs 160 million checks (each test is running 4 checks). To me it's a toss up, as currently Variables is only used for Shadow, and this jsperf is not taking into account the additional overhead of adding a custom save/restore function which would be run on CanvasRenderer.prototype.clip(), as well as some NodeParser.prototype.paint() and NodeParser.prototype.paintNode() calls.

I have rebased this PR against latest master. I've updated the rangyinputs library now that it has been released (this fixes undo/redo on everything except IE) and I've also added `spellcheck="true"` to the editor.

All of these updates have been pushed to the Live demo @ http://editordemo.ghost.io (email: demo@ghost.org, pass: test1234).

There are definitely other improvements to be had: finding a solution for tabs, cleaning up some of the upload events and other things, but the base functionality is here and I think, providing we're happy this is working nicely cross-browser, it would be preferable to get this merged into master ahead of the next release and make any further adjustments as separate PRs.

@PaulAdamDavis rebasing had a lot of conflicts in CSS - it might be worth you going through and checking that I didn't screw it up (I probably did). 

Pending getting the tests passing, a review of the CSS by @PaulAdamDavis and further cross-browser testing of the updated PR, I'm going to take the [WIP] tag off of this :)
