issue_title: Pass the current runner config into the onPrepare hook
body:
Thanks, all, for bearing with me, especially @juliemr for being so diplomatic!

Yes, @hankduan, that's roughly the goal, although I'm trying to be a little generic with my description because running multi-resolution tests is just one use-case. I can think of dozens of others when you get into enterprise-app space.

My position is that onPrepare is perfectly time for doing test-run-specific setup - that could mean configuring the browser's resolution, setting up some environment variables such as where some test outputs will be dropped, setting up a timing analytic, etc. These are things that are not ideally done before starting Protractor itself (e.g. environment variables) because of the added value of multiCapabilities. m/c is perfect for setting up a collection of browser combinations that you want to test against. Using Chrome + Firefox and adding Safari later or IE on a box that supports it is the obvious fit there, and it's the one the documents suggest.

But as soon as you say "oh, I can say I want BOTH Firefox and Chrome" the logical next step is to say "Chrome 1400x1050 and also Chrome 1024x768". This is a single line of code in onPrepare... as long as you know that this is the resolution desired. But resolution is not the only use-case - as I said above perhaps you could be testing i18n functionality and setting the browser's language. You can do that with the --lang=LANG flag in Chrome's arguments in the capabilities - but how do you tell your test to go to LANG.mydomain.com and that you want your test reports dumped out to build/reports/LANG? Yes, multiple configs are possible - but they're almost identical so it's a pain to maintain if you decide to switch to SauceLabs one day. On the other hand, a 1-line-of-code solution is possible if you make the 'current' capabilities config accessible somewhere onPrepare (and others?) can get to it. You just `browser.get('http://' + currentCapabilityConfig.lang + '.mydomain.com/');` in your test script, or `browser.takeScreenshot().then(....   // Write the PNG to 'build/screens/' + currentCapabilityConfig.lang + '/home-page.png')`

I also still think this would be very valuable when you start using Protractor's recently-added support for making these hooks call external scripts. You could have some very elegant and powerful configurations with very little work.

I could probably imagine several dozen cases where you might want to test some browser-specific aspect of your site/app, something whose only functional difference is a slight change in the capabilities config block.

I suppose the generic feature-request is to provide some way of enabling context-sensitive work to be performed inside hooks (and test scripts?) And I believe the single thing required to make all that happen is to have access to the current capability configuration object being executed. If you prefer not to inject it, perhaps a simple call to obtain it? IMO it's a little weird because there's already browser.getCapabilities() which suggests that it does this (but returns something else), but anything in this category would totally solve the problem for me.

Just brainstorming here... This may be just a horrific idea (I blame a sleepless night) but it seems like Angular's own dependency injection is a clean way to address a lot of these kinds of things. The provider/injector concept is already very familiar to Angular authors, and it seems like it wouldn't be much more than an else case and an array iterator (with calls to providers to obtain the things to inject) in the spot where hooks are being called. Totally understand if you hate the idea, but it does seem like another way to address this kind of problem in a relatively generic way that doesn't lead to hard-coding of hook arguments - and potentially even allows test authors/maintainers to create their own providers...

Or maybe just browser.getCapabiitiesConfig() and we're done here? :) Would you accept a PR that provided that?
issue_labels.name: [cla: yes]

issue_title: Make JSON output to be ready to convert to JUnitXML for CI usage
body:
@jlin412 cucumber.js is already using such json formatter to log Cucumber processes, and quite complete implemented Cucumber concept. So it looks like not really a "problem", just need someone to save the log/result into a well formatted json file, which can be easily put into CI to generate beautiful  reports.

And Protractor is exact the one who already implemented "resultJsonOutputFile" configuration and functionality. If the Json output file is already there, why not improve it to be more CI friendly?

However we are not sure why jasmine/mocha/cucumber these three framework in Protractor need to be shared as common output. Using different testing framework to test against one project looks like not really common cases. Maybe there are some reasons for this?

With the Json format being improved, we don't need report generator like jasmine-reporters which require developers to pay attention to the configuration and match the correct reporter versions. All we need is a parser to convert .json to .xml.
issue_labels.name: [cla: yes]

issue_title: Error 255 when upgrade the ghost
body:
Hi, all:
I upgrade the ghost from 0.3.3 to 0.5.8 according the document given by http://support.ghost.org/how-to-upgrade/
1.Download the latest version of Ghost from Ghost.org
2.Extract the zip file to a temporary location
3.Delete existing index.js and package.json then copy new index.js and package.json files to the same directory.
4.Next, delete the old core directory completely, and then put the new core directory in its place.
5.For releases which include update to Casper (the default theme), delete the old content/themes/casper directory and put the new one its place
6.Run npm install --production
7.Finally, Restart Ghost so that the changes take effect

Then, when i use "npm start" to start my ghost, there is an error happen, here is log:

ghost@0.5.8 start /home/xiaohuolu/blog
node index
Migrations: Database upgrade required from version 000 to 003
Migrations: Creating database backup
Migrations: Database backup written to: /home/xiaohuolu/blog/content/data/vinllen-chens-blog.ghost.2015-01-13.json
Migrations: Running migrations
Migrations: Creating table: permissions_apps
Migrations: Creating table: apps
Migrations: Creating table: app_settings
Migrations: Creating table: app_fields
Migrations: Creating table: clients
Migrations: Creating table: accesstokens
Migrations: Creating table: refreshtokens
Migrations: Adding column: tags.image
Migrations: Adding column: tags.hidden

Migrations: Populating permissions
Migrations: Removing old permissions
Migrations: Converting admin to owner
Migrations: Populating default settings
Migrations: Complete

ERROR: (Code: EACCES) 
There was an error starting your server. 
Please use the error code above to search for a solution.

npm ERR! weird error 255
npm WARN This failure might be due to the use of legacy binary "node"
npm WARN For further explanations, please read
/usr/share/doc/nodejs/README.Debian

npm ERR! not ok code 0

Thanks for anyone's reply

Yes. The pubkey_node is for extra logging detail. In recent versions of rippled this is provided in the initial server subscribe response, so this extra call to server_info is only necessary for old versions of rippled. This function will probably be deprecated entirely soon.

issue_title: IE9 re-executes all external scripts again on document.documentElement.cloneNode(true)
body:
For some reason IE9 decides to re-download and execute all scripts again on `documentElement` clone. While the scripts are already stripped to avoid them getting re-executed before appending them to the cloned window, IE9 will need them to be stripped prior to the node being cloned.

Works as expected on IE>9.

https://saucelabs.com/tests/718465e9b0ad40579c6b999a76e7edff

I think it would be more clear to use different names like:
`var rangeSetString = String(rangeSet);`
`assert.strictEqual(typeof rangeSetString, 'string', 'Ledger range malformed');`
`var rangeStrings = rangeSetString.split(',');`
`var range = rangeStrings[0].split('-').map(Number);`
I thought about it. On second thought, I'll do that

issue_title: Make JSON output to be ready to convert to JUnitXML for CI usage
body:
As an end user who only use 1 framework, being able to combine the three frameworks might not be important to you, but as a framework developer, it is very important because it allows us (including people looking to contribute) to introduce a single feature to all protractor frameworks without going to each individual framework and learning how to implement a feature for it. This results in easier learning curve, faster feature delivery and easier maintainability.

For example, we use this to write tests to test protractor -- i.e. asserting stacktrace is sane, error code is correct, right errors are being thrown, etc. Without a common reporter, we would need to go to adapt this backend test framework for each of jasmine/mocha/cucumber. 

That being said, developers are more than welcome to add more useful output to resultJsonOutputFile if it is useful or modify the current output if it doesn't make sense. However, for your case, implementing new reporters for test frameworks (i.e. jasmine/mocha/cucumber) is not the responsibility of protractor. What if tomorrow another person comes and wants resultJsonOutputFile to report a different output that breaks your conversion to .xml, but say helps conversion to .html? That's why protractor is built so that people can easily attach other reporter modules to it, so that everyone can use the most appropriate report for their use case, and not try to implement all reporters itself.
issue_labels.name: [cla: yes]

body:
This PR adds cross origin headers to the RSS feed thus allowing it to be accessible by other webpages which wish to pull the feed using AJAX. This is useful if you want to include the latest X posts from your blog on an external site.

There are no particular security concerns to be worried about here as it only allows the `GET` method and nothing in the `rss` action changes any data.

issue_title: Make JSON output to be ready to convert to JUnitXML for CI usage
body:
Agreed, the primary purpose of the JSON output is to serve as a common language between test frameworks. This is for Protractors own use as well as plugins. The documentation for this JSON is in https://github.com/angular/protractor/blob/master/lib/frameworks/README.md. I'm going close this PR since it will break things for us by updating only cucumber.

We could take a look at a another change which edits the spec result format for all frameworks and updates the associated documentation and usage from plugins. Note that this would probably introduce a breaking change, so we'd need to pick a good time to release. If we do it, I'd like it to be so that the output matches a format agreed upon by a group such as that being discussed at https://github.com/js-reporters/js-reporters

issue_title: add support for multiple Text Shadows
body:
Thanks for the PR!

The travis webdriver tests always fail for pull requests (http://docs.travis-ci.com/user/pull-requests/#Security-Restrictions-when-testing-Pull-Requests).

Few issues:

 - The whitespace should be 4 spaces instead of tab.
 - Whats the purpose of the `dx` variable and why is it needed? The current test doesn't work at all for me with that dx value added/subtracted from the different values.
 - As the text gets rendered multiple times and the fill color is hardcoded to black, won't this break rgba colors which aren't 100% opacity?
 - `NodeParser` shouldn't directly access the canvas context, instead use the `setVariable`  or other methods / properties in the `CanvasRenderer`. 

I've added some more tests to https://github.com/niklasvh/html2canvas/blob/master/tests/cases/text/shadow.html
(including some with the opacity issue) but would be nice to have some more.

issue_title: [Discussion] Sitemaps - what should be included?
body:
@dannyvankooten you'll be able to remove all those unused tags via tag management now that 0.5.8 is out.

As for fixing this up - I think it's pretty clear that these changes are required, but in order to do them we need to add filtering abilities to the API:

- filter out tags with 0 posts
- filter out authors with 0 posts

Tags do already have a concept of post_count, but there's no way to filter the API based on this property. Authors don't have a concept of post_count.

The main question I guess would be how to do filtering based on a post_count property. As a simple version we could use a negation syntax like: `?include=post_count&post_count=-0` to mean include `post_count` and don't return items where the post_count is 0. 

Using `-` for negation comes from the idea of using gmail style filtering in other places. E.g. tags="fred, -bob" means has the tag fred and doesn't have the tag bob.

Another potential syntax is json-style, `post_count={gt: 0}` to mean include items where post_count is greater than 0. As well as `gt` we could support less than (`lt`), equals (`eq`) and not equals (`neq`).

I think both syntaxes have merit and slightly different purposes. We haven't implemented anything like this in the API yet, but there's likely to be need for both negation and comparison as we move forward.

Just throwing this out there to get some thoughts from other people.
issue_labels.name: [help wanted]

issue_title: [Feature] Advanced Tag Management
body:
As of 0.5.8, we've shipped the basic [tag management feature](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/issues/4248). There are a number of cleanup and improvement tasks that we still need to track, and the big picture vision for tags described in the [Tag 101](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/wiki/Tags-101) document on the wiki, covers a number of advanced features that we can now add one at a time.

Remaining tasks from #4248:

- [ ] Dry up the code (issue #4642)
- [ ] Use tag meta data on tag archive pages (issue #4677)
- [ ] Tag Management: Functional Tests (issue #4507)
- [ ] Enforcing uniqueness of tag names (issue #4687)

Advanced features include (issues to be raised as and when we're ready to implement):

- [ ] The query helper (https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/issues/4439)
- [ ] Ordering (specific to a post, alphabetical, and by number of posts)
- [ ] Visibility / Private tags
- [ ] Primary tags (like a category)
- [ ] Hierarchy
- [ ] Improved tag UI in the editor (#3800)
- [ ] Search and filtering

At present the [Tag 101](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/wiki/Tags-101) document is the best resource for details on the advanced features.
issue_labels.name: [feature]

issue_title: [Feature] Tag Management
body:
Here's the original UI issue: #3926 , and the markup was added in #4171. The big picture vision for tags is written up in the [Tag 101](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/wiki/Tags-101) document on the wiki, which covers tonnes of advanced features.

---

In order to ship tag management we need to deliver a minimum working version. Here's what we think it should look like: 

![screenshot of simple tag list](http://puu.sh/cZyOy.png)

This list shows each tag in a list. The list needs to have infinite scroll applied to it, much the same as the users or posts list. The number on the right is the number of posts that the tag is associated with.

Clicking on any one of the tags in the list will open up the 'tag settings menu' or TSM :)

![screenshot of edit screen](http://puu.sh/cZAA0.png)

This allows for editing the tag name, slug, description, and post cover image. There is also a meta data screen the same as in the post settings menu. Editing the slug updates a live URL preview.

This screen should only appear for users with the role 'Editor' or higher.

Development How-To
===================
The tags UI is hidden behind a feature flag! To see, use, and develop with the tags settings you must set `tagsUI: true` in the `development` object of your `config.js`. 

E.g:

```
development: {
    url: 'http://localhost:2368',
    tagsUI: true,
    ...
```


Server Side
---------------------------------

### Tag API
- [x] Full BREAD baby! (Currently, only Browse is implemented) #4263
- [x] Output number of posts associated with tag (issue #4521)
- [x] Ensure API permissions are correct 

Client Side
-------------------------------

- [x] Add new page to settings #4260
- [x] BREAD (WIP PR #4489)
- [x] Add infinite scroll (done in PR #4489)
- [x] Add autosave and remove save button (issue #4517)
- [x] Add the cover image (issue #4506)
- [x] Add number of posts (issue #4683, requires #4521)
- [x] Permissions - Only editors and up
- [x] Add meta data screen (issue #4509)
- [x] Fixup the delete flow (issue #4633)
- [x] Dynamic URL preview (issue #4499)
- [ ] Dry up the code (issue #4642)

Themes
-------------

- [ ] Use tag meta data on tag archive pages (issue #4677)
- [x] Make sure `{{image}}` helper works for tags (issue #4506)

Bugs & Improvements
--------------------

- [x] Bug: Settings menu doesn't close on transition  bug ember (issue #4504)
- [x] UX Issue: Tag management list needs larger click area  ember (issue #4505)
- [ ] Tag Management: Functional Tests (issue #4507)
- [ ] Enforcing uniqueness of tag names (issue #4687)

See [Tag 101](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/wiki/Tags-101) for a description of advanced features we'll be adding later like hierarchy, visibility and search.
issue_labels.name: [ember, epic, feature, help wanted]

issue_title: {{next_post}} and {{prev_post}} helpers
body: This requires #4262 (there is an open PR #4772) ---- With the addition of the ability to fetch the next and previous post via the API, we need to make it possible for theme developers to access this functionality. The [{{#get}}](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/issues/4439) helper provides one avenue for doing this, something like: ``` {{#get "posts" id="current-post-id" include="next,prev"}} {{#prev}}{{title}}{{/prev}} {{#next}}{{title}}{{/next}} {{/get}} ``` However, that's a little unintuitive for a feature like this (which is highly requested and likely to be used by a large number of people). So it makes sense to provide a slightly nicer set of helpers. `{{next_post}}` and `{{prev_post}}` As each of these will fetch all of the properties of a post, they'll need to work as a block helper: i.e. `{{#next_post}}}{{title}}{{/next_post}}` and `{{#prev_post}}}{{title}}{{/prev_post}}`. Each helper will need to determine the current post ID, make a query to the API to fetch the data, and then ensure the data is provided such that helpers like `{{title}}` and `{{url}}` will work correctly inside the block.

issue_title: Pass the current runner config into the onPrepare hook
body:
Currently the `onPrepare()` hook has no arguments passed into it. This means that, even though it is called once per capability, it has no idea which capability is being executed so it can't make context-sensitive decisions. This PR passes that configuration block into `onPrepare()` so it can do that, like including requirements that only certain tests need (for performance reasons, or where only certain environments require/support them).

Since `runFilenameOrFn_()` already supports the concept of passing arguments to the callback, this only requires a 1-line code change.

issue_title: Bug: Strange behaviour for User Roles
body:
### Issue Summary

Hi. Apologies if this has been fixed in the master branch - I skimmed the search results and couldn't see a matching issue posted.

So, every time I go into Settings > Users, the Role will always default to Administrator, even if they are saved as something else. Yet, if I make an amendment to another field and save, it doesn't pick up the Administrators selection on the Users page.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Log into Admin.
2. Go to Settings, then Users.
3. Choose any user (ideally a non-admin) and click.
4. Note their Role compared to what displays on the User page.
5. Make amendments. Save.
6. Recheck Users page.
7. Repeat 4-6.

### Animated Proof

![ghost bug final](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9639417/5731382/9db63930-9b7a-11e4-812f-86201fac624d.gif)


### Technical details

* Ghost Version: 0.5.8 Release
* Client OS: OSX Yosemite 10.10
* Server OS: CentOS7
* Browser: Chrome 39.0.2171.95 / Firefox 35.0

This environment variable has been used historically to tell programs whether the
program may write escape sequences which encode color to stdout and stderr.

TTY detection only determines whether the file descriptor is interactive. It says nothing about
whether it's fit for colors.

Calling `mocha` from within vim, for example, causes some problems:

![screen shot 2015-01-13 at 4 16 52 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/237985/5732007/dda12590-9b3f-11e4-9d4a-c547507e93d3.png)

issue_title: Facebook callback goes to wrong server in a multi-server AWS stack
body:
Thanks again.  This issue is fully documented here:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27926635/facebook-authentication-callback-to-wrong-server-with-aws-elb-elastic-load-balan

Namely, the application was doing an auth request before having established a session.

issue_title: Facebook callback goes to wrong server in a multi-server AWS stack
body:
We have an AWS EC2 stack of several webservers running node.js/passport.  These servers are behind a NAT, and there's an Elastic Load Balancer which directs traffic in round-robin fashion to distribute load among the servers.

When there's a Facebook authentication, the callback response may go to the same server that issued the request, but sometimes it goes to the wrong server (because browsing traffic can be directed to any webserver in the stack).  So if we reduce the number of webservers to 1, everything works great.  If we increase the number of webservers and increase traffic, the client hangs waiting for the callback.

I'm looking for a best-practice way of addressing this use case.

EDIT1: I'm beginning to look into how to approach this problem using a server dedicated to handling the Facebook callback (which I'll call an authentication server).  For a Facebook authentication request on a webserver, the webserver has to make a request to the authentication server for it to do the Facebook authentication and respond with a Facebook token.  I'm not sure how the cookies get forwarded in this case (from the webserver to the authentication server) - I'm just somewhat new to node.js and passport programming.

EDIT2: The other alternative would be for AWS to provide support (if it's not already there - but I don't think it is) for a webserver to query the NAT to find out what outside port it's on, and the ELB to forward traffic according to specific port when given in the callback URL.

Autoprefixer is removing 'display: -webkit-box'
body:
What is input CSS?

In you output example prefixed `display: -webkit-box` has no unprefixed `display: flex`. If Autoprefixer finds prefix without unprefixed version, it decide that is browser-specific hack and didn’t remove outdated prefix (because it is look like that you want to hack some bug in old version like `-webkit-transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0)`).

Interactive demo uses latest 5.0-release from master (it is my mistake, I forget to create branch in Rails plugin which is used by demo to take standalone build). Autoprefixer 5.0 uses Browserslist with more correct global usage statistics calculation.

issue_title: Remove collections dependency and es6-set instead
body:
Since [collections module][1] modifies native objects, it's only good
to be used as a top dependency of an application and not modules that
it's using.

The problem is that this will conflict if native objects has been
modified by another module, let's say something like [sugar][2] or just
another version of collections. When you have two of these being used in
your app, you might be in trouble, where some code depends on a
behaviour of a method implemented by one module but actually the method
had been silently overriden by another module having a different
behaviour.

[1]: http://collectionsjs.com
[2]: http://sugarjs.com

issue_title: Source maps referring to complied css instead of SASS files
Passing Cookies to API endpoint
body:
The referenced commit lets you use the $.ajax for whatever reasons. It does not turn on sending cookies in the XMLHttpRequest by default.  And it should not be done - the server needs to confirm it and if it does not, which is the default behaviour, the entire AJAX call fails.  It is a protection against XSRF attacks; only some REST APIs perform the authorization using cookies, usually only partially.  See [withCredentials & Access-Control-Allow-Credentials](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Access_control_CORS#Requests_with_credentials).

You should still set `jqxhr.xhrFields = { withCredentials: true }` or `xhr.withCredentials = true` somewhere.  An ugly solution would be [modifying the JQueryHttpClient's execute method to do it before calling `$.ajax`](https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-ui/blob/master/dist/lib/swagger.js#L1404).  Optimally the `SwaggerUi` could include an additional option for this, for example:

    new SwaggerUi({
          url: "http://petstore.swagger.wordnik.com/api/api-docs",
              dom_id: "swagger-ui-container",
              useJQuery: true,
              withCredentials: true,
             ...

If the `ShredHttpClient` could be modified to support it, it would work only for the `JQueryHttpClient`.

A solution without modifying Swagger would be registering an `$.ajaxTransport` for all data types, creating a usual `XMLHttpRequest` instance there and set the `withCredentials` flag on it right away.

I think that the SwaggerUi should offer a flag for it, unless it allows you to access the `$.ajax` instance or to propagate options to it somehow.

issue_title: [API] Retrieve next and previous post
body: @ekulabuhov :+1:, there are more API related issues if you are interested :wink:

issue_title: API: Next and Previous post
body:
Many moons ago, #529 was raised to describe a future in which theme developers were able to access information about the next and previous post, according to the chronological order which posts are published on the blog.

Back then, bookshelf didn't support subqueries, we didn't have a clear plan for the API, and we didn't have any idea about having a query helper. All of these things combined to make this issue quite tricky to solve.

The solution that was put forward was an always-on addition to the API which meant making 2 extra queries for every post page. This seemed like unnecessary overhead for the `GET /posts/` request for a feature that wouldn't be used by everyone. Not having performance tests made it riskier.

Now that we have a clearer idea of what our API is supposed to look like (in short, JSON API but with inline objects rather than `linked`), it is much easier to design clean solutions to problems like this one. The proposal for adding next & previous support to the API is to update the posts endpoint to accept `next` and `previous` as `includes` E.g.

GET `/posts/?include=next,previous`

It should be possible to add one or both of these options, and get the corresponding post returned in the response in the following format:

```
{
    posts: [{
        id: 1,
        title: 'Something here',
        ...
        next: { 
             id: 6,
             title: 'Another post thing',
             ...
        }
    }]
}
```

Implementing this at the model level is going to require some fancy bookshelf-ery. May be worth using the subquery support here. Performance testing would be very much appreciated.

Notes:

- `next` is the post published after the current post, so should be more recent
- `previous` is the post published before
- If the `next` or `previous` posts are requested but don't exist because we are at one end of the list or another, the key should be included, but the body should be null.
- To make the API consistent, we should always return `next` and `previous` keys with the id of the post, such that adding them to `include` causes the whole object to be included, rather than the keys to magically appear. This definitely needs perf tests and will likely be a separate issue.
- This is just an API addition and won't make this feature available to themes
issue_labels.name: [api, help wanted]

issue_title: Feature: signal from a test code to abort the current running suite
body:
Hi.

I need some help and i did not know where to turn to. The question is: 
Do we have this functionality in mocha, or is this a new feature?

More details: 
I'm trying to use mocha to code some DB tests. Assume the following structure

```
migrate db to current version:
    setup:  
        - connect as admin 
        - create test db
        - close admin connection
        - run 'create-db' of previous version
    the migration flow:
        setup: connect to test db
        should pass with no errors:
            setup: begin transaction
            - alter tables & SPs
            - add built-in records to root tables
            teardown: decide if to commit or rollback
        run of sanity test sqls should pass with no errors:
            setup: begin transaction
            - insert demi data
            - execute some ETL sp
            teardown: decide if to pass or fail, but ALWAYS rollback
        teardown: db close connection
    teardown:
        - connect as admin 
        - connect to main db
        - close connection
```

Now, this flow makes great sense.
In fact, all the `the migration flow` section is a code that if we could abort it on first error, and take decisions on the teardown - it would even be safe enough to run as part of rollout to production db itself.

Now since a DB rollout happens on some DevOps machine that would talk to the db, there's no problem running mocha there, and have the communication with the db a side-effect of running the suite, and enjoying the explicitness of the spec reporter, the well-programmed waterfall, and all the rest :)


But - for that, I should be able to *abort* a suite with all it's yet-to-be-exectuted steps, *without skipping hooks* like teardown/afterall hooks.

I found the `Runner.prototype.abort` API and it looks almost like what I need - except for the fact it aborts the entire execution, and not only the current suite - but if it works I might be able to live with that.
But I did not find a way to access the runner from code of user-function for test or for a hook...

Do we have this functionality in mocha, or is this a new feature?


P.S
The only place I saw `runner.abort()` used is the `process.on('SIGINT', function() { runner.abort(); }) on the CLI file in bin. 
Is this how it's intended to be used? sounds hacky to me...
I need some confirmation that I'm not abusing this whole thing before I'll feel good with harsh statements like `process.emit('SIGINT')`...

Any word would be a helo :)

Thanks for bearing with me

issue_title: Error handling
body:
We handle errors multiple ways in Turf:

* returning `null`
* returning an `Error` object https://github.com/Turfjs/turf-flip/blob/master/index.js#L65 https://github.com/Turfjs/turf-polygon/blob/master/index.js#L23
* throwing an `Error`

I vote for throwing errors on the basis of:

* It fails faster
* It gives useful line numbers for where the error happened and which function it happened in, unlike returning errors, which defer the failure to the next function

/cc @morganherlocker @lyzidiamond

issue_title: Cross Origin Image does not load in IE9 but works on Chrome (fiddle provided)
body:
> IE9 has limited CORS support through XDomainRequest, but it only supports plaintext data, so you cannot use it to load images.

Actually, I just tested this on IE9 and found it to not be true (anymore?). Seems this may have been patched within the past ~4 years; according to [a Microsoft blog](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/05/13/xdomainrequest-restrictions-limitations-and-workarounds.aspx):

> Note: As of 2014, XDomainRequest doesn't appear to send any Content-Type header at all. It's not clear to me when this changed.

Which means the content type of the returned resource can be anything, including image.

And so it could be worth it to reopen this issue and try using `XDomainRequest` (if available) when we find that XHR doesn't support CORS.

Thoughts?

(Another, related optimization for image loading should be to allow both the `proxy` and `useCORS` options to be specified in the same invocation, with the behavior in that case being "attempt CORS, and if that fails, fall back to the proxy." The current logic ignores the proxy if `useCORS` is `true`.)

issue_title: Bugsnag blocked by AdBlock in Firefox
body:
This is unfortunate, but I guess it's kind of flattering that we're now widely used enough to get noticed :/.

More concretely, we've been added to the "EasyPrivacy" blacklist https://easylist-downloads.adblockplus.org/easyprivacy.txt — which blocks loading any script called `bugsnag-*`, or any 3rd-party request to `bugsnag.com`.

There are two partial workarounds that I see:
1. Host `bugsnag-2.js` on your own server under a different name. This will allow the Bugsnag script to load so that any references to `Bugsnag` will work rather than raising an error.
2. Check for `if (Bugsnag)` before trying to use the Bugsnag object.
These won't fix notifications (as they are blocked by the other rule), but will allow your javascript that interacts with Bugsnag to keep working.

If we added js support to [bugsnag-agent](https://github.com/bugsnag/bugsnag-agent) then we could let you send notifications via your own domain without installing [Bugsnag Enterprise](https://bugsnag.com/enterprise); but to be honest, if users want to avoid being tracked enough to install something that causes as many problems as adblock, then we should probably respect their decision.

issue_title: Connect Navigation page to live data
body:
Yeah, I left it there on purpose as the only validation specified in the issue was to not save a row if it's entirely blank.  I suppose it could be valid to want to add all your Labels and then come back later or something...

I did have a ValidationEngine validation wired up for a while to do missing/too long validation on those fields but that opens another can of worms--mainly that this "Setting" model is one big record, so if you add validations, they're going to fire anywhere you try to save something stored in the setting record.  For example, go into Settings/General and make an invalid change, leave the screen and go to either Navigation and save or to Labs and toggle the Code Injection checkbox.

I was going to open a new issue about needing to handle this now that we're modifying settings in multiple places...

Anyway, tl;dr, validations haven't really been specced and for the above reason, I didn't want to create more weirdness with the way settings are saved.

issue_title: Manage the Navigation Menu Setting / Data
body:
This is part of the Navigation epic: #4535, and requires #4537 

--- 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/120485/5228785/917b5448-7717-11e4-9b1d-1e24a48e5729.png)

The list of navigation items should be stored as a JSON object in the settings table. 

This means creating a new [default setting](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/blob/master/core/server/data/default-settings.json) called `navigation` with the type `blog`.
It should have one default item: "Home" - pointing at the root URL, which will be stored as just `/`.

On save, the values from the interface should be serialized into a JSON object and saved via the settings API.

The JSON object needs to contained ordered name and url pairs, something like:

```
{[
    {name: 'Home', url: '/'}
]}
```

* Pressing the `+` button should add another new row / item
* Pressing the save button should save all the rows which are not blank 
* Pressing the trash icon should remove the row / item
* Drag and drop reordering is dealt with in  #4540

I think the base URL should be stripped from the start of each URL when it is stored, so that we only store relative paths (and the navigation continues to function if the URL changes). If the URL doesn't start with the base URL, then we store and use the absolute URL.
issue_labels.name: [data, ember, settings]

issue_title: If remote.connect fails to validate SSL certificate, does not throw an error
body:
I had a client trying to secure connect to a websockets server. However, the hostname and certificate had a mismatch, which caused the client to repeatedly disconnect and attempt to reconnect. rippled server logs include repeated entries that include this when the client disconnects and reconnects:
```
2014-Apr-16 18:11:00 WebSocket:ERR Error reading HTTP request. code: asio.ssl:335544539
```

It would better if ripple-lib emitted an error event rather than repeatedly trying to connect to a host with a mismatched certificate.

issue_title: book_offer doesn't support limit field
body:
The remote request book_offer doesn't support "limit" field as in standard websocket requests.
It is a very useful feature that lowers the work for the server and reduces wait time of that call, so it should be supported.

issue_title: Cant find the correct webview context
body:
Hi all,

I have a pretty complex mobile-app with 2 webviews, where one of them has angular embedded and the other doesn't.

When calling wdBrowser.contexts I get an array which looks like that:  [ 'NATIVE_APP', 'WEBVIEW_1', 'WEBVIEW_5' ]

Most of the times contexts[1] is the angular embedded one, but when it is not my automation tests fail because of the requirement for angular.

Does anyone have a workaround for changing the context to the angular embedded webview in 100% of the times?

I tried to inspect the webview's url the after choosing it, but non angular webview throws an exception when using getCurrentUrl() : 'Error while waiting for Protractor to sync with the page'

Thanks in advance for your help

issue_title: Swagger UI Description allows HTML Injection (XSS by Design)
body:
Hi, I was trying out the Swagger UI, and I noticed that the ```swagger.apiInfo.description``` value allows HTML, which could lead to an XSS injection (if that ```description``` string is maliciously manipulated) Here is a unit test that replicates this issue (in Coffee-Script): ```coffee QA_NWR_API = require './TM-QA-NWR-API' app = require '../../app' describe.only 'swagger', -> page = QA_NWR_API.create(before, after) url = 'http://localhost:8002/' server = null before (done)-> server = app.listen(8002); url.append('docs').GET (html)-> html.assert_Is_String() done() after -> server.close() url.GET (html)-> assert_Is_Null(html) done() it 'Issue - Swagger UI Description allows HTML Injection (XSS by Design)', (done)-> dynamicText = 'jQuery Injection - '.add_5_Random_Letters() javascript = "$(function() { $('#target').html('#{dynamicText}')})" app.swagger.apiInfo.description = "Description element allows:

...

" page.chrome.open url + 'docs', ()-> page.html (html,$)-> $('#target').html().assert_Is(dynamicText) done() ``` ... as executed in WebStorm: ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/656739/5754748/d4d33f60-9c94-11e4-85bd-96dd351089c3.png) It looks like this is 'by design' since for example the [swagger-node-express](https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-node-express/blob/master/sample-application/app.js) takes advantage of this 'feature' to add a link to its description: https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-node-express/blob/master/sample-application/app.js#L83-L90 ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/656739/5754675/e556eb08-9c93-11e4-8bf4-7b4d42d93c14.png) I don't think that this is a high risk security issue, but it would be good to either: a) add a note to the documentation (referencing this issue) with an alert to be careful with the ```swagger.apiInfo.description``` value, or b) use markdown for the description value (which will allow features like links, without the html scripting capability)

issue_title: Taking screenshot breaks layout
body:
I've been trying out html2canvas for the last couple of days, I'd originally installed it via Bower so had 0.4.1 running. On discovery of a bug with :before elements I manually set Bower to fetch master.

Now when I make a screenshot, my current page loses styles, and my screenshot has much bigger rendering issues than it did in 0.4.1 - I'm screenshotting a SPA so the markup is vast and not easily readable, but I've attached some screenshots:

DOM before screenshotting:
![screen shot 2015-01-15 at 10 10 42](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1395013/5755660/2035740a-9c9f-11e4-831b-f0251e3d9b35.png)

![screen shot 2015-01-15 at 10 11 21](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1395013/5755668/3ae04686-9c9f-11e4-8a11-4b2762821c60.png)

Any ideas why my existing DOM elements are being affected ?

issue_title: Failed at the sharp@0.8.3 install script.
body:
Hi @Couto, I believe the problem you've run into is that yesteday's 1.5.1 release of nan is more strict about 64 to 32 bit Integer conversion.

I've fixed this via https://github.com/lovell/sharp/commit/eefd471674e2a4869e80478da929d5af5677d8b7 on the intake branch. Please can you try:
```
npm install lovell/sharp#intake
```

issue_title: Taking screenshot breaks layout
body:
And after even more investigation it seems to be caused by document.replaceChild and document.adoptNode causing the original DOM to lose style context, some :before and :after nodes would be lost because the CSS that created them was no longer present, even though the <head> remains unchanged.

I've created a workaround by just appending the outerHTML of the cloned document : https://github.com/cloakedninjas/html2canvas/commit/0bfd4a4e1fc92f15ec96a77e38de28729d9548e9

I'll leave this issue closed because I was unable to replicate the issue in JSfiddle, but this might be useful to others in the future.

issue_title: How to integrate with jwt based authentication?
body: It may be an issue with the spec itself. Based on http://oauth.net/documentation, it looks like JWT is an extension of OAuth2, though I'm not sure how it comes in to play. It looks like it can be integrated with the implicit (bearer) flow, which is already supported by Swagger, but I'm not sure whether that requires any additional extensions.

issue_title: map.sourceContent option ignored unless map.inline:true
body:
**Expected behavior**: setting `map.sourceContent: false` doesn't generate `sourcesContent` in source map
**Observed behavior**: `map.sourceContent` only affects the source map file when `map.inline: true`, but the inline source map still contains `sourcesContent`

This is harmful because the `sourcesContent` output breaks variable linking.

---

I noticed that with grunt-autoprefixer running, cmd-clicking a value set by a variable no longer linked to the variable definition, and instead linked to the rule. After experimenting with various settings, I found that the sourcesContent property in the source map file seems incompatible with Chrome's variable linking. 

I set map.sourceContent:false, and found that grunt-autoprefixer was still generating source maps with sourcesContent. The only time sourcesContent seemed to work was when inline source maps were generated, which still contain the sourcesContent, and still break Chromes variable linking.

issue_title: Navigation URL default value (base URL preview)
body:
This is part of the Navigation epic: #4535
----

This issue covers the rules of what the default value for the URL field should be, and how it should behave, for each item in the Navigation UI:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/120485/5228785/917b5448-7717-11e4-9b1d-1e24a48e5729.png)

Entering a relative URL will be very common, so to make this easier, the base url should be provided as a default url, rather than as a placeholder. It should follow these rules:

* By default, the value should be the blog's base URL (including subdirectory)
* if value === base url, set the colour like a placeholder, else colour is black like a value 
* on focus, the colour is always black like a value
* if value === base url on click/focus always puts the cursor at the end
* if value === base url, and cursor is at the end, pressing backspace should delete the whole url
* if value === null on focus-out then the base url should be re-inserted

This should make it easy to add a relative URL, and to clear the field to enter an external url.

In future, it'd be great to add autocomplete / suggestions to this input ;)
issue_labels.name: [ember, settings]

issue_title: Generated post URL from title should replace @ with dash
body:
> The issue is, as I see it, where symbols are used to separate words without spaces. Usually, there would be spaces as well as the symbol, and the spaces would end up being collapsed down into a single dash.
>
> So the question becomes what symbols, like the @ sign, are likely to be used without spaces as word separators, as opposed to being used as prefixes and suffixes that don't require the concept of a space.
> ...
> If we de-duplicate and trim away leading/trailing dashes, then we can probably replace most characters with a dash, rather than removing it and the question becomes which characters can't we do that for - to which the answer is 'any character which could appear in the middle of a word' - i.e basically just '

This is a fantastic summary @ErisDS! Thanks.

@claydiffrient My real-world cases are quite limited to the following:
- phonegap-cli@4.1.2 `/phonegap-cli-4-1-2/`
- PhoneGap Vancouver Meetup @ 7:30pm `/phonegap-vancouver-meetup-7-30pm/`

This boils down to `- @ . :` as the special characters that I use. The `:` could become a `-` or simply removed. However, I prefer @ErisDS's simple and predictable approach over building special characters for certain characters because you can't satisfy everyone :)

@claydiffrient While I'm unfamiliar with the Ghost code-base, commit f354a1b looks clean, well written, and complete to @ErisDS's outline. Nice work!

issue_title: Check all users when generating slug
body:
No Issue
- Set 'status: all` when calling generateSlug from the user model
  so that all user slugs are checked for duplicates instead of
  only active users.

Error can be reproduced by inviting a user (`user@example.com`) and then inviting another user that shares the same local-part with the first user's email address (e.g., `user@example.net`).  Currently only "active" user slugs are checked for duplicates, so both users will end up with the same slug and the second invitation will cause an error.

issue_title: BrowserStack timeouts on OS X
body:
I've noticed that even with latest Karma versions (like 0.12.31) BrowserStack is disconnecting when running browsers on OS X. With Firefox/Chrome it's easy enough to switch to Windows, not so much with Safari.

After e-mail exchanges with the BrowserStack team it turned out the old socket.io version is the culprit. I see @vojtajina already has a [WIP branch](https://github.com/vojtajina/karma/tree/socketio_10) with newer socket.io version but I didn't see any issue to track these BrowserStack issues so I'm creating this one.

BTW, I can't run this WIP branch in my project as we rely on Node 0.11.14 and the version from the branch doesn't have fixes making it work in this Node versions (those fixes are included in newest released Karma versions).

issue_title: io.js support
body: I agree with with @domenic said, its true that it would be quite a hassle for all cli based programs that depend on node to add such an option.

Issue: https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/issues/1220

May be we can continue there.

issue_title: Bug:
body:
### Issue Summary
`contentPath` and `themePath` are different in production and development mode when Ghost installed as npm module.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `npm install ghost`
2. index.js
```javascript
/*
Ghost 0.5.8 installed as npm module

Command:
 NODE_ENV=development node index

Result (expected):
 config.paths.contentPath = /path/to/project-root/content/
 config.paths.themePath = /path/to/project-root/content/themes
 
Command:
 NODE_ENV=production node index

Result (unexpected!):
 config.paths.contentPath = /path/to/project-root/node_modules/ghost/content
 config.paths.themePath = /path/to/project-root/node_modules/ghost/content/themes
 
 */

var path = require('path');
var ghost = require('ghost');

ghost({
    config: path.join(__dirname, 'config.js'),
    contentPath: path.join(__dirname, 'content')
}).then(function (ghostServer) {
    
    console.log ('Current mode is ' + process.env.NODE_ENV);
    
    // contentPath and themePath are different in production and development mode!
    console.log('config.paths.contentPath = ' + ghostServer.config.paths.contentPath);
    console.log('config.paths.themePath = ' + ghostServer.config.paths.themePath);
    
    ghostServer.start();
});
```
Run `NODE_ENV=development node index`. Result:
```
Current mode is development
config.paths.contentPath = /path/to/project-root/content/
config.paths.themePath = /path/to/project-root/content/themes 
```

Run `NODE_ENV=production node index`. Result (unexpected):
```
Current mode is production
config.paths.contentPath = /path/to/project-root/node_modules/ghost/content
config.paths.themePath = /path/to/project-root/node_modules/ghost/content/themes
```

### Technical details

* Ghost Version: 0.5.8 (as in npm install)
* Client OS: OS X 10.10.1
* Server OS: OS X 10.10.1
* Node Version: 0.10.33
* Browser: n/a
* Database: sqlite (default)

issue_title: Add support for io.js
body:
> What is the status of Travis CI supporting io.js

Support for io.js needs to land in nvm before it can be used on Travis-CI.

Extending what @jgable said, io.js is (obviously) really new, and there's going to have to be a bit of lag while tooling catches up and the dust settles.  At the point when we can easily install it we'll be able to give it a shakedown and see what kind of issues we have with our dependencies, ES6 feature conflicts, etc.

issue_title: Client mode virtually unusable in real world
body:
There are two big design mistakes (IMO) in the implementation of the client mode:

1. `.compile()` returns a function, not a string
   - I cannot think of any occasion that returning a client function in function form would ever be helpful. All tests for client mode uses a `.toString()`.
   - Jade returns a string.
2. The current API does not allow changing the function name of the output function, making it impossible to have more than one functions in a webpage without manual `var thisIsTheNameIWant = eval(str)`
   - This is extremely awkward for users who want to embed their function string in a HTML `data-` attribute.
   - Jade fixes this making `options.name` represent the name of the function.
   - Currently the output function is called `anonymous()`, which is plain stupid (Jade uses `template()`).

Both of these points cannot be done without breaking backward compat.
issue_labels.name: [bug, enhancement]

issue_title: turf.nearest for linestrings
body:
For when I want to find the closest gas station to the *stretch of freeway* where I'll likely be low on gas.

This is better than doing turf.nearest on a single point, for two reasons:
- I care less about *where* the station is, as long as it's not too far out of my way. I don't mind going a couple more exits before turning off.

- Turf.nearest on a road is likely to return nearer results than on a point, because it's a larger search area.

issue_title: update nodemailer to v1.x ?
Issue parsing '//' string literal
body:
This line does not parse correctly with this library, instead it throws the error "Unexpected identifier":
```js
<% var root = location.protocol + '//' + location.host %>
```
Current workaround is to replace the '//' string constant with an escaped '\/\/' (or '/' + '/' also works). I suspect that the global double-slash search-and-replace comment stripping at [ejs.js#L471](https://github.com/mde/ejs/blob/master/lib/ejs.js#L471) is not considering this edge case properly.

issue_title: Using insecure Urls despite forceAdminURL being set
body:
This comment considers the near-identical logic which appears in these three places:

```
core/server/api/authentication.js:49:                var baseUrl = config.forceAdminSSL ? (config.urlSSL || config.url) : config.url,
core/server/api/users.js:48:        var baseUrl = config.forceAdminSSL ? (config.urlSSL || config.url) : config.url;
core/server/api/mail.js:88:                siteUrl: config.forceAdminSSL ? (config.urlSSL || config.url) : config.url
```

In all cases, if `forceAdminSSL` is set but `urlSSL` is not, an insecure Url will be used, when the configuration option clearly requested to force SSL. 

Why not update the validation of `config.forceAdminSSL` to require that  `config.urlSSL` also be set if `config.forceAdminSSL` is set?  Then all three locations above could be simplified to definitely  use `config.urlSSL`  when `config.forceAdminSSL` is set, instead of returning an insecure Url when the config requested that secure one be forced.

issue_title: Client mode virtually unusable in real world
body:
There are two big design mistakes (IMO) in the implementation of the client mode:

1. `.compile()` returns a function, not a string
   - I cannot think of any occasion that returning a client function in function form would ever be helpful. All tests for client mode uses a `.toString()`.
   - Jade returns a string.
2. The current API does not allow changing the function name of the output function, making it impossible to have more than one functions in a webpage without manual `var thisIsTheNameIWant = eval(str)`
   - This is extremely awkward for users who want to embed their function string in a HTML `data-` attribute.
   - Jade fixes this making `options.name` represent the name of the function.
   - Currently the output function is called `anonymous()`, which is plain stupid (Jade uses `template()`).

Both of these points cannot be done without breaking backward compat.
issue_labels.name: [enhancement]

body: Interpolation reminds me of single-variable interpolation inside a string or a heredoc. I've seen this referred to in other places as "expressions" -- which isn't much more descriptive. Could we just use "escaped/unescaped output"?
Kinda nit-picky, but I don't think the unescaped output (<%-) tag is necessary for the preprocessor style.
I don't know. I just copied from a test.

Using "scriptlet" here might be kind of misleading or confusing. You explicitly *have* to use output tags (likely unescaped) to get the results to show in the rendered output. It's really just a built-in helper function.
There are no tests for this yet, but I believe the top-level vars are available throughout -- it just mixes the next set of locals onto them, so you can override or enhance.
True. Will fix.
Is this for the docs, or the library? This might be confusing to readers.
Might be good to include an item here for the license.

@mde said:
> Could we just use "escaped/unescaped output"?

In other places I called "output" the output HTML, so ...

Jade calls it "buffered code" which isn't any more descriptive.

Handlebars calls it "expression" but at the same time uses the word for loops and conditionals too.

Mustache calls it "variable," which in EJS's case might be ambiguous as we can have variables in scriptlets too.

Angular.js calls it "binding," which I think is the most viable of all.
For the license of ejs?

issue_title: Fork scaffolding logic into yeoman generator
body:
Let assume that all migration logic are moved to a separate package to easily create grunt/gulp plugins (#5). But there is also need help with generation configs/models/migrations etc. For example, there is a `generate` script in the RoR world. Scaffolding is out of the tasks related logic there. Most of js developers already use task runner, some part of them is using yeoman generators. Having a third different tool that combines task related and scaffolding logic can make things slightly confusing.

For example, generator could provide the following (assume it named `generator sequelize`):

- this will ask where to store configs, models, migrations and create a structure based on answers:

```bash
yo sequelize
```

- this will create config at the specified location:

```bash
yo sequelize:config
```

and so on. What does you think about that?

issue_title: Error on init
body:
I am running sequelize-cli v0.3.3. When I call `node_modules/.bin/sequelize init` I get the following error:

    /home/postal/Dropbox/Area51/MyProj/node_modules/sequelize-cli/node_modules/gulp/node_modules/liftoff/index.js:141
        throw new Error('You must provide a callback function.');
              ^
    Error: You must provide a callback function.
        at Liftoff.launch (/home/postal/Dropbox/Area51/MyProj/node_modules/sequelize-cli/node_modules/gulp/node_modules/liftoff/index.js:141:11)
        at Object.<anonymous> (/home/postal/Dropbox/Area51/MyProj/node_modules/sequelize-cli/node_modules/gulp/bin/gulp.js:26:5)
        at Module._compile (module.js:456:26)
        at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:474:10)
        at Module.load (module.js:356:32)
        at Function.Module._load (module.js:312:12)
        at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:497:10)
        at startup (node.js:119:16)
        at node.js:901:3

I'm actually not a fan of cargo-culting the "threequal," just using it everywhere just as a best-practice because people like Crockford say you should. IMO there's no reason to use triple-equal unless you really want specific object equality. I do use it in a few places (with zero, for instance) just because JSLint/JSHint complains if you don't. But threequal is almost never necessary, and using the it is often an indication the the programmer doesn't understand the difference between double- and triple-equal, and when you'd use which one, and why. I'd really like to revert this commit unless there's some specific reason we need it.

issue_title: No warning when an option flag is meaningless during migration
body: This is no issue with the CLI. It could be part of the sequelize core, but this might be a major change in general.

issue_title: No warning when an option flag is meaningless during migration
body:
E.g.

```coffeescript
module.exports =
  up: (migration, DataTypes, done) ->
    migration.createTable tableName, {
      date:
      users:
        type: DataTypes.INTEGER
        allowNull: false
    }, {
      comment: "Table comment."
      meaninglessOptionFlag: true # CLI should warn user about this
    }
```

Related: https://github.com/sequelize/doc/issues/156

body:
You can, but:

1. Consistency. `grep` shows that there were 5 `===`'s and 7 `!==`'s, compared to 5 `==`'s and 1 `!=`.
2. jsPerf shows that it's faster. Of course you can argue that it's cargoculting and useless microoptimization but that is one of the factors.

I don't particular care about what Crockford preaches or what linters say anyway (I don't use a linter). And yes, the `===`'s are not "necessary" *per se*. So do what you'd like to.

And just in case you were wondering, I am one of the 2% who actually know the difference ;)
I'm not sure why it includes the slash, unless it's implementation-specific. This function originated with use in the browser. This is definitely way cleaner.

Consistency is good -- but some of the inconsistency is either from satisfying the linter, or copy-pasta in the rush to implement the missing v1 features. (And of course there are a few places where you need actual object equality.) I'd generally prefer to use it only where needed.

I'm less interested in micro-optimizations especially in libraries which will be used in multiple JS implementations, over a long period of time. Granted, this isn't bending over backward to tweak the perf numbers in one specific engine, but I put a priority on just writing good, idiomatic JavaScript, as long as it's reasonably performant.

Your changes to the escape function are a great example of something I had done in a really dumb way, and was having a big, obvious impact on perf. That's the kind of stuff I worry about.

FWIW, linters *do* catch some of the stupid stuff I do sometimes, so I think they're useful. :)

I had no doubt you know the difference -- it made me curious, seeing you make this change. I'd like to revert it, and make it a loose policy to avoid the threequal unless there's a specific reason for it. Thanks for the understanding!
Great improvement here. I kinda hate chaining, but what I was doing there with instantiating RegExp over and over was really stupid. NIce work.

issue_title: Feature: Navigation
body:
Hi there, just thought I'd share my view on post, pages & navigation structures from working with different content management systems for over ten years.

A lot of other platforms make the visual distinction between **navigation** and the actual **content** like you're proposing here. One downside with it is that it cripples the publishing flow somewhat since most of the time you're first "writing content", and the "attching it" to a structure. In other words you're transforming a simple task into a two-step process.

Also, for the person writing the content, the only point of separating the navigation structure from the pages is if it's possible to create several navigation structures and publish the same page in several of them at the same time.

A simpler way to present this to the user would maybe be to create a new view called Pages/Site/Whatever where the navigation structure is shown. Here users can create "pages" of different kinds, for example:

* Content page (post with `page=1`)
* Tag archive
* Internal link (i.e to another post)
* External link

When the user creates a new entry the new post is created together with the navigation item in a single transaction, making it seemless for the user and turning it into a single step. If this kind of view was created, then maybe it would also be logical to filter out posts with `page=1` from the post list.

In other words, the same underlying structure could be used, it's just presented in a different way.

Btw, I really love the project!

Regards
issue_labels.name: [css, ember, epic, feature, ghost-ui, settings]

issue_title: Fixes #4435, also refactors checkSSL to be unit-tested.
body:
I started with the commit already in #4435:
   https://github.com/JoshWillik/Ghost/commit/c77bed6c97c2301a4f930ffd31f516fa340dd296

I rebased it on to master to make sure it still applied cleanly, which it does.

I checked for test coverage of the related checkSSL middleware and found no unit tests,
presumably because of the dependencies on `config`, `req` and `res`.

I added a commit which is purely a refactor which moves most of `checkSSL` into
a unit-testable routine and added several unit tests for it.

Since the routine was not tested, I moved it from the middleware/index.js to
middleware/middleware.js as the docs say that the later is the location for
unit-testable middleware.

The two commits are *not* squashed because they are clearer as two: the former
shows the logic change, the latter is a refactor.

There some functional testing in `test/functional/routes/admin_test.js`
which confirms the refactor doesn't break anything.

issue_title: Fix time-zone related test failures.
body:
Before this patch, I was getting a test failure like this:

    AssertionError: expected 1419008400000 to equal 1418990400000

The two numbers above represent timestamps in the epoch format that are exactly
5 hours apart from each other-- the difference from laptop's native time zone
compared to UTC.

After explicitly setting the time zone to UTC, the tests pass as expected.

This issue may not manifest itself on Travis, or Vagrant Linux VMs on Mac,
which may already be natively running in UTC.

The patch only affects the tests running and doesn't affect the time zone
setting for the running application.

issue_title: Post Preview Links
body:
Another way of implementing this (slightly more complex) is to add a new "reviewer" role to the admin. You could then add users that you want to review your unpublished content, send them the link to your page with some form of flag (i.e `?mode=preview` or something) and force them to log in before viewing the preview.

The downside to this approach would of course be that it would take more effort to send a one-time preview link to a person that you might not send a preview to again.

The main issue we're going to have with adding the constraint now, is that the code doesn't prevent duplicates, so there may be duplicates in the database already. I'm not sure how we can fix that so that the constraint can be added :anguished: 

Adding an `order` integer to `posts_tags` would also be good as we could start to work towards outputting tags in the order they were added to the post, and allowing that to be re-organised.

issue_title: [Discussion] Use knex.migrations & knex.seed instead of our migration system?
body:
When Ghost first started out, bookshelf/knex had no solution for migrating the database through versions, so we built our own. 

There are some really nice things about our migration system, in fact someone proposed [knex steal it](https://github.com/tgriesser/knex/issues/127). 

### Ghost Migrations

Our migrations work by us modifying the `schema.js` file, and updating the databaseVersion number in `default-settings.json`. When Ghost starts, it checks the number in `default-settings.json` against the local database version, and if number in Ghost is higher it knows it needs to perform some migrations.

It then runs a comparison between the local database and `schema.js`, figures out what has changed, and generates the alter table and alter column statements to update the database. That means that when we release a new version of Ghost, if the database version number changes, then when a user upgrades the migrations will automatically run. 

Sometimes if you're on master (especially if you're a developer) you can get stuck because the database version number changes in one commit, and one of the `schema.js` updates doesn't happen until a later commit. The workaround for this is to start Ghost with a `FORCE_MIGRATION=true` env var. This forces Ghost to compare the local database with `schema.js` and then generate and run any migrations that are required.

It all works pretty neatly, and the REALLY nice thing about it is that it is all based on a big JSON object that describes the database, which is useful for other aspects of models and validations.

### The Downside(s)...

There are a few downsides to our migration system. One big one is having to maintain it - knex doesn't yet fully support all the possible alter operations that you might want to do on a database, so as it adds more options, we need to add them to the possible statements that can be generated by our system.

More importantly, Ghost's migration system focuses 100% on the database structure, and has no provision for modifying the data in the database. In systems like ActiveRecord, migrations often contain data modifications as well, useful for doing things like changing default values.

Ghost has a [fixtures system](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/tree/master/core/server/data/fixtures) which is totally separate, and is little more than some hard-coded functions which detect if migrations are going through a database version and therefore need to adjust some data. Deep within this, are the [permissions fixtures](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/tree/master/core/server/data/fixtures/permissions), which are woefully lacking in any sort of [migration capability](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/issues/3910) and this is holding us up from adding new permissions.

Meanwhile, Knex has added its own [migration system](http://knexjs.org/#Migrations) based on ActiveRecord and more recently added the concept of [seed files](http://knexjs.org/#Seeds-CLI). 

**So the big question: is the system in Knex now more sophisticated than ours, will it solve our fixtures problems, as well as other [migration issues](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/issues/4687#issuecomment-70423880) and should we switch?**
issue_labels.name: [data]

issue_title: Post Preview Links
body:
I don't think I'd(*personally*) opt for the "reviewer" role method, as I feel it ads a bit more complexity to the workflow; I would not be adding additional users to my blog just to take a sneak peak at one of my posts.

It might have some valid use cases in the online magazine industry or when it comes to journalists, but in those cases the users reviewing the content would probably have other roles like "editor" within the system anyway.

My personal take is having an extra step in the workflow which users could choose to skip if they wanted: 'draft' => '**preview**' => 'published'

All draft posts = 100% private - login required
All preview posts = visible to users who know the unique UUID based URL
All published posts = 100% public - no login required, post appears in the sitemap.

I believe that this is to do with the importer tests failing. This problem is due to an oversight on my part -the new importer updates are designed to support importing markdown files from Roon - and because both Roon & Ghost(Pro) run in UTC, I overlooked the need to ensure that this was enforced in the tests.

I suspect that setting process.env.TZ is not the correct fix for this, but there may be something further that has been overlooked - hence the request for more information.

Author writes post, enables preview mode, reviewers are then able to comment on the posts or sections within the post, spot typos etc and provide feedback. The Author can then action these comments prior to publishing.

issue_title: Post Preview Links
body:
Authentication for "preview" URLs could probably be enabled/disabled as a labs feature.

So the code could ship with "preview" requires authentication(secure by default) or it could be shipped as "preview" does not require authentication(visible by default) and allow the users to adjust this as a global setting.

I don't think I'd go so far as to say each post should have "public preview" or "private preview".

Although, it could be that we have the three post states and the author can invite people do be "contributors". (using contribute as "comment" should probably be reserved for what readers would do once it's published).

Then if the contributor get's an invite they would need to sign up and create an account.

They would only be able to contribute to posts they were invited to contribute to, so it would be:

* does user have permission to contribute to this post?
* does user have the UUID based URL to access the post in the first place?
   * if yes to both => allow contribution

This workflow might be better suited to a plugin/app though, as it could start to get super complex in terms of variations and options also the "contributions" received would need to be channelled to the author in a logical way that make it easy to process and action.

issue_title: Fix time-zone related test failures.
body:
Thanks for the additional information :smile: 

Setting aside the issue of whether or not it's safe/reliable to set `TZ` in a currently running node process, what you're doing is only in effect when grunt is running the test suites.  In a "real" instance of Ghost, `TZ` won't be set and the importer will convert the date string from the filename into a value based on the local timezone, and we could end up with unexpected datetime values in other parts of the system.

I don't disagree with the sentiment that everyone should be running server processes in UTC but I'm not sure that hijacking `TZ` is the best route (for us, at least).  Someone running Ghost may have other code running alongside it and have the reasonable expectation that having properly set `TZ` outside of node, that the setting will be honored as is standard behavior.

issue_title: Assume datetime in import filename is UTC
body:
> Is it safe to assume to the date-time in the file name is in UTC?

It is.  The markdown importer was built to handle files generated by the https://roon.io/ exporter, which creates those files with a UTC-based datetime.

Absent building in support for reading offset out of the filename, dealing in UTC seems to be the most sane way forward.

issue_title: Fix time-zone related test failures.
body:
@jaswilli, thanks for the reply.

> what you're doing is only in effect when grunt is running the test suites.

That was intent. Like the practice using specific fixture data for
tests, setting a specific time zone for tests give you reliable and
consistent baseline time-zone for the tests.

> In a "real" instance of Ghost, TZ won't be set and the importer will
> convert the date string from the filename into a value based on the
> local timezone, and we could end up with unexpected datetime values in
> other parts of the system.

True. From what I saw of the related import ticket, there was a not a
spec yet for how to interpret the time data in Markdown file names.
Expecting that data to be UTC would certainly be convenient, as there's
not a place in the markdown import spec currently to convey time zone
data.

> I don't disagree with the sentiment that everyone should be running
> server processes in UTC but I'm not sure that hijacking TZ is the best
> route (for us, at least). Someone running Ghost may have other code
> running alongside it and have the reasonable expectation that having
> properly set TZ outside of node, that the setting will be honored as is
> standard behavior.

As I understand, `grunt test-unit` (and other test invocations) start
their own node process, run tests and shuts down the process. Any
`process.env.TZ` value set within would apply only to that process and
expire with the process exits at the end of the test run. I don't see
any side-effect of this affecting a running Ghost server, which is not
the same node process as any of the `grunt test` commands.

I was only striving to help the test suite run consistently in different
time zones, since it was failing in the Eastern time zone for me.

issue_title: Fix time-zone related test failures.
body:
> As I understand, grunt test-unit (and other test invocations) start
> their own node process, run tests and shuts down the process. Any
> process.env.TZ value set within would apply only to that process and
> expire with the process exits at the end of the test run. I don't see
> any side-effect of this affecting a running Ghost server, which is not
> the same node process as any of the grunt test commands.

Yes, that's correct.  I was speaking in terms of fixing this issue entirely, which would require setting `TZ` not only when running the tests, but also when a regular instance of Ghost is running.

If you only manipulate `TZ` to get the test suite to pass, then you've effectively masked a bug that will surface in production.

issue_title: Fix time-zone related test failures.
body:
In this case, the test was apparently /intended/ to run in UTC and explicitly setting UTC fixed that test. 

If you want to explicitly test importing data from another time zone, then a test should explicitly set a specific time zone and then test for the specific offset from UTC.

Not controlling the time zone of tests is prone to producing unexpected results as just happened.  I've made the mistake before of letting tests run in the random environment of users before with similar failures as I recently found.

You can continue to discover time-zone related test suite bugs by waiting for the suite to be run in different zones, but I think setting UTC as a default for the test suite and explicitly testing for time-zone offsets when necessary will both avoid the unexpected failures like today as well as providing coverage for time-zone related issues.

issue_title: Wish: Better diagnostics when unsupported NODE_ENV is set
body:
If `NODE_ENV` happens to already be set to an unsupported value, several `grunt` command will fail to work, with no indication of what the problem is. This could happen to potential contributors who checking out the project, but happen to have a different `NODE_ENV` value already set via `.bashrc`. (That was my case). 

Here's what the failure looks like:

```
$ grunt express:dev
Running "express:dev" (express) task
Starting background Express server
Stopping Express server
```

You you can try explicitly setting `NODE_ENV=boom` to see what happens.

Ideally a diagnostic would be printed in this case like `NODE_ENV=boom` is not supported.`

issue_title: Fix time-zone related test failures.
body:
There might be some merit in attempting to get the test suites to always run in a predetermined timezone but I'd have to spend some more time thinking about it.

The issue in this specific instance, as I see it, is that the importer is applying an offset to epoch time based on the local timezone (if set), but that offset isn't being recorded anywhere.  In the future when that datetime value is pulled out of the database there's no way to tell that an offset was already applied.

If we were forcing the tests to be run in an arbitrary timezone, the tests would pass but we wouldn't have discovered the issue with the importer and then we'd be hitting the bug in production instead of in testing. That's why I'm hesitant about forcing a timezone.

issue_title: Bug: `contentPath` and `themePath` are different in production and development mode
body:
### Issue Summary
`contentPath` and `themePath` are different in production and development mode when Ghost installed as npm module.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `npm install ghost`
2. index.js
```javascript
/*
Ghost 0.5.8 installed as npm module

Command:
 NODE_ENV=development node index

Result (expected):
 config.paths.contentPath = /path/to/project-root/content/
 config.paths.themePath = /path/to/project-root/content/themes
 
Command:
 NODE_ENV=production node index

Result (unexpected!):
 config.paths.contentPath = /path/to/project-root/node_modules/ghost/content
 config.paths.themePath = /path/to/project-root/node_modules/ghost/content/themes
 
 */

var path = require('path');
var ghost = require('ghost');

ghost({
    config: path.join(__dirname, 'config.js'),
    contentPath: path.join(__dirname, 'content')
}).then(function (ghostServer) {
    
    console.log ('Current mode is ' + process.env.NODE_ENV);
    
    // contentPath and themePath are different in production and development mode!
    console.log('config.paths.contentPath = ' + ghostServer.config.paths.contentPath);
    console.log('config.paths.themePath = ' + ghostServer.config.paths.themePath);
    
    ghostServer.start();
});
```
Run `NODE_ENV=development node index`. Result:
```
Current mode is development
config.paths.contentPath = /path/to/project-root/content/
config.paths.themePath = /path/to/project-root/content/themes 
```

Run `NODE_ENV=production node index`. Result (unexpected):
```
Current mode is production
config.paths.contentPath = /path/to/project-root/node_modules/ghost/content
config.paths.themePath = /path/to/project-root/node_modules/ghost/content/themes
```

### Technical details

* Ghost Version: 0.5.8 (as in npm install)
* Client OS: OS X 10.10.1
* Server OS: OS X 10.10.1
* Node Version: 0.10.33
* Browser: n/a
* Database: sqlite (default)
