issue_title: Named regex parameter substitution fails
body:
We are using named parameters with a regex pattern, and the substitution fails.

In attached example, the parameters are defined as:
`GET /{year:[\d]{4}}-{month:[\d]{2}}-{day:[\d]{2}}`
when filling in the parameters, this results in the following URL:
`https://localhost:10891/2014}-01}-01}`
with one superfluous curly bracket still there.

issue_title: Named regex parameter substitution fails
body: ![parametersubstitution](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1526633/5799084/7d57159e-9fce-11e4-969e-2a3fe9b4b8bc.png)

issue_title: Named regex parameter substitution fails
body:
Swagger does not support such a declaration for path templates. Each part that's surrounded with curly braces is considered a parameter, and the regex within it is irrelevant.

Swagger 2.0 supports the `pattern` property which allows you to limit the value to a certain regex, but it is not yet implemented in the UI. There's going to be a PR soon (community contribution) that will display the required pattern, but the PR to allow validation of it will take a bit longer.

issue_title: Bug: Enforced trailing slash causes issues with Facebook social plugins when migrating.
body:
### Issue Summary
Facebook treats URLs with or without trailing slash as separate URLs. This causes a series of issues with the Facebook Scraper including the Likes counter being reset to 0 when migrating from a blogging platform that does not enforce trailing slashes on blog posts. Redirecting from a URL without a trailing slash to one with a trailing slash does not solve the issue either because Facebook follows all redirects and only looks at the canonical URL of the final destination. Due to this, migrating from other blogging platforms with social plugins is a non-option in some cases.

### Steps to Reproduce
Set up a blog with the platform of your choice and publish a post without a trailing slash. "Like" the post on Facebook. Migrate to Ghost (use CloudFlare or the likes to set up your custom URL). Check your "Like" counter on the blog post on Ghost. It will be 0 because of the trailing /.

issue_title: Adds slashes to urls
body: This causes a series of issues with Facebook when migrating from URLs without a trailing slash (e.g. a Drupal driven Blog).

issue_title: Named regex parameter substitution fails
body: Validation is not needed here, the server will do that. The issue is with constructing the URL, it trips over the nested pair of curly brackets. I did see #831, is that the PR you are referencing and would that fix the construction of the URL?

issue_title: Named regex parameter substitution fails
body: No, it's not related to #831. The problem with constructing the URL is that your spec is invalid. Your path can't be defined as `/{year:[\d]{4}}-{month:[\d]{2}}-{day:[\d]{2}}`, it has to be defined as `/{year}-{month}-{day}`

issue_title: audit use of `parseInt`
body:
There seem to be many places in the code where `parseInt` is used where `parseFloat` might be considered more appropriate/correct. This can result in certain rounding errors and blurry renders, as mentioned in, for example, #340 ([relevant comment](/niklasvh/html2canvas/issues/340#issuecomment-70265757)).

It should also be noted that, according to [the spec(s)](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/number), pixel (and most other length/position/dimension/number) values can be floating point numbers, so any regular expressions used to parse numbers values should probably also be audited to ensure they're checking for a possible decimal part, where appropriate.

issue_title: Named regex parameter substitution fails
body:
Is it invalid for swagger-ui, as it's valid spec for the runtime.

We're using RestEasy, which has regular expression support in the @Path (see [their docs](http://docs.jboss.org/resteasy/docs/1.1.GA/userguide/html/Using__Path_and__GET___POST__etc..html)). It's also mentioned in the [JAX-RS 1.0 specs](https://wikis.oracle.com/display/Jersey/Overview+of+JAX-RS+1.0+Features).

For now, we can remove the regex so at least the swagger integration doesn't break as that's confusing for the user, but it seems like a valid feature of the @Path parameter.

At least, thanks for the quick response!

issue_title: Named regex parameter substitution fails
body:
It is invalid for the spec. Just because JAX-RS allows it, doesn't mean Swagger allows it. 

At the moment, we do not allow specifying regex as part of the template itself, but as said, in Swagger 2.0 you can specify the regex as part of the parameter *definition*.

What you're describing is a possible bug with swagger-core as it should replace the regex with the path parameter definition (not necessarily an easy match and switch). Feel free to open an issue on swagger-core about it.

issue_title: Bug: Enforced trailing slash causes issues with Facebook social plugins when migrating.
body:
OK - I think that is a slight misunderstanding, I was trying to get the person who comment to properly raise an issue if one existed - it wasn't at all clear from the comment what he meant - a quick check my end found no obvious issue with the scraper and trailing slashes. 

I really don't consider the issue raised here to be a bug in Ghost, as I don't think it is doing anything incorrectly - the URLs are valid and consistent, the canonical URL and structured data is reported correctly and enforcing a slash is a sane thing to do for consistency. There's an automatic 301 from the non-slashed to slashed version of every URL, which solves URL problems in the majority of cases.

Raising a feature request to allow the slashes to be turned off is one course of action, but the amount of work required to make it possible is significant given the size of the underlying problem, and I'm not 100% that having the option is desirable. Further, it is a global change to your blog to solve a migration issue, which doesn't really make sense as it isn't a solution to the migration problem. There are other platforms you might migrate from, like tumblr, which can have IDs in the URL that Ghost is not able to maintain, and therefore the URL is forced to change. 

Therefore the correct course of action is to find a way to solve the problem of migrating URLs.

What is needed, is have a way to tell sharing services that the resource they are looking at is one-and-the-same as the resource they have data for. I think this can be done at least for facebook by setting the og:url to the old post. There are ways to do this for other services as well.

It is quite possible (although awkward) to resolve the issue by making modifications to the theme and/or adding extra things to the content of each post. Having a native way to resolve this would be great - it will certainly be very easy with apps and probably one of the first apps it'd be possible to build. 

I'm going to ping @cobbspur here as he's got a lot of experience of migrating blogs and solving these issues. Perhaps we can come up with a plan, whether it requires apps, or an external tool to modify the imported posts, etc - and then look at solving it that way.

issue_title: Border radius not capped
body:
Its possible to apply a "too high" border radius to elements, that is being capped by all browsers if its above a value that makes sense.

For example: You have a container that is 200x200px of size and you want to make it a perfect square. The correct border radius would be 100px - everything above won't work.

However, its a common case that people will use values much higher - mostly when you don't know exactly how the dimensions of the applied image will be. The browser automatically caps the border radius on the highest possible even value - html2canvas doesnt do that, what leads to strange effects.

Demo of the effect: http://jsfiddle.net/gmz0wnwr/

issue_title: Bug: Enforced trailing slash causes issues with Facebook social plugins when migrating.
body:
> I really don't consider the issue raised here to be a bug in Ghost, as I don't think it is doing anything incorrectly - the URLs are valid and consistent, the canonical URL and structured data is reported correctly and enforcing a slash is a sane thing to do for consistency. There's an automatic 301 from the non-slashed to slashed version of every URL, which solves URL problems in the majority of cases.

I full heartedly agree. I am not saying that Ghost is at fault here in terms of how it handles the URL. It's just an unfortunate problem that arises due to the differences with the former platform. There isn't really a global consensus on the meaning of trailing slashes. Some say it means that the URL is a directory. But there is no actual standard afaik. However, I am not objecting to the idea of having trailing slashes on all URLs.

> What is needed, is have a way to tell sharing services that the resource they are looking at is one-and-the-same as the resource they have data for. I think this can be done at least for facebook by setting the og:url to the old post. There are ways to do this for other services as well.

Sadly, as I understand it (I also tried it with no luck) this is not possible. It might have been a caching issue with Facebook so I can try that again but I think I also hit the refresh button on the URL Scraper Debugger over at Facebook when trying it.

Facebook seems to be the most ignorant of the common services. Twitter has no issue with the 301 redirects at all and correctly identifies the resulting blog post URL as the same as it was before.

Thanks for your time and the thorough answer. Looking forward to hear from @cobbspur :)

issue_title: Error during `npm install sharp`
body:
I should start off by saying a lot of this falls outside my area of expertise, so I might be incorrectly opening an issue for something that isn’t relevant to this library. Not 100% sure.

When I try to install sharp via npm, I get the following errors:
```
npm WARN package.json node-uuid@1.2.0 No repository field.

> sharp@0.6.2 install /Users/gscottolson/test
> node-gyp rebuild

  CXX(target) Release/obj.target/sharp/src/sharp.o
../src/sharp.cc:119:22: error: use of undeclared identifier 'VIPS_ANGLE_0'; did you mean 'VIPS_ANGLE_D0'?
  VipsAngle rotate = VIPS_ANGLE_0;
                     ^~~~~~~~~~~~
                     VIPS_ANGLE_D0
/usr/local/Cellar/vips/7.42.1/include/vips/conversion.h:65:2: note: 'VIPS_ANGLE_D0' declared here
        VIPS_ANGLE_D0,
        ^
../src/sharp.cc:124:18: error: use of undeclared identifier 'VIPS_ANGLE_90'
        rotate = VIPS_ANGLE_90;
                 ^
../src/sharp.cc:126:18: error: use of undeclared identifier 'VIPS_ANGLE_180'; did you mean
      'VIPS_ANGLE_D180'?
        rotate = VIPS_ANGLE_180;
                 ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~
                 VIPS_ANGLE_D180
/usr/local/Cellar/vips/7.42.1/include/vips/conversion.h:67:2: note: 'VIPS_ANGLE_D180' declared here
        VIPS_ANGLE_D180,
        ^
../src/sharp.cc:128:18: error: use of undeclared identifier 'VIPS_ANGLE_270'; did you mean
      'VIPS_ANGLE_D270'?
        rotate = VIPS_ANGLE_270;
                 ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~
                 VIPS_ANGLE_D270
```

At some point, the variables `VIPS_ANGLE_180` were renamed to `VIPS_ANGLE_D180`:
https://github.com/jcupitt/libvips/commit/154796a8dc091ad545b6d56896b47e324c1471ab

Is this a version incompatibility with the `libvips` package? Is there an easy way to resolve this?

issue_title: Error during `npm install sharp`
body:
Yes, as you spotted, the libvips API for angles changed slightly in 7.42.0.

v0.7.0+ of sharp has the https://github.com/lovell/sharp/commit/46f229e308da94074b6aeaa69b0a9a790ff6c0a2 fix, which allows it to work with versions of libvips before and after this.

If you're going to upgrade libvips and therefore upgrade sharp from v0.6.2, I recommend taking it all the way to the latest v0.8.4 to pick up changes that improved colour/profile handling and image quality.

issue_title: Using insecure Urls despite forceAdminURL being set
body:
But if `forceAdminSSL` is set, a redirect will be issued in the event that a request comes in on a non-https link.  The "forcing" of SSL isn't necessarily by way of providing an SSL URL, it's in forcing the connection itself to be SSL.

I believe the intended use for `urlSSL` is if the secure URL differs from the non-secure URL, e.g., `http://my-ghost-blog.com/` vs. `https://secure.my-ghost-blog.com/`.  If the only difference is in the protocol, a standard redirect will suffice and `urlSSL` isn't needed.

I'm going to close this but if anyone has more to add feel free to do so and I'm happy to re-open.

issue_title: Using insecure Urls despite forceAdminURL being set
body:
This comment considers the near-identical logic which appears in these three places:

```
core/server/api/authentication.js:49:                var baseUrl = config.forceAdminSSL ? (config.urlSSL || config.url) : config.url,
core/server/api/users.js:48:        var baseUrl = config.forceAdminSSL ? (config.urlSSL || config.url) : config.url;
core/server/api/mail.js:88:                siteUrl: config.forceAdminSSL ? (config.urlSSL || config.url) : config.url
```

In all cases, if `forceAdminSSL` is set but `urlSSL` is not, an insecure Url will be used, when the configuration option clearly requested to force SSL. 

Why not update the validation of `config.forceAdminSSL` to require that  `config.urlSSL` also be set if `config.forceAdminSSL` is set?  Then all three locations above could be simplified to definitely  use `config.urlSSL`  when `config.forceAdminSSL` is set, instead of returning an insecure Url when the config requested that secure one be forced.

issue_title: Wish: Better diagnostics when unsupported NODE_ENV is set
body:
Agreed.

The code to output an error in this situation is actually already in place.  I think it stopped working at some point as a result of a side-effect in how the error logging module is configured, combined with some refactoring of the Ghost bootstrapping process.

The error handling in the bootstrap process as well as the filtering in those logging methods should probably given a once-over to fix up issues like this.

issue_title: IE9 re-executes all external scripts again on document.documentElement.cloneNode(true)
body:
For some reason IE9 decides to re-download and execute all scripts again on `Node.cloneNode(true)`. While the scripts are [already stripped](https://github.com/niklasvh/html2canvas/blob/master/src/core.js#L171) to avoid them getting re-executed before appending them to the cloned window, IE9 will need them to be stripped prior to the node being cloned.

Works as expected on IE>9.

https://saucelabs.com/tests/718465e9b0ad40579c6b999a76e7edff
issue_labels.name: [Bug]

issue_title: segmentation fault with broken jpeg
body:
It looks like the "JPEG datastream contains no image" error from libjpeg isn't correctly handled or bubbled up. This condition can be [reached](https://github.com/svn2github/libjpeg-turbo-code/blob/master/jdapimin.c#L259) when end-of-file (or Buffer in this case) occurs when reading image metadata.

An extra NULL reference check in sharp's image loading code should fix this - leave it with me - thanks for reporting.

Do you know of any IP/legal reasons that would prevent me adding the truncated/corrupted `02247503-02.jpg` file to sharp's test fixtures to prevent such a problem occurring again?

issue_title: add a way to override "anonymous" CORS
body:
Maybe via an option called `useCredentials` (which can be  `boolean` or `function(src)` or maybe `RegExp`) to specify whether or not to send credentials with CORS requests on a per-image basis? E.g., if `true`, or if the function returns `true` when passed the image url, or if the image url matches the regular expression, we do `image.crossOrigin = "use-credentials";` instead of `image.crossOrigin = "anonymous";` ? (XHR requests would also do `xhr.withCredentials = true;` in those cases.)

Use case: I use the script on a site that uses images from two different domains, one of which is a subdomain I own which requires credentials (responses to image request returns with `Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://mydomain.com` and `Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true` headers) and the other which isn't/doesn't.

Thoughts?

issue_title: Cannot read property 'pageOrigin' of undefined
Allow rendering invisible HTML fragments
body:
I would like to use html2canvas as a HTML renderer to HTML5 canvas (I have a HTML5 canvas app but want to show some popup menus to the user which would best be expressed as HTML elements).

So I would pass an HTML String or an invisible element, and get back the canvas which I can hopefully then getImageData() and then putImageData() wherever I want.

The following issue appears related:
https://github.com/niklasvh/html2canvas/issues/107

However, using visibility:hidden (+ hack the code) doesn't work well because elements still take up space, and flickering is also not good.

I appreciate this is not the 'raison d'être' for this library, and perhaps isn't technically feasible, so I will fully understand if this issue gets closed, but if you have any ideas how to peruse a part of html2canvas code to do this, it would be appreciated.

issue_title: Allow rendering invisible HTML fragments
body: As described in #107, it isn't possible. html2canvas relies on the browser to calculate the area for the element to be able to render it, and it requires it to not have `display: none`

body: Any reason for making `*` and `-` all `+`? They are recognized by markdown and there for a reason: 11dfabc621a8684a5fa3feadd003d2687e52509d

Ugh, sorry. I should have taken a closer look -- but from the language of each item, it wasn't clear to me it had been added on purpose. I was scratching my head trying to remember if I'd just done it inconsistently originally.

I've always relied on the language of the various item to determine what it did (new feature, removed feature, changed behavior, bugfix, improvement, etc.), not on sigils for addition/removal/modification to code. But if you think it's useful and there's an existing convention for it, let's keep it.

Apologies, and I'll revert my commit. :)

Haha no problem. It probably took you a while to fix all the `*` and `-`'s anyway. Sorry about that. I like having these symbols as they allow downstream to see *immediately* what changed and if they need to worry about it. Say if a release is all `+` then probably no.

issue_title: spurious segmentation fault
body:
Thanks for the useful backtrace Bernhard.
```
...
#3 0x00007fbf454a32fd in jpeg_finish_decompress (cinfo=cinfo@entry=0x7fbf1c2552a0) at jdapimin.c:387
#4  0x00007f3de59a5ea8 in readjpeg_free (jpeg=0x7f3dc4294c70) at jpeg2vips.c:198
...
#379 0x00007f3de59ccd3e in vips_cache_trim () at cache.c:713
...
```
The inclusion of `vips_cache_trim` suggests libvips is doing a cache eviction. The mention of `jpeg_finish_decompress` means it's trying to remove a JPEG-backed image object that failed to complete decompression.

https://github.com/jcupitt/libvips/blob/master/libvips/foreign/jpeg2vips.c#L194-L198

@jcupitt Would you expect this object be present in the cache in this state?

issue_title: spurious segmentation fault
body:
Assuming this is vips 7.42, I think that's OK. jpeg_finish_decompress() is only called from readjpeg_free(), and readjpeg_free() is only called from a ::close callback. This is the only path for a shutdown of the reader, and you would expect it to come here during cache eviction.

Could this be jpeg reading from a memory buffer? If it is, it could be trying to shut down a reader attached to a memory buffer that has been freed. Could node have trashed the input buffer for some reason?

I think the rule is, if you call:

```C
int
vips_jpegload_buffer( void *buf, size_t len, VipsImage **out, ... )
```

`out` now owns the memory buffer. You must not free that buffer until `out` emits ::close.

Actually, it's stricter, I think. The jpeg reader will shut down on out::close, so the memory buffer must stay alive until out::postclose, since you don't know in what order ::close handlers will fire.
issue_labels.name: [triage]

issue_title: spurious segmentation fault
body: yes, it's 7.42

issue_title: spurious segmentation fault
body:
I wondered why it was reading the input during close. I skim-read libjpeg and all jpeg_finish_decompress() does is verify the last few bytes in the file and raise an error if they're wrong. I think we can live without that, so I removed the call. It doesn't leak, jpeg_destroy(), which we still call, frees resources.

Of course, node will still need to not free the buffer until ::postclose.
issue_labels.name: [bug]

issue_title: Swagger fails to create proper request ui when hosted NOT under root directory
body:
Hi guys,

Here is input information

1) I'm using Swagger for Spray (https://github.com/gettyimages/spray-swagger)
2) Servlet root for my service is `/api` (and that's causes problems I think)
3) Here is how I initialize Swagger servlet
```scala
  val swaggerService = new SwaggerHttpService {
    override def apiTypes = Seq(typeOf[AuthenticateSwagger])
    override def apiVersion = "2.0"
    override def baseUrl = "/api" // let swagger-ui determine the host and port
    override def docsPath = "api-docs" // This path is ignored by swagger-ui. There is hardcoded one in index.html
    override def actorRefFactory = context
    override def apiInfo = Some(new ApiInfo("Innotas API", "Documentation on RESTful JSON-based Innotas API", null, null, null, null))
```

Therefore Swagger json is located at `/api/api-docs` and Swagger UI at `/api/swagger/`

Now when I attempt to make request using UI it fails because Swagger-UI calls

`/api/api/authenticate`

for the sake of experiment I changed value in `baseUrl` which shockingly made requests look like

`/api2/authenticate`

I'm not familiar witj JavaScript but why would Swagger behave like that ? I couldn't find such comparison in the code (something like where it compares portions of URI).

Thanks.

issue_title: Swagger fails to create proper request ui when hosted NOT under root directory
body: As far as I know, spray-swagger uses Swagger 1.2, and Swagger 1.2 simply does not support relative URLs for the `baseUrl` property. You have to use the full path if you want it to work properly.

issue_title: Swagger fails to create proper request ui when hosted NOT under root directory
body:
What version exactly would you recommend to uses ? spray-swagger uses 1.3.

Also on maven I see only this
http://mvnrepository.com/artifact/com.wordnik/swagger-core_2.11/1.3.12

issue_title: Swagger fails to create proper request ui when hosted NOT under root directory
body:
1.3 is the version of swagger-core. I know it's a bit confusing.

swagger-core 1.3 produces Swagger 1.2 docs.
swagger-core 1.5 (which is currently under development and there's no stable version yet) produces Swagger 2.0 docs, and I'm not sure spray-swagger can use that. In fact, as far as I know, spray-swagger build its own docs and uses only the annotations from swagger-core. If you want to check about its ability to produce 2.0 spec, I'd suggest opening an issue on their repository.

issue_title: Transfer of route paths from hard-code to config
body:
Hi @katiefenn :)

Reading back through the issue, I see that I wasn't clear on my intentions with this refactor. The idea was to rip out the english words from the routes: the words `tag`, `author`, `page`, and `feed` which a user might wish to change either to a different thing (like genre instead of tag) or to translate - as opposed to ripping out all of the routes and making them customisable.

The idea in the end is that there will be a setting where I can change 'tag' to 'genre' or similar, but for now, there was no need to make them configurable, just doing the hard part of ensuring the routes always work. 

The big difference between putting something in our config (in which case @halfdan's comment about keeping them internally rather than in the example file is correct) vs a setting, is that a setting can be changed on-the-fly, whereas config requires a restart of Ghost. So with config you can guarantee that the strings are loaded before the routes, but with a setting you can't.

I'm not 100% which route we'd go down here - I think changing the word for a tag is likely to want to be a setting, and I have no idea how translations will be loaded.

That was the reason for leaving this refactor at the point where the strings are refactored out into an internal place, so at least changing them is done in one place - because there are other places than just the routes where those strings are hard-coded E.g: https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/blob/master/core/server/config/url.js#L125

issue_title: Navigation menu drag & drop
body:
We generally support the last 2 versions of major browsers, so IE10+ (the rest update automatically or new versions have a majority market share, so a non-issue). [Can I Use](http://caniuse.com/#feat=dragndrop) says no mobile browser supports native drag & drop events, so they'll need a polyfill. I would imagine most polyfills aim to support as many browsers and devices as possible.

I think keeping it as close-to-the-metal as possible would be best, and likely the easiest to integrate with Ember? Native drag & drop (with a polyfill) makes sense to me.
issue_labels.name: [beginner, ember, settings]

issue_title: Bug: Footnote Markdown Syntax Inside Code Ticks Showing HTML
body:
The problem here is that the footnotes code only extracts `pre` blocks before doing it's thing. 

See [ghostfootnotes.js#L81](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/blob/master/core/shared/lib/showdown/extensions/ghostfootnotes.js#L81)

Other extensions like highlights extract both `code` and `pre` blocks: 

- [ghosthighlight.js#L25](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/blob/master/core/shared/lib/showdown/extensions/ghosthighlight.js#L25)
- [ghostgfm.js#L47](https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/blob/master/core/shared/lib/showdown/extensions/ghostgfm.js#L47)

Fixing this issue requires adding the code block extraction and replacement to footnotes and adding tests to check that it's working the way we expect now.

issue_title: Navigation URL default value (base URL preview)
body:
This is part of the Navigation epic: #4535

----

This issue covers the rules of what the default value for the URL field should be, and how it should behave, for each item in the Navigation UI:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/120485/5228785/917b5448-7717-11e4-9b1d-1e24a48e5729.png)

Entering a relative URL will be very common, so to make this easier, the base url should be provided as a default url, rather than as a placeholder. It should follow these rules:

* By default, the value should be the blog's base URL (including subdirectory)
* if value === base url, set the colour like a placeholder, else colour is black like a value 
* on focus, the colour is always black like a value
* if value === base url on click/focus always puts the cursor at the end
* if value === base url, and cursor is at the end, pressing backspace should delete the whole url
* if value === null on focus-out then the base url should be re-inserted

This should make it easy to add a relative URL, and to clear the field to enter an external url.

In future, it'd be great to add autocomplete / suggestions to this input ;)

issue_title: Inside onPrepare forking new browser instances throwing an error 100
body:
Are you sure that is working? You've never reassigned `element` to global so it's always using the original browser. 

Anyway, even if you assign element like you did with browser, it only works because you're not using the browsers in parallel. So yes it will work for this case, but once you start mixing the browser, your test will break. 

Consider:
```
it ('test', function() {
  browser = browser.a
  element = browser.a.element
  element(by.xyz).getText().then(function(text) {if (text === 'abc') {element(by.abc).click()});  
  browser = browser.b
  element = browser.b.element
})
```

Now `element(by.xyz)` will work against browser1 but `element(by.abc)` will work against browser2 because your assignment is synchronous while promises are async. You will understand what I'm saying once you start working with this.
issue_labels.name: [needs: more info, type: bug]

issue_title: $$ should be listed under "element.all(locator)" instead of "element(locator)"
body:
`$$` is a shortcut for `element.all(by.css(...))`, not generic `element.all`.

This is slightly confusing, but those entries in the docs are actually describing the fact that you can chain element with $.

`element(by.id('foo')).$('.myclass')`
or
`element(by.id('foo')).$$('.myclaass')`

So it makes sense that they're listed under `element`. What we probably should do is highlight the exported globals (`$`, `$$`, `browser`, `element`, etc) in the docs somewhere).

issue_title: POST formData not working
body:
I'm trying to send a simple string as a POST parameter in swagger 2.0. However, I cannot seem to get it to work.

````
    post:
      summary: POST simple parameter
      description: Test
      consumes:
        - application/x-www-form-urlencoded
      parameters:
            name: _method
            in: formData
            type: string
            required: true
            description: testing
````

When I view a log of the $_POST details in my PHP server, the array is empty. It should contain the "_method" parameter. 

Please note that this was found as a bug in the swagger-editor here: https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-editor/issues/299

I have found the same problem in the swagger-ui. Perhaps I'm missing something?

issue_title: MonitoredItem on changed not fired
Inconsistent behavior on undefined object property reference
body:
Minimal test:
```js
eval(require('ejs').compile('<%- data.test %>'))({data:{}});
```
In ejs <=1.0.0, this returns `''` (empty string).
In ejs 2.x, this returns `'undefined'`.

This breaks some existing templates, so unless there's an intentional reason to make this breaking change (and it's clearly documented), I would like to see consistency with the <=1.0.0 behavior.

issue_title: doxme readmes
body: @tmcw agree, this should be 100% generated from the jsdocs.
issue_labels.name: [docs]

issue_title: Inconsistent behavior on undefined object property reference
body:
(BTW you don't need the `eval()`)

Will fix.

issue_title: Inconsistent behavior on undefined object property reference
body:
Technically this is a breaking change. @mde what do you think?

To fix this, I would need to make EJS output templates like one of these:

1. EJS 1 style:

   ```js
var buf = []
[...]
;buf.push(data.test)
[...]
;return buf.join('')
```

2. Ternary operator:

   ```js
var __output = ''
[...]
;__output += (data.test) == null ? '' : data.test
[...]
;return __output
```

I'll do some benchmark on these.

issue_title: Inconsistent behavior on undefined object property reference
body: Now I read more and more EJS 1 code, I really think it's fairly reusable as EJS v2. The OO stuff and expensive regex matching is really dragging the compilation speed down. EJS v1 depends purely on `indexOf` which, believe it or not, is *fast*.

issue_title: Inconsistent behavior on undefined object property reference
body:
Minimal test:
```js
require('ejs').render('<%- data.test %>', {data:{}})
```
In ejs <=1.0.0, this returns `''` (empty string).
In ejs 2.x, this returns `'undefined'`.

This breaks some existing templates, so unless there's an intentional reason to make this breaking change (and it's clearly documented), I would like to see consistency with the <=1.0.0 behavior.

issue_title: options found in locals object. The option(s) is copied to the option object. This behavior is deprecated and will be removed in EJS 3
options found in locals object. The option(s) is copied to the option object. This behavior is deprecated and will be removed in EJS 3
body:
It is not deprecated, but you are putting locals in the options object. *That* is deprecated.

If you are using express, there is no workaroudn right now.

If you are calling ejs directly, split locals and options into two objects and call `render(str, locals, options)` or `renderFile(str, locals, options, fn)` or `compile(str, options)(locals)`.

issue_title: New Navigation Helper
body:
@ErisDS a few small questions, the template above suggests ```handlebars
  • {{label}}
    • ``` but it seems like the class the li's class should probably be `nav-{{labelSlug}}` where `labelSlug ~= generateSlug(label)` since the class *probably* doesn't need the same uniqueness guarantees as post slugs do (since it's prefixed by `nav-`, would it be fine to implement a simple slugify() for labelSlug which looks like `label.toLowerCase().replace(/[^\w ]+/g,'').replace(/ +/g,'-')`? This seems like a fast enough transform that i'm guessing it's fine to leave as a computed property in the {{navigation}} helper and not worth storing in when creating the navigationItems in the first place. my other question: is something like `{{current}}` implemented right now in some other part of the codebase? it feels like something that might be problematic to reimplement.

issue_title: Karma times out on Travis/SL because IE9 is never started (Angular.js build)
body:
I'm a Sauce Labs employee, investigating the same issue for a customer.

Something weird seems to be going on;  When I watched one of the tests with video turned on (By adding the line `recordVideo: true` to the `sauceLabs` object in my config) the Karma header never updated from 'Karma - starting', but the list of browsers and browser activity did.

From https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/blob/v0.12.31/client/updater.js#L22 it appears that, once a connection has been made, the status should have been updated.

But, the list of browsers is updated when an 'info' event is emitted: https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/blob/v0.12.31/client/updater.js#L27

(Both of these were in `karma.js` which I assume is compiled from everything in the `client` directory?)

So I'm a little confused how we could simultaneously not be connected, and receiving events from the server.  I'd think it was just the `StatusUpdater` being naughty but you were saying you're not seeing a console log of the socket ever connecting.

In a local install of Karma I added the `connecting` and `connect_failed` events to try to track more precisely what was going on.  Unfortunately I can't get the problem to reproduce.  I've cloned Angular's repo and am currently trying to get it running tests in the hope it'll fail consistently, so I can have at it more savagely.

Disclaimer:  I'm mostly a Ruby dude, I don't have the JS-fu so might just be missing something obvious.

issue_title: Deprecation notice when rendering with valid data and no options
body:
You cannot export a `__express` property on your module if you're going to yell at everyone. Exporting an `__express` property means you're agreeing to support the defined interface of `__express`, which is to mix locals and options.

It's like someone came by asking if you could help them as long as you did it their way (i.e. Express checks for `require('your_module').__express`) and you agreed you would (because you defined a function there), but then whenever they asked for help (called `__express()`), you yelled at them that you won't do it their way.

issue_title: Add a work around for express users for the deprecation notice.
body:
>> Would also be lovely if it were possible to display the message with the depd module

> Nice self-advertising ;)

haha. I don't like to do that, but really there is no other contenders on the deprecation message front. I thought out it because I was trying to upgrade a CLI to the newest `ejs` and I got that warning, but had no idea which of my dozens of calls to `renderFile` caused it, since there's no location data. I eventually figured it out and then ran the script again and the message was still there, apparently from yet another call.

I had to make the `depd` module to have a sane experience correcting code as a consumer of a deprecated API (since all the other deprecation modules on `npm` didn't provide it). The main thing is that module will not work in web browsers and it has no desire to, which is why I mentioned the stuff about the dependency management (if you cannot depend on non-browser deps, then clearly it's a moot point :) ).

issue_title: add support for multiple Text Shadows
body:
2)  The dx value is needed as an offset so the shadow is separated from the text (it should push the text out of bounds, while the shadow stays in place). This is because in canvas context there is no way to create a shadow of a certain color without also creating text of the same color. While in CSS you can specify multiple text-shadows, so in canvas context you need an offset so only the shadows (not the text itself) are visible. This point is valid in all cases unless you have one shadow on fully opaque text.

3) Nope, it's only the shadow being rendered to the visible portion of the screen. The text color must be 100% opaque or it will be multiplied against the shadow. It doesn't matter what color as long as it's opaque, so I just chose #000.

I'll try to get back to you with an update soon. I'm reading up on qunit/mocha and looking into how tests are setup (new to me).

btw, "grunt test" command on the homepage docs is returning "Task "test" not found."

issue_title: MonitoredItem on changed not fired
body:
After investigation I found that the server send a ServiceFault message with Bad_Timeout Error in place of each expected Publish responses. as started in the spec (Spec 1.02 part 4 page 81 5.13.2.2 Function DequeuePublishReq())
the server will dequeue the PublishRequest in first-in first-out order and will validate if the publish request is still valid by checking the timeoutHint in the RequestHeader. If the request timed out, the server will send a Bad_Timeout service result for the request and de-queue another publish request.
In Part 4. page 144 Request Header the timeoutHint is described this way timeoutHint UInt32
This timeout in milliseconds is used in the Client side Communication Stack to set the timeout on a per-call base. For a Server this timeout is only a hint and can be used to cancel long running operations to free resources. If the Server detects a timeout, he can cancel the operation by sending the Service result Bad_Timeout. The Server should wait at minimum the timeout after he received the request before cancelling the operation. The value of 0 indicates no timeout.
Node-opcua uses timeoutHint=0 in the requestHeader by default. In our case , the server doesn't consider a timeout=0 means no timeout as per the spec. This is clearly a bug on the server side, that you might want to report to the vendor. Anyway, I have put a workaround in the code, that should fix the issue. please confirm.

issue_title: Can it support the video tag and take  a screenshot?
body:
Once a video is loaded, videos are handled the same as images in regards to drawing onto a canvas. 

Since HTML2Canvas creates a new frame to render all pages, you'd need to clone the video, wait for "oncanplaythrough" to be fired, transfer over the currentTime on the video, and then you could draw to the canvas.  You would want to look at imagecontainer.js and imageloader.js for reference in /src/

As far as rendering the actual controls of the video/audio (as per brcontainer's issue), they'd need to be manually drawn, which seems out of specs for this project.

issue_title: spurious segmentation fault
body:
Based on John's suggestion, the latest code on the `intake` branch now waits for the `postclose` signal emitted by libvips before deleting the (copy of the) input buffer.

It also now correctly notifies the V8 garbage collector of the memory allocation, which means garbage collection should run in a more timely manner, with less danger of hitting swap for long-running processes.

I've run the leak tests and everything seems OK on Node 0.10 stable, but it currently segfaults on Node 0.11 unstable. The latter uses completely different memory allocation logic for Buffers so I need to do more triage/testing.
issue_labels.name: [bug]

issue_title: CanvasRenderer.variables & save/restore state
body:
I'm noticing that the CanvasRenderer.variables are not being tracked properly with save/restore states. How would you prefer to fix this: (a) make this.variables into an array for tracking states, and pop/push when save/restore is run. (b) tap into native tracking of variables—e.g.: use "if (this.ctx[property] !== value) {" instead of "if (this.variables[property] !== value) {" in CanvasRenderer.prototype.setVariable I think option (b) would be easier, and you don't have to worry about things as much. I did a jsperf on the performance gains of using this.variables, and it's negligible on 1,000,000 checks. This will fix issues with shadow not rendering properly in certain cases, such as this:
Giant blue lobsters!!!

For instance on line 13:
```javascript

```
definition['enum'] should be used instead of definition.enum or enum should be renamed to something else.

issue_title: Audit uses of Promise's `.then`, add rejection callbacks when useful
body:
There are currently many instances in the code where of `.then` is being called on a Promise without passing a second handler for the rejection case. This can result in cases where there is a silent failure.

I would recommend adding basic rejection handlers in these cases, which can simply log the rejection reason, and possibly handle any cleanup that might be necessary on a case by case basis. There could even be a default rejection handler as an option.

issue_title: request: `it.todo`
body:
### Use case:
- tests that can't be yet implemented, but should be. 
- 'remind' the author, be grepabble.

### benefit
- more literate programming.
- "todo" lives in the code.

### why not use  `it.skip`.
- like `it.skip` should 'orange' a bug tracking / code review board.
- `it.skip` should be reserved for "commenting" out tests (during an active session). 
- `it.todo` is more forceful / intentional.  



### Costs to implement
- more readme, docs work.
- yet another state, that all reporters must know about.  (only if `todo` is a new state, per proposal 2 following).

### possible implementations
1. alias `todo` to `it.skip`, which preserves the distinction in the code, even if 
2. new function `todo` that can be logged in reporters as distinct from pending.

issue_title: spurious segmentation fault
body:
I've found liborc <0.4.20 segfaults and <0.4.22 leaks.

The Node 0.11 unstable segfault was related to the V8 notifications of memory (de)allocation. The version of V8 used by Node 0.11 requires you to know which "Isolate" VM should be notified.

I'm going to remove the V8 notification code as its use is optional, it only helps the GC when memory is really tight and the multi-threaded nature of how to solve the problem makes my head hurt.

issue_title: Use of reserved javascript words as properties leads to IE errors
body:
Yes, but the swagger team should chose the solution:

1. Rename the properties (for instance enum -> enumValues, default -> defaultValue, in -> location)
This may be the cleanest solution but this means breaking the api backward compatibility, modifying the spec, the examples etc... a huge work (I would not do it myself)

2. Change the way to access every properties.
I would personally not chose this solution, it's a bit risky and less readable I think

3. Change the way to access only the impacted properties.
This is the quicker and safer way but not very nice to read as it will introduce inconsistency in the code like this:
```javascript
      param.allowableValues = {};
      param.isList = true;
      param.['enum'] = ["true", "false"];
```

issue_title: Use of reserved javascript words as properties leads to IE errors

issue_title: IE9 login screen blank page, JavaScript error: replaceState
body: Hi @RicSwirrl, As far as I know it isn't required directly by Ember, but is required because Ghost uses Ember's [history API feature](http://emberjs.com/guides/routing/specifying-the-location-api/) to have urls rather than hashes in the admin panel. Ghost is not expected to support IE9, I'm afraid I don't think this can be worked around and I'd wager that even if it could, you'd likely face much bigger problems once this one was solved.

issue_title: Template generated from JSON schema does not contain nested fields
body:
Hello.  
swagger-ui seems to have an issue generating templates for JSON schemas that have nested fields. The following snippets show the reference to the JSON schema and the schema itself. The screen capture at the bottom shows the template generated by swagger-ui.  Thank you.

paths:
  /phonebookDisplay:
    put:
      tags:
        - phonebook
      description: display an entry in the phonebook
      operationId: phonebookDisplay
      parameters:
        - name: input
          in: body
          description: input
          required: true
          schema:
            $ref: "#/definitions/IVTNO_INPUT_MSG"

definitions:
  IVTNO_INPUT_MSG:
    required:   
      - INPUT_MSG  
    properties: 
      INPUT_MSG:
        type: object
        properties:
          IN_FIRST_NAME:
            maxLength: 10
            type: string
          IN_LAST_NAME:
            maxLength: 10
            type: string
          IN_EXTENSION:
            maxLength: 10
            type: string
          IN_ZIPCODE:
            maxLength: 7
            type: string

issue_title: Add checks to make sure that NODE_ENV corresponds to config key.
body:
Also checks that required keys are found in the configuration.

In production, issues warning is mail is not configured.

Resolves #4825.

This is an alternative to an open pull request targeting the same issue:
https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/pull/4835

The #4835 approach supported only 'development' and 'production' environments.

This approach supports any environment that has a matching key present in config.js,
and also goes further to check that the configuration contains the required keys.

The 'mail' key is treated exceptionally, since it is not configured for the
development and test and environments out of the box. A warning is issued if 'mail.transport'
is not set in production, but the server won't be stopped from starting up.

Another comment implied that it was valid for config.js to be completely
missing and that remains supporteed as well.

issue_title: Error: Unknown authentication strategy
elementexplorer INFO level logging low SNR; how to turn off?
body:
Most of this is coming from the selenium standalone server using the same stdout as the tests. We should indeed have some way to configure this.

A quick fix that you can use now is to start up the selenium standalone in a separate process (either calling it yourself or via `webdriver-manager start`) and connect to it using `seleniumAddress` from a config or the command line (e.g. `--seleniumAddress http://localhost:4444/wd/hub`).

issue_title: Add checks to make sure that NODE_ENV corresponds to config key.
body:
hey @markstos, thanks for this :)

One of the things that Ghost 'tries' to do, is provide exceptional error messages, so we are always keen to resolve issues like the one you described where there was no error - it really doesn't fit with the kind of experience we want users of Ghost to have.

You'll see elsewhere in the startup checks file that Ghost uses a 3-part error message pattern, where the error is in red, some context follows in white, and a hint at what to do or where to go for the answer in green. It would be great if you could expand your messages to follow this.

The config and mail checks seem to me to perhaps be duplicating checks that we already have elsewhere in the application - here's the config validation: https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/blob/master/core/server/config/index.js#L310

And here's the mail validation:
https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/blob/d2d9e4aea242cec0ca39749a3fe55ce15e16c879/core/server/index.js#L106

It may well be that these things need improving to show better error messages, and the mail messaging is currently in the UI rather than on the console, so adding extra logging to the console seems like a good idea, I'm just a little concerned about having 2 very similar checks in different parts of the codebase.

issue_title: Cross Origin Image does not load in IE9 but works on Chrome (fiddle provided)
body:
It's not stupidity, it's just not yet learned. :]

In general, a proxy is a service running on one server that allows you to access resources that live on other servers. In html2canvas, a proxy would be used to load cross-origin images via javascript. This helps circumvent browser restrictions, namely the Same Origin Policy, because the proxy is (presumably) on your own domain, so the browser is just getting some "local" image.

For hints on implementing one, you can check out, for example, http://apidock.com/ruby/Net/HTTP. You can essentially write a controller that listens for a request with a "url" parameter, fetches the URL, and returns the content. (Note that html2canvas will only use the proxy for images.)

See some sample implementations in other languages here:
https://github.com/niklasvh/html2canvas-proxy (Python)
https://github.com/brcontainer/html2canvas-php-proxy (PHP)

Hope that helps, and feel free to open-source your result!

body:
Yes, as I mentioned in https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/issues/4825#issuecomment-70531654, the error handling is already in place for these things, it just needs some attention to address a regression.

Thanks for the quick response.  I have started the selenium server as a separate process, and I am on protractor 1.6.1 (from npm install, not from master).

@juliemr giving --seleniumAddress on the cmd to elementexplorer did the trick, thank you!  (I'm giving protractor training today. :+1:  ) But I have a bit of confusion you may be able to clear up for me.

I found that even tho I wanted to use seleniumAddress: null in my protractor.conf.js (as i'm happily using for my specs), elementexplorer could not seem to launch it, so I needed to start it myself (ele expl spat ECONNREFUSED if I had not started it). But after starting it *and* giving elementexplorer the --seleniumAddress alleviates the extra logging problem.  Q: You mention setting in a conf -- what conf is elementexplorer reading? I would like to leverage it.

Aside: There is not much doc on elementexplorer yet, but I am discovering its features and i really want to exploit its powers.  For example, I just figured out that it works as expected -- I can load my page object files with require() and hit them interactively.  Powerful stuff. Thank you.

issue_title: Error: Unknown authentication strategy
body:
Ah so you were registering a route with the 'simple' auth strategy before you had actually registered the 'simple' strategy itself, very easy to do. Thanks for posting the solution to the issue.

One thing I usually do for auth in Hapi is to create a plugin called `authentication` which register's the auth scheme plugin - hapi-auth-bearer-token in this case, and then also registers the strategy, that way each plugin has only one concern so you don't have your api plugin also responsible for authentication.

If you want to try this pattern let me know and I can elaborate more with code samples etc.

issue_title: Fix up users API so admin role can edit owner
body:
I think so but if you're on to something to make it better I'm open to it :)

Right now we check the payload to make sure it's valid, check to make sure the context user has permission to edit the user (`canThis`), and then if roles are involved we do the additional checks for roles, and then we attempt the edit.

So if we don't need to worry about roles it seems pretty straightforward:  `canThis` user edit?  -> attempt edit.

issue_title: New Navigation Helper
body:
hi, i have a quick question about where i should add the navigation items to the context of the page (in `frontend.js`). I tried it two different ways and they're both kinda messy, so i'd appreciate any feedback you have:

the first is by adding a parallel `api.settings.read('navigation')` in `getPostPage()` This then would propagate the navigation items similar to pagination via the options parameter that gets passed through to `api.posts.browse` and from there, it would then be re-extracted into the context object in `formatPageResponse()` similar to the way pagination is.

the second is by calling `api.settings.read('navigation')` from within `formatPageResponse()` and then having that return a promise. This would require changing all its callers to execute the template rendering in a `.then()` and would require altering the method to accept parameters to merge immediately.

Although the first approach feels a bit gross to me since it's a bit tangly, but it also feels less weighty than changing the semantics of the `formatPageResponse` method. I'm trying the first one and commit it and welcome any feedback on it.

issue_title: Start karma with no autorun
body:
You can put to karma.conf.js:

```js
        frameworks: ['jasmine'],
        files: [
            '*.test.js'
        ],
        autoWatch: false,
        browsers: ['PhantomJS'],
        singleRun: false
```

and then manually run tests `karma run --port=9876`

issue_title: Add randomization support
body:
## Big Fat Warning

This is a **WIP**. I just wanted to throw the idea out there and see if there's any feedback before I start writing tests and docs.

## How to use it?

The array shuffling is done with the [knuth-shuffle-seeded](https://www.npmjs.com/package/knuth-shuffle-seeded), my fork of [knuth-shuffle](https://www.npmjs.com/package/knuth-shuffle) that supports seeding.

```
mocha --randomization tests
mocha -a tests
mocha -a tests:mySeed123ee456eeed
```

```js
{
  randomizeMode: 'test'
, randomizeSeed: 'mySeed'
}
```

If your test needs to be tested in a particular order, add `noRandom`:

```js
describe.noRandom('my test', function () {
  [...]
})
```

`noRandom` plays nicely with other modifiers (although I admit the implementation is a little ugly):

```js
describe.noRandom.only()
describe.only.noRandom()
describe.noRandom.skip()
describe.skip.noRandom()
xdescribe.noRandom()
```

## Current state

Currently it only supports test-level randomization (`mode === 'tests'`), which means that only the order of tests within a suite is randomized.

## TODO

- tests
- docs
- suite-level randomization (might be added after this PR)

Fixes #902.
repo_description: mocha - simple, flexible, fun javascript test framework for node.js & the browser. (BDD, TDD, QUnit styles via interfaces)

issue_title: Sourcemaps with map.json extension doesn't seem to work with bugsnag
body:
Hi @loun4, our fetching proxy is returning an SSL error:

(71) Protocol error (TLS code: X509_V_ERR_UNABLE_TO_GET_ISSUER_CERT_LOCALLY)
SSL Certficate error: certificate issuer (CA) not known: /C=US/ST=New Jersey/L=Jersey City/O=The USERTRUST Network/CN=USERTrust RSA Certification Authority

The problem is that your web-server is missing an intermediate certificates. You certificate file for Tengine currently contains only two certificates (1. and 2.), it needs to also contain 3.

1. `Subject: OU=Domain Control Validated, OU=Gandi Standard Wildcard SSL, CN=*.ooxad.com`
1. `Subject: C=FR, ST=Paris, L=Paris, O=Gandi, CN=Gandi Standard SSL CA 2`
1. `Subject: C=US, ST=New Jersey, L=Jersey City, O=The USERTRUST Network, CN=USERTrust RSA Certification Authority`

i.e. the file should look like this:

```

issue_title: Custmer json format javascript error
Custmer json format javascript error
[TASK] Refactor to use bignumber.js
body:
While historically it seems to_text() would return '0' for native amounts that overflow, internally it sets NaN as the value_. Elsewhere we blow up when limits are exceeded. There's no comments here explaining this strange behaviour or what a future course of action to fix it might be. What are the plans for fixing up amount.js beyond using bignumber.js (which by itself doesn't really buy much)? 

In any case, this seems to be a behavioural change.
repo_description: A JavaScript API for interacting with Ripple in Node.js and the browser

issue_title: Start karma with no autorun
body:
@maksimr the current project has about 3k tests that take around 5 minutes to run, I don't want to run them on each start given that the CI is green

The answer I was looking for is to simply double the letter of the test `ddescribe` or `iit` and then when you call karma start it will only run that test.

issue_title: Start karma with no autorun
body:
Hi, 

I will love it if karma won't run all the tests at start.

issue_title: Start karma with no autorun
body:
@balauru great.

Be careful, since version of 0.3 karma-jasmine [change](https://github.com/karma-runner/karma-jasmine/commit/207018b83201b2b72cb14a8c6d528ac24d53f7a9) ddescribe on [fdescribe](http://jasmine.github.io/2.1/focused_specs.html) and iit on fit.

issue_title: spurious segmentation fault
body:
This one is probably a toughie:

I'm pulling image urls from a queue, download them and run some sharp transformations on them.
Every once in a while a get a segmentation fault like this:

https://gist.github.com/bkw/8bb899281c2c87727f46

Unfortunately I have a very hard time reproducing this. I tried processing the same images in succession but no luck. But when I go back to processing the queue, sooner or later the crash happens again.

If you have any advice how to enhance this bug report, please let me know.
issue_labels.name: [bug]

issue_title: No error message/fail when incorrect browsers specified
body:
I had been using Autoprefixer 2.0.0 with this browser config:

```
options: {
	browsers: ['last 2 version','Android 2']
},
```

However, after updating to 2.2.0 the Autoprefixer task continued without any error messages but was not processing the job (e.g. it didn't pick up the source file and write to a dest).

Could some feedback be included so that the task fails if an incorrect browsers parameter is passed?

Hi @truonguit2010,

It sounds like you either don't have your gmail credentials entered correctly, or there's something wrong with your the `mail` section in `config.js`.  Here's a link to the gmail setup:  http://support.ghost.org/mail#gmail

I'm going to close this as I don't think it's a problem with Ghost itself.

issue_title: abort trap error
body:
to be fair, i think this is a node error, like many things:

```js
> sharp('/Users/jong/Downloads/We0opiV.jpg').resize(50).toFile('test.jpg', function (){})
{ options: 
   { width: 50,
     height: -1,
     canvas: 'c',
     angle: 0,
     withoutEnlargement: false,
     sharpen: false,
     progressive: false,
     sequentialRead: false,
     quality: 80,
     compressionLevel: 6,
     output: '__jpeg',
     fileIn: '/Users/jong/Downloads/We0opiV.jpg' } }
> Assertion failed: (enter->IsFunction()), function MakeDomainCallback, file ../src/node.cc, line 1027.
Abort trap: 6
```

This is when i execute it in the REPL.
OS X 10.9.3
Node 0.11.13
issue_labels.name: [triage]

Who would trade 1 XRP for 5 XRP?

I'm not opposed to changing the behaviour of this code. In fact, I believe
it should be changed, to throw errors more liberally and consistently. It
seems senseless squandering efforts on attempting to faithfully reproduce
old quirks ( which this change set can't achieve a perfect score for
anyway, due to rounding changes ) when it could be put into defining
sensible behaviour.

The discussion is very much in scope. This a huge bunch of changes
requested to be merged, including some amounts now overflowing to zero.
This is a bad change, made worse in the context of avoiding making good
ones.

If there was concerns about the size/scope of the request, it could broken
into logical commits like the rippled guys sometimes do. Anyway, bad
changes need to be excised from this request before merging.

I think what sublimator is saying is that this change introduces _new_ behavior which is both incorrect and very dangerous - numerical overflow is handled by setting the value to 0 instead of either setting it to NaN or throwing an exception.

Correctness is of supreme importance - this is financial software, and people will be putting serious money through this - so it's _always_ a relevant issue worth bringing up if you see code that you even suspect is incorrect.

issue_title: [Feature] Controlling Content Elements' HTML Properties
body:
This is a feature request for the ghost-ui in response to [halfdan's](https://ghost.org/forum/plugins/15941-custom-post-content-adding-css-classes-onto-sections-in-blog-posts/) forum request, but more generalized.

I'd like to suggest adding a small icon next to each tag in the preview panel with an (extensible) options drop-down/modal to influence relevant/available html attributes of that tag (e.g. the class and id of all tags, target for links, etc.). Another icon on top, or next to the gear at the bottom could enable/disable this functionality, similar to the [pilcrow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pilcrow) that enables its display in word processing.

The motivation here is primarily in keeping the ability to add image placeholders (and the inherent ability to drag&drop them into the preview panel), while enabling a greater degree of customization. 
An example application would be to set certain post images to a specific class to be used in a (e.g. lightbox) gallery, while leaving others out.

As we already have interaction in the preview pane (i.e. image drag-in and the image-delete button), this would fit nicely in the existing paradigm.

issue_title: options found in locals object. The option(s) is copied to the option object. This behavior is deprecated and will be removed in EJS 3
body:
Express generators should be using "~2.1.4", which will pick up the minor version bump that fixes this problem: https://github.com/expressjs/generator/commit/3a987d261c6531c79fae4515ab5fbbb1d33fc3f0 (Of course, apps generated with the generator prior to the fix might have the old version installed.)

It doesn't replace the undefined value. All it does is *output* an empty string (that is to say, it outputs nothing) for any expression in an output-tag (<%= or <%-) whose result is `null` or `undefined`. This is the same behavior as EJS 1.x.

issue_title: fs.exists is being deprecated
body:
`fs.exists` is used a few places in the code base, but is being deprecated by [node](https://github.com/joyent/node/pull/8418) and [io.js](https://github.com/iojs/io.js/issues/103) and is not recommended by the current official [Node.js docs](http://nodejs.org/api/fs.html#fs_fs_exists_path_callback).

Alternatives include using `fs.stat` or just skipping the check, trying a file action, and handing the error if it doesn't exit.

Refactoring to avoid `fs.stat` now would provide a bit of future-proofing.

issue_title: Add support for compile-time `with()`
body:
One of the major bottlenecks in the execution of template functions is the use of `with () {}` construct, which is not even supported in JavaScript strict mode. To work around this, some (most of my performance-critical) projects use the `_with` option to disable the use of `with () {}` in template scripts and use `locals.variable` instead of `variable` in EJS files.

Recently, it has come to my attention that there is a module [`with`](https://github.com/ForbesLindesay/with) that scans the source for undeclared variables and adds a shim for it, all at compile-time. This has two major effects and one side effect:

1. compile speed is a **lot** slower
2. runtime speed is a **lot** faster
3. undeclared variables are not recognized as errors but instead resolve to `undefined`, which then resolve to the empty string

Compilation benchmark:

```
ejs v2 old x 28,709 ops/sec ±0.09% (101 runs sampled)
ejs v2 new x 1,343 ops/sec ±1.83% (96 runs sampled)
```

(21 x slower)

Template benchmark:

```
ejs v2 old x 174,356 ops/sec ±0.47% (102 runs sampled)
ejs v2 old !_with x 4,324,186 ops/sec ±0.13% (102 runs sampled)
ejs v2 new x 596,334 ops/sec ±0.42% (100 runs sampled)
ejs v2 new !_with x 4,387,799 ops/sec ±1.35% (100 runs sampled)
```

(3.4 x faster)

I am certainly against enable this by default, as the performance regression caused by it is way too big. But do people think it's worth adding an option for? Also how about implicitly enabling this option when caching is enabled?

issue_title: turf.nearest for linestrings
body:
The challenge with nearest for linestrings is that a linestring could have only 2 points, making it difficult to run nearest through each sets of coordinates in that point. I solved this problem by taking linestring and 'complexifying' it by adding points on the linestring within a certain distance of each other. Then I can search for nearest in that list of coordinates on the linestring.

I did this in rwt-to/GeoJSON-Tools (https://github.com/rwt-to/GeoJSON-Tools/commit/35abcf081fc4d13d9552ff69193236b49ee34da6), but I'm not promoting that you use the tool. I just saw Turfjs today, and if someone would like to port the 'complexify' method from GeoJSON-Tools, you're welcome to. 
We use GeoJSON-Tools internally, and there's lots of work to do, so I haven't committed anything to it in some time now.

issue_title: Errors in `startup-check.js` should exit non-zero (currently 0)
body:
When something goes badly wrong on startup, such as dependencies not being there, we should complain loudly (which we do) but we should also exit with non-zero so that whatever started Ghost knows that there was a problem.

This applies to all of `packages()`, `contentPath()` and `sqlite()` in this file: https://github.com/TryGhost/Ghost/blob/master/core/server/utils/startup-check.js

I'm happy to submit a PR if this sounds ok?

issue_title: How to set width as 100%?
body:
I was asked by one of the people who use the spreadsheets that are created by the library if I could update it to do just this.
It certainly is possible, but the solution I could think of is not great and basically involves using system tools to render the font string in order to account for font size, face and decoration and measuring that. I don't like this solution because it relies on the system which is different for different developers. I haven't found a good server-side solution in pure javascript since every solution I have found relies on the browser's DOM.
If I could find an efficient way of measuring the width of a font string in pure javascript, I would then need to find an efficient way of finding the longest string. I'm thinking it would involve separating the strings of a column into different array of different styles, finding the longest string in each array, calculating the width of each longest string and then using the longest width for the column width. This would happen during the xl.write() process. I think this would be efficient enough to not cause a significant increase in the time taken to generate the excel file that would outweigh the benefit given.
I'm going to mark this as an enhancement request. If you know of or can think of an efficient way to measure the width of a string once it has been rendered, then please let me know.

issue_title: map.sourceContent option ignored unless map.inline:true
body:
**Expected behavior**: setting `map.sourceContent: false` doesn't generate `sourcesContent` in source map
**Observed behavior**: `map.sourceContent` only affects the source map file when `map.inline: true`, but the inline source map still contains `sourcesContent`

This is harmful because the `sourcesContent` output breaks variable linking.

---

I noticed that with grunt-autoprefixer running, cmd-clicking a value set by a variable no longer linked to the variable definition, and instead linked to the rule. After experimenting with various settings, I found that the sourcesContent property in the source map file seems incompatible with Chrome's variable linking. 

I set map.sourceContent:false, and found that grunt-autoprefixer was still generating source maps with sourcesContent. The only time sourcesContent seemed to work was when inline source maps were generated, which still contain the sourcesContent, and still break Chromes variable linking.

issue_title: Bug: Meta description doesn't work inside of `{{#foreach posts}}`
body:
### Issue Summary

Right now `{{meta_description}}` returns an empty string when used inside of `{{#foreach posts}}`. On the other hand doing `{{log meta_description}}` prints the correct string to the console.

### Steps to Reproduce

This happens wherever there's a `{{#foreach posts}}`. For simplicity's sake, here are steps to reproduce this with the default theme (Casper):

1. Replace `{{excerpt ...}}` with `{{meta_description}}` in `partials/loop.hbs`
2. Visit a page with a post list (for example the frontpage) and notice the empty text instead of the post description.

I think I got a patch ready but first wanted to ask whether that's intentional or a actually bug.

### Technical details

* Ghost Version: 0.5.8

issue_title: Fix time-zone related test failures.
body:
Before this patch, I was getting a test failure like this:

    AssertionError: expected 1419008400000 to equal 1418990400000

The two numbers above represent timestamps in the epoch format that are exactly
5 hours apart from each other-- the difference from laptop's native time zone
compared to UTC.

After explicitly setting the time zone to UTC, the tests pass as expected.

This issue may not manifest itself on Travis, or Vagrant Linux VMs on Mac,
which may already be natively running in UTC.

The patch only affects the tests running and doesn't affect the time zone
setting for the running application.

issue_title: Errors in `startup-check.js` should exit non-zero (currently 0)
body:
Hi @chilts,

The reason those checks use `process.exit(0)` is to avoid the generation of long, confusing error output and stack traces from things like npm.

Because `startup-check` is checking for a class of error/misconfiguration that is likely to be encountered only by way of a mistake in setting up the environment by users who may not be very experienced, it's really helpful to not have to wade through a hundred lines of "stuff" to try and figure out what went wrong.

If you have an example of a real-world situation where Ghost exiting with a status of `0` is problematic we can discuss it and see if we can come up with a solution, but absent that I'd prefer to be pragmatic and make this class of error as easy as possible for our users to troubleshoot.

In fact, the scenario you're describing is apparently what was happening in Issue #36. I wasn't following the commentary closely, but now I see this:

@dgofman-equinix wrote:
> I am not using renderFile (only ejs.render) and still getting the same waning using v2.2.2

I this case, it might have been appropriate to say, "sorry, you're using the new API."

issue_title: Add support for compile-time `with()`
body:
One of the major bottlenecks in the execution of template functions is the use of `with () {}` construct, which is not even supported in JavaScript strict mode. To work around this, some (most of my performance-critical) projects use the `_with` option to disable the use of `with () {}` in template scripts and use `locals.variable` instead of `variable` in EJS files.

Recently, it has come to my attention that there is a module [`with`](https://github.com/ForbesLindesay/with) that scans the source for undeclared variables and adds a shim for it, all at compile-time. This has two major effects and one side effect:

1. compile speed is a **lot** slower
2. runtime speed is a **lot** faster
3. undeclared variables are not recognized as errors but instead resolve to `undefined`, which then resolve to the empty string

Compilation benchmark:

```
ejs v2 old x 28,709 ops/sec ±0.09% (101 runs sampled)
ejs v2 new x 1,343 ops/sec ±1.83% (96 runs sampled)
```

(21 x slower)

Template benchmark:

```
ejs v2 old x 160,036 ops/sec ±1.11% (100 runs sampled)
ejs v2 old !_with x 680,884 ops/sec ±0.43% (98 runs sampled)
ejs v2 new x 631,878 ops/sec ±0.40% (102 runs sampled)
ejs v2 new !_with x 675,687 ops/sec ±0.46% (100 runs sampled)
```

(395% old, 94% `!_with`)

I am certainly against enable this by default, as the performance regression caused by it is way too big. But do people think it's worth adding an option for? Also how about implicitly enabling this option when caching is enabled?

Note that the `with` module uses acorn, which might be undesirable for users using the browser to render EJS, but I can easily use a conditional to filter that out when `browserify`ing.

issue_title: Add support for compile-time `with()`
body: After thinking about this a little bit more, I guess the tradeoff is not worth it, so closing.

issue_title: End user report customization
body:
This is the highest requested feature and should be the breaking one. The main goal is to bring jsreport into the end user's browser. This means report customization will not be exclusive job for the jsreport integrator but it will give opportunity to the end users to customize invoices or what ever other report.

We will start simple in the first phase and provide just a simple report editor similar to one in jsreport studio. Later we may build a full WYSIWYG editor on the top of it.

## Concept
External web application embedding jsreport will download some jsreport init scripts first. When the user reaches a particular page or a button application triggers opening a lightweight jsreport designer. The designer will popup in the specified placeholder or in the dialog. The user should be able to preview and customize report there and save it back.

## Designer
jsreport lightweight designer could be the same as the [playground](https://playground.jsreport.net/) simplified studio. We only need to make it smaller so it fit to the placeholder.

## Security
We want to support also the scenario where jsreport is used in the multitenant environment. For this is crucial to guarantee that one tenant cannot see the templates from the other tenant and so on. This should be at least partially supported in jsreport otherwise every application needs to implement some kind of a authentication proxy in front of jsreport.

Mirroring users from another system or calling another authentication service is maybe an overhead at least for now. Let's provide security in easier way.

First, on premise version must get some kind of an admin account authentication. Admin should be specified in the standard config.

External application then should be able to call a specific jsreport REST method to get a restricted permission token for some specified id. The id can be a tenant id or user id of the external application. Retrieved token will then used when creating and accesing jsreport. jsreport will filter by the token only objects that were create with particular id.

## Widgets
We should not stick just to pdf reports. User should be able to easily design html live widgets running in the browser because it will be quite a quick win when we already have preview mechanisms and editor. The difference will be that recipe, javascript templating engine and script evaluation will run in the browser opposite to the typical server side rendering. We will introduce a client html recipe responsible for this.

jsreport server will be just a widget storage in this scenario.  But where are widgets will be pdf printing required and a lot of work for jsreport server.

## Implementation

Tasks need to be implemented:
1. enable CORS on the jsreport
2. test a playground jsreport studio embedding into an external web applications
3. add admin user authentication through config file
4. implement restricted permissions
5. implement client side html recipe
issue_labels.name: [enhancement]

issue_title: Asserting state on current page after button click, but before next page loads
correctly handle encoding of body parameter that is enum when api consum...
body:
correctly handle encoding of body parameter that is enum when api consumes application/json

Currently the UI sends just the bare string with no quotes around it when an API has a body parameter and comes application/json, which is not valid json. Now there is some argument as to whether even a quoted string by itself is valid json, but a lot of json parsers accept it and allow the API to be invoked. In its current form the API cannot be invoked from the UI no matter what json parser you're using. I tested this on a 2.x version of Jersey.

I am not really a UI developer, so please let me know if this is entirely the wrong approach or if anyone has a cleaner way to fix this. Thanks.
repo_description: Swagger UI is a dependency-free collection of HTML, Javascript, and CSS assets that dynamically generate beautiful documentation from a Swagger-compliant API.

issue_title: Example needs updating for graph api 2.2
body:
The `public_profile` scope is now limited to

```json
{
  "id": "10152969621155502",
  "first_name": "AJ",
  "gender": "male",
  "last_name": "ONeal",
  "link": "https://www.facebook.com/app_scoped_user_id/10152969621155502/",
  "locale": "en_US",
  "name": "AJ ONeal",
  "timezone": -7,
  "updated_time": "2015-01-19T02:26:31+0000",
  "verified": true
}
```

Also, here are some values you can use by default so that it works with 0 setup:

```javascript
var FACEBOOK_APP_ID = "746913342088510"
var FACEBOOK_APP_SECRET = "ad539732cbfbd60169f32336e257b37c";
// ...
callbackURL: "http://local.foobar3000.com:4080/auth/facebook/callback"
// ...
passport.authenticate('facebook', { scope: ['public_profile', 'email'] })
// ...
app.listen(4080)
```

The port must be 4080.

His problem is actually caused by `ejs.render` with a data object including the "filename" key. He's not doing anything wrong, it's just an issue of the choice of variable name. A big part of separating the data object from options was to avoid having magical reserved keys (like "filename" or "cache") in your data which would actually end up being opts.

As long as we have this backward-compat shim, we can't avoid some sort of special treatment -- copying them from data to opts for backward compat. Since opts are optional, there's also the possibility that this is just someone using the new API correctly who happens to be using one of the previously reserved keys (e.g., "filename"). There's not really a nice solution to this, so I'm inclined to remove the deprecation notices completely.

Deprecation notices are fine when you're calling a defined, discrete function that's going to go away, but it's harder in a case like this where we're trying to guess if they're relying on deprecated functionality. In this case, we're getting it wrong.

issue_title: JSDoc annotations
body: I agree with you 100% about JSDoc. I don't love it, but it's pretty much the only show in town for inline doc. I'm glad to see some detailed docs happening here. I'm not married to the current OOP Template approach, so this may need to change if we decide to do significant rewriting, but I do think the OOP approach is easier to understand than just throwing around objects and functions. We'll probably end up modifying rather than doing a big rewrite -- in any case, this is awesome!
