issue_title: non-aspect resize?
body:
After months of using this library I finally noticed that sharp does exactly how it it documented ;-)

Joking aside, I somehow managed to completely overlook the cropping behavior of resize() when used with two non-null parameters. Given the auto-logic when omitting one, and also having max() I somehow assumed that specifying both parameters would scale to the given size, ignoring the original aspect ratio, and essentially stretch and squeeze the image to fit.

I understand that this is a very uncommon and usually completely unwanted usecase for the general public. Unfortunately I do need it for my application, and I really don't want to switch to something else.

Am I overlooking something how this could be achieved already, or am I asking for a new feature that probably no one would use, except for me?

issue_title: support `it` in template function
body:
> `it` comes from http://olado.github.io/doT/

While I agree that we should make the conversion from other templating languages easier, there is simply no end for this. Jade uses `self`, for example, and it would be overkill if we have three or four (counting `l`) variables referencing the same thing. And thus, I consider not changing anything the best solution here.

> I think that `with` should be disable or removed in next version(so I pull request to development branch), then people use `locals` in template function is bad thing.

I don't think I understand this sentence.

(If you feel you can better express your opinions better in Chinese, please do, as it is my first language.)

> all tempaltes should have `<% var l = locals %>` in @TimothyGu 's way.

I personally don't feel that it is *that* inconvenient.

issue_title: Add an option to ignore all unneeded whitespace
body:
Benchmarking shows that sometimes too many

```js
__output += "        \n";
```

will have a very negative effect on performance. It is also one of the major reasons why doT is much faster than EJS, even though theoretically EJS is simpler.

New line slurping does get rid of the new line, but then you still have

```js
__output += "        ";
```
issue_labels.name: [enhancement]

issue_title: Find out why doT is so much faster
body:
Escape function ported in #50.

Now templates generated with `!_with` mode is about 55% as fast as doT's.

issue_title: support `it` in template function
body:
@zensh said (translated by me):

> In ES5, `with` is not allowed in strict mode.

Yes we already know that.

> [...]
>
> (an example showing how `with` fails in strict mode in the browser)
>
> In other words, `with` is deprecated and recommended against, at least in the browser. I just hope to have a shorter name for the locals object, `l`, `e`, and `ejs` all work (although I think `ejs` might be conflicted with `require('ejs')`). So that's why I suggested to use `it` as at least it is consistent as *something*.
>
> `locals` or `<% var l = locals %>` feels extremely redundant.

First, it is unlikely for us to change the default, definitely not in EJS v2 but unlikely in EJS v3.

Second, personally I am fine with using a shorter name like `it` or `l`, with this explanation. However the final weight of decision still lies in @mde's hands.

I'm trying to run Grunt locally for the first time on a fairly clean install (without even `nodejs` previously installed) of Ubuntu 14.04 (the most recent LTS edition), by cloning the github repository and switching to the `stable` branch.

Grunt installed fine (`sudo npm install -g grunt`), but then, `npm install` failed because my `~/tmp` directory was owned by `root`, but I guess that's the fault of how `npm` (or maybe `grunt`) installs on trusty, 'cos I don't think that `~/tmp` directory existed before. I just fixed the permissions (`sudo chown -R robin:robin ~/tmp`) and then `npm install` succeeded.

But then when I ran `grunt init`, I got these errors:

```
Loading "docker.js" tasks...ERROR
>> Error: Cannot find module 'watchr'
Loading "jscs.js" tasks...ERROR
>> Error: Cannot find module 'vow-fs'
Loading "sass.js" tasks...ERROR
>> Error: Cannot find module 'each-async'

Running "shell:bower" (shell) task

Running "update_submodules:default" (update_submodules) task

Running "concat:dev" (concat) task
File core/built/scripts/vendor-dev.js created.

Running "copy:dev" (copy) task
Copied 2 files
Warning: Task "sass" not found. Use --force to continue.

Aborted due to warnings.
```

Now knowing how to fix this (I checked `ruby-sass` was definitely installed) I just continued with `grunt init --force`.

Then when I type `npm start` I get this:

```
> ghost@0.5.8 start /home/robin/projects/Ghost
> node index


module.js:340
    throw err;
    ^
Error: Cannot find module 'sax'
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (module.js:338:15)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:280:25)
    at Module.require (module.js:364:17)
    at require (module.js:380:17)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/home/robin/projects/Ghost/node_modules/nodemailer/node_modules/aws-sdk/node_modules/xml2js/lib/xml2js.js:8:9)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/home/robin/projects/Ghost/node_modules/nodemailer/node_modules/aws-sdk/node_modules/xml2js/lib/xml2js.js:283:4)
    at Module._compile (module.js:456:26)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:474:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:356:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:312:12)
npm ERR! weird error 8
npm WARN This failure might be due to the use of legacy binary "node"
npm WARN For further explanations, please read
/usr/share/doc/nodejs/README.Debian
 
npm ERR! not ok code 0
```

Any ideas?

issue_title: Asserting state on current page after button click, but before next page loads
Asserting state on current page after button click, but before next page loads
body:
You can use `browser.ignoreSynchronization = true`, but I would caution against testing this kind of timing-specific thing in end to end tests, because sometimes the test will be running slowly and even without synchronization your test will fail. 

Please read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/angular/protractor/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#questions); these types of questions are ill-suited for GitHub. Thanks!

issue_title: `lastEvent` is not reset at the end of event handler wrapper
body:
Unless I am mistaken, the intent of logging the last event is when it was likely the trigger for the error. I was reading the notifier code (https://github.com/bugsnag/bugsnag-js/blob/master/src/bugsnag.js) 
 and realized `lastEvent` is never reset anywhere which suggests to me that if an event handler fires `lastEvent` is set with that event and then sent back with the next error on the page which may be completely unrelated to the event. I would have expected lastEvent to be cleared at the end of any event handler wrapper, because if the error didn't happen in the handler, it is no longer relevant.

issue_title: `lastEvent` is not reset at the end of event handler wrapper
body:
I understand, but actually it's come in very handy in the past. Where an `onclick` event has been the `lastEvent` and I have been able to correctly determine where the user was, and how they caused the error to occur. That event could be a second or two in the past, but the whole idea of `lastEvent` is to capture the last known event that fired, so it shouldn't ever be 'cleared'. I understand that if the last event was 2 minutes ago, it's probably irrelevant, but I don't really ever see that happen.

Let me know if that makes any sense :smile:

Hi @ytzong and welcome to Ghost!

If I understand your issue correctly you are looking for a way to get to the edit screen when you are visiting the published version of a post? This is already implemented by simply adding `/edit` at the end of the URL.

Example:
Post: `http://www.your-domain.com/post-name`
Edit:  `http://www.your-domain.com/post-name/edit`

If I understood wrong, please update your issue with more information about the behaviour you are looking for and I'm happy to reopen the issue.

issue_title: Race condition in our E2E tests
body:
@juliemr and I spent a little while hunting this one down yesterday.  The short of it is that [asynchronously writing `karma.conf.js`](https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/blob/master/test/e2e/support/world.coffee#L38) causes the tests to be asynchronous, and as a result two tests can run at the same time.  Specifically, I can consistently cause the following to happen on my OSX and Ubuntu machines:

1. [`proxy.feature`](https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/blob/master/test/e2e/proxy.feature) reaches the `fs.writeFile` line
2. [`reconnecting.feature`](https://github.com/karma-runner/karma/blob/master/test/e2e/reconnecting.feature) reaches the `fs.writeFile` line
3. `reconnecting.feature`'s callback is called
4. `proxy.feature`'s callback is called

The result is that both `reconnecting.feature` and `proxy.feature` read from a corrupted `karma.conf.js`, causing both tests to fail dramatically.  I see three possible solutions:

1. Get cucumber.js to wait for one test to finish before starting the next
2. Make writing a file synchronous
3. Randomize the file name for what is currently `karma.conf.js` so that collisions are unlikely

Solution 1 the best of course.  I dug into how `grunt-cucumberjs` invokes the tests, and basically it's just running cucumber's [command-line script](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/bin/cucumber.js).  I couldn't find a cucumber flag for waiting for asynchronous tests however (though I have been using cucumber for less than 24 hours).  So this solution seems unfeasible.

Solution 3 is a terrible idea, since it exposes us to more race conditions in the future*.  So I vote that we make writing the config file synchronous.  It's a little inefficient, but it's the simplest, most future-proof solution.

*Julie ran into an error about a port being in use at one point in time.  It could have been that two tests were both trying to run `karma start` at the same time

issue_title: `lastEvent` is not reset at the end of event handler wrapper
body:
This is definitely the intended behaviour, often you see something like this:

click "refresh" -> AJAX -> throw exception.

It's really handy to be able to see that it was refresh that was clicked. Obviously sometimes it's misleading, as correlation does not imply causation, but overall it seems positive to me.

In the future we'll move this to use the nascent breadcrumb support (bugsnag-android is the only library using it right now), but for now this is working as intended.

 and realized `lastEvent` is never reset anywhere which suggests to me that if an event handler fires `lastEvent` is set with that event and then sent back with the next error on the page which may be completely unrelated to the event. I would have expected lastEvent to be cleared at the end of any event handler wrapper, because if the error didn't happen in the handler, it is no longer relevant.

issue_title: boolean relationships
body:
> intersects by running an intersection and checking whether the result is nil

@tmcw yeah, that's pretty much what I had in mind. Agree that these should be separate implementations with performance front and center. I think most of these can be implemented to run very fast using modified variations of [turf-kinks](https://github.com/Turfjs/turf-kinks/blob/master/index.js). Throw in sweepline, or various other indexing strategies, and it should be quite performant. `contains` will probably be the most expensive.

For reference, this seems to be the exact specification that Shapely (and probably postgis, ogc, etc.) try to follow http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DE-9IM

Also, I believe Shapely uses planar geometry, but I think these calculations should be geodesic in Turf.

issue_title: {{navigation}} helper
body:
Sorry, I saw this whilst I was away but didn't have enough internet to reply and let you know that `{{url}}` was going to clash and be a bit complicated :(

The idea of our `{{url}}` helper (at present) is that it outputs the url for the current scope - so if you're currently outputting a post, and use `{{url}}` you'll get the url for that post. Likewise for tags, and authors, etc. It makes sense that the same should happen if you're in the scope of a navigation item, because what you want to do is exactly the same - output the url for the current object.

However, calling the property `url` alone isn't enough, the url helper & urlFor method will need to be updated to handle nav objects. The navigation template should then probably use `{{url absolute="true"}}`  by default in order to match the spec that all the urls be output in absolute form.

I hope that it is not too much extra work to make this happen. The benefit of moving the url logic all the way down into `config.urlFor` is that in future we'll be able to output navigation items in other ways than just the theme template - potentially useful for apps and who knows what.

issue_title: Resize image multiple times
body:
Hi Jonathan,

An undocumented feature is that if the input is a filename, you can do exactly what you're trying to achieve.

You're using a Buffer, which behaves slightly differently to work around a nuance of the V8 garbage collector.

An input Buffer containing compressed image data is copied and unreferenced as soon as the first call to `toFile` (or `toBuffer` or `pipe`) is made. This is to avoid the situation where, should the memory compaction stage of the V8 garbage collector run in the time between a resize task being queued and being processed, the Buffer could move without us knowing.

In your example this means the internal reference to `imgBuffer` held by the instance of `sharp` doesn't exist by the second call to `toFile`.

To provide the API you're expecting, we'd need to change this module to hold two copies of the input Buffer in memory at the same time, one in JavaScript land and one in C++ land. The newer version of V8 and the changes to Buffer allocation in Node.js 0.11 unstable (and io.js) might improve the situation, so I'd be happy to revisit this when they stabilise.

As an aside, the default behaviour is to crop with centre gravity so you can leave the `.crop(sharp.gravity.centre)` bit out.

issue_title: Add a key-press to re-run the specs under --watch
body: @al-the-x to most users, ⌃C isn't ‘send a signal to the program’, it's ‘get me out of this program to the place where I type other programs' names.’ And that's assuming they know that those two things are *different*. Hence my original suggestion of swallowing the space-bar or something; that's a more intuitive interface for the vast majority of users, than attempting to explain UNIX signals to them (or worse, stomping on possibly pre-existing expectations of being returned to the terminal, to do so)

issue_title: Segmentation fault: 11 on OSX in combination with gulp-responsive
body:
Hi Tom, thanks for the detailed report with backtrace.

The inclusion of `vips_cache_trim` leads me to believe you've run into #151, which was fixed in v0.9.0.

I notice `gulp-responsive` is using [v0.8.0](https://github.com/mahnunchik/gulp-responsive/blob/master/package.json#L37). Are you able to try updating the dependency to see if that fixes the problem for you?

issue_title: Resize image multiple times
body:
Thanks for such a comprehensive answer and the cropping shortcut, it's a tad more complicated than I imagined. 

I wonder if you can suggest the most efficient way of what I'm trying to do. I'm using the [multer middleware](https://github.com/expressjs/multer) to handle user image uploads, which you can either write straight to disk, or keep as a buffer. At the moment I'm keeping it as a buffer, then looping over it to make the three thumbnails and writing them to disk. 

It sounds like I could write it to disk, read it back with sharp and create the three thumbnails in a single chain like my example above. 

I imagine the former is more memory/CPU intensive, whereas the latter is more IO.
issue_labels.name: [question]

issue_title: isEnabled() assertion returns incorrect value for disabled <label> element
body:
I just discovered what I am pretty sure is a bug.

The markup I am using looks like this:
``` html
<label id='blah-label-id' disabled="disabled" data-ng-click="handleClick()">
<input type="radio">blah</label>
```

The Protractor assertion I am using looks like this:
```javascript
expect(element(by.id('blah-label-id')).isEnabled()).toBe(false);
```

However, the above assertion fails.

When I test it to see the result of `isEnabled()`, it returns `true`, when you'd expect it to return `false`.

I have tested this by calling `getAttribute('disabled')` on the same element – it returns `'true'` (as a string, not a boolean value).

Note that in the same suite of tests, I am successfully using the `isEnabled()` assertion on `<input type="range">`, `<input type="text">` and `<button>` elements.
issue_labels.name: [WebDriver issue/feature]

issue_title: Option to retry tests
body:
Tests should be consistent.  They should either always fail or always pass.  Unit tests are generally pretty consistent.  With functional tests, however, several factors outside of our control may cause a test to fail.  For example, my functional testing stack consists of MochaJS, WebDriverJS, and BrowserStack.  The tests usually pass.  However, in some cases, like when the network is congested or BrowserStack is slow in creating a VM session, a test may fail.

Since mocha doesn't support retries yet, I have to re-run test suites in their entirety.  With each suite taking a non-trivial amount of time (between 5 to 15 minutes) to complete, this solution isn't ideal.

It would be nice if mocha supported retries.  If a test in a suite fails, then I could retry that test instead of of re-running the entire suite.

issue_title: Resize image multiple times
body:
Untrusted user input? I recommend you write to disk rather than take the risk of filling memory. You'll benefit from OS-level file caching, which could well be faster than the memory hand-off between each V8/Node/sharp/libvips/libjpeg layer (I like to think of memory as being IO-bound).

You might want to look at [limitInputPixels](https://github.com/lovell/sharp#limitinputpixelspixels) for added safety too, although it is based on trusting the metadata of input files.
issue_labels.name: [question]

issue_title: Run `after` and `afterEach` even after spec failure
body:
I think the `after` and `afterEach` should run even if the `spec` fails. Sometimes its needed to because we might be doing some clean up work inside `after` and `afterEach` functions.

Example would be:
Let say I am testing a module which copies a directory recursively into a different directory. Now after the test is over I want to delete the newly created a directory as a cleanup.

Its like in the `database` world, when you test you manipulate the data inside the tables but when your test finishes you always `rollback` the changes regardless of failure or success.

  property isRelative is referenced.

issue_title: Returned promises do not get resolved
body:
I believe I narrowed it down. We had jasminewd installed in our root node_modules\ folder. Whenever jasminewd is installed in the root, and I uninstall 1.3.1 and install 1.6.1, I get the issue.

If I uninstall jasminewd from the root node_modules\ and then uninstall protractor 1.6.1, protractor works as expected. I even tried uninstalling jasminewd and reinstalling it and then updating protractor and got the same results.

In short:
jasminewd at root. uninstall protractor, install protractor -> **problems**
jasminewd at root, uninstall jasminewd, install jasminewd, uninstall protractor, install protractor -> **problem**

jasminewd at root, uninstall jasminewd, uninstall protractor, install protractor -> **WORKS**
issue_labels.name: [needs: more info]
